headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Earnings Release Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Earnings Release Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Paul Gifford. Please go, sir.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gwen. And thank you for joining us today as we discuss our fourth quarter 2009 results. In the room with us today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with some brief prepared remarks,
componenttext: Thank you, Gwen. And thank you for joining us today as we discuss our fourth quarter 2009 results. In the room with us today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with some brief prepared remarks, followed by Q&A. A presentation is available on our website, www.goodrich.com, which together with our press release, provides the basis for most of our remarks.Before we start, let me remind you that today's remarks include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, and actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. They are also detailed in today's earnings press release. I urge you to read them carefully. This call is being webcast and replays will be available at our Internet site beginning this afternoon. Once again, we ask that callers limit themselves to one question so we can get through all callers. Thank you very much for doing that. Now I'll turn the call over to Marshall, who will provide you with an overview of the fourth quarter 2009 results and our updated full year outlook for 2010.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. I assume you've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of those documents that you'll find helpful as you think about Goodrich. Rather than spend all of m
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. I assume you've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of those documents that you'll find helpful as you think about Goodrich. Rather than spend all of my prepared remarks on the information already contained in the press release, today, I will only spend a few minutes on our actual results for the fourth quarter and our outlook for 2010. Then I'll focus on trends and indicators of what we are seeing in our markets right now and what we think those trends mean to Goodrich. Overall, my remarks will be shorter than in the past which will leave more time for questions.Let's start with a quick overview of our fourth quarter results and our outlook for 2010. Our fourth quarter earnings per share of $0.82 per share were consistent with our prior outlook range of $0.72 to $0.87. Included in those earnings were several items that were non-operational in nature. The following items affected our fourth quarter 2009 earnings compared to the fourth quarter 2008. Higher expenses for restructuring, acquisition and China JV formation costs and environmental reserves totaling about $0.05 a share; higher share base compensation of about $0.05 this year; higher pension expense of about $0.13 per share; a higher tax rate, which resulted lower income of about $0.08 per share; and finally, last year, we had income related to the formation of our engine controls joint venture of about $0.12 per share. This was not repeated during the fourth quarter of 2009.The remaining change in income was primarily due to decreased commercial aftermarket sales. The unfavorable impact on income of lower aftermarket sales was once again partially offset by the continued success of our cost-containment initiatives that are in place throughout the company. Our fourth quarter 2009 sales, compared to fourth quarter 2008, decreased by about 3% or $53 million. Our large commercial airplane original equipment market experienced a sales increase of 22% and our regional, business and general aviation original equipment sales decreased by about 44% during the quarter.Sales in our commercial aftermarket channel decreased 20% in the fourth quarter 2009 compared to the fourth quarter 2008. Our defense and space market channel continues to show strong growth, with an increase in fourth quarter 2009 sales of 11% compared to the fourth quarter 2008. In the fourth quarter 2009, we achieved segment operating income margins of 14.2% compared to 16.3% in the fourth quarter of 2008. The fourth quarter 2009 margins included increased pension expense of about 1.6% of sales. For the fourth quarter 2009, net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures was excellent at $176 million or about 166% of income from continuing operations, even after we contributed $50 million more than our prior outlook to our worldwide pension plans. For the full year 2009, our free cash flow conversion was 87%, including total pension plan contributions of $238 million. If you exclude the $50 million in incremental pension contributions, our conversion rate would have been about 96%.During the fourth quarter, there were two especially noteworthy events. We completed the acquisition of Atlantic Inertial Systems or AIS during the fourth quarter. AIS is a leading provider of mission-critical guidance, stabilization and navigation products and systems for military and defense market. This will be a great addition to our portfolio, and their products serve markets that should see substantial growth in the years to come, even in a flat military spending environment. For 2010, we expect AIS to be slightly accretive to earnings including the impact of purchase accounting adjustments. The first slide of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner was the second noteworthy event. As a reminder, the Boeing 787 features a significant number of our products. Goodrich systems and components in the 787 include the company's nacelle and thrust reverser system, electric braking system, air data sensors, ice detectors, engine data concentrators, fuel management software and fuel quantity indicating systems. In addition, we provide the aircraft's proximity sensing system, the integrated fuel system for the auxiliary power unit, the cargo operating system, cabin attendant seating, exterior and flight deck lighting systems, integrated heated composite floor panels and a unique flight deck entry video surveillance system designed to interface with the aircraft's electronic flight bag system.Now I'll shift to our full year outlook for 2010. We believe the economic recovery will continue in 2010. And therefore, we expect sales growth in most of our major market channels for 2010. Overall, we expect 2010 sales of approximately $7.1 billion, up 6% to 7% from our 2009 sales of $6.7 billion. A little less than 1/2 the increase is from the added AIS sales. We expect large commercial airplane original equipment sales to increase by about 5%, assuming that current narrowbody production rates are maintained through at least early 2011, and 787 deliveries begin in late 2010. We expect regional, business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales to decrease by more than 10%, reflecting flat performance versus the second half of 2009. Large commercial regional, business and general aviation airplane aftermarket sales are expected to increase by about 4% to 7%, assuming that worldwide available seat miles, ASMs, increase in the range of 1% to 3% in 2010. We expect aftermarket sales to continue to be weak for the first few months of 2010, with more significant recovery beginning towards the middle of the year. That said, we do expect the first quarter to be sequentially higher than the fourth quarter of 2009.Finally, defense and space sales of both original equipment and aftermarket products and services are expected to increase by about 15%, including sales generated by the AIS acquisition.Our outlook for 2010 net income per diluted share remains the same as we announced last October, in a range of $4.15 to $4.40. For 2010, we continue to believe that the first quarter will be higher than fourth quarter 2009, but will be our weakest quarter in 2010. Our 2010 outlook incorporates the following assumptions: A full year effective tax rate of 29% to 30%, reducing income per diluted share by about $0.19 compared to our 2009 results, pension expense is expected to be about the same as pension expense recorded in 2009. During 2009, we achieved a return on U.S. plan assets of about 11%. We will use a discount rate of about 5.9% for our U.S. plans in 2010.For 2010, we expect net cash flow provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures to exceed 85% of net income, a little better than we forecast last October. We continue to expect capital expenditures for 2010 to be in a range of $250 million to $275 million,And now expect pension contributions to be between $100 million and $150 million.Now I'll spend a few minutes on our market channels and some recent information about what we're seeing in them. Our expectations for large commercial production rates haven't changed since our prior outlook. We continue to expect Boeing and Airbus to maintain narrowbody production rates, and that they will deliver about the same number of airplanes in total as they delivered in 2009. For the commercial aftermarket, some of the macro indicators are showing improvement. Passenger airline trends continue to improve. Airline load factors remain at high levels, and RPM data continues to show positive trends. There are indications that some airlines will be raising capacity in 2010 compared to 2009.Rate traffic, which is usually a leading indicator of passenger recovery, has continued to rebound. According to IATA data, freight traffic in November of 2009 was strongly ahead of the same period in 2008. Keep in mind that there is usually a lag between traffic and capacity improvements and higher aftermarket sales, and this lag is different for all of our products. We expect that our first quarter aftermarket sales will be sequentially higher than our fourth quarter 2009 sales, but they will still be well below levels achieved during the first quarter 2009. Within our businesses, we are seeing some interesting things. Some of these observations are based on only two to three weeks data. So while they're hopeful signs, they are not yet trends.Landings for planes that we have under cost for great [ph] landing agreements were flat to slightly up in December 2009 compared to December 2008. And our wheel and brake order backlog increased sequentially in December 2009 compared to November 2009. In our Aerostructures business, piece parts sales are higher in early January than they were in December, and intake levels at our MRO facilities in U.S. and Europe are higher in January than they were in November and December of 2009. Major part sales in the fourth quarter of last year decreased significantly compared to both the prior and year-ago quarters. But the fourth quarter sales levels are consistent with our quarterly expectations for all of 2010.Aftermarket backlog in our Interiors business appears to have stabilized, which has order intake in our Landing Gear business. The market for our defense and space products remains strong. Our fourth quarter defense and space sales continue to show above-trend growth at 11%, and we expect 2010 sales to grow at a rate of about 15%. Without AIS sales, we still would be expecting a good growth of about 5% in this market channel. Overall, our performance during a very challenging 2009 was very good, and we look forward to 2010 as a year during which we return to a growth trend in most of our markets.We've been able to maintain strong margins despite significantly higher pension expense and reduced sales in our most profitable market channel. I attribute our strong results to a continued focus on cost control and operational excellence. Our focus on flight-critical systems with the non-discretionary aftermarket, our strong positions on newer large commercial aircraft and our significant and growing Defense and Space business has positioned us very well to grow sales and earnings as the economy emerges from this recession. Our longer-term prospects for sustainable growth are also excellent, fueled by our significant market share gains on new commercial and military aircraft and development. Our financial position is excellent, with about $800 million of cash on our balance sheet and a significant cash flow generation expectations for 2010. This allows us to continue to seek acquisition opportunities that would enhance shareholder value and help our company to grow and thrive. I'm looking forward to talking to you all throughout 2010 about Goodrich as we continue to tell our story. Now I look forward to your questions.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttextpreview: Could you give us maybe a little color on -- you're saying that you are seeing, with the aircraft that you track, you are seeing some improvements. And while it's still early, by geography or so, is there any particular geography that's standing out more
componenttext: Could you give us maybe a little color on -- you're saying that you are seeing, with the aircraft that you track, you are seeing some improvements. And while it's still early, by geography or so, is there any particular geography that's standing out more than the others?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well certainly. Asia has had most of the growth. But we kind of had kind of across-the-board improvement. So it isn't just any one region, but Asia just had a higher growth rate than anywhere else.
componenttext: Well certainly. Asia has had most of the growth. But we kind of had kind of across-the-board improvement. So it isn't just any one region, but Asia just had a higher growth rate than anywhere else.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you've characterized just broad based, really?
componenttext: So you've characterized just broad based, really?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the margin performance, still, I think you've talked a lot of your lean initiatives and your cost controls, and we're obviously seeing evidence of that in terms of where your margins are kind of troughing out. Is this about the level, I mean,
componenttext: In terms of the margin performance, still, I think you've talked a lot of your lean initiatives and your cost controls, and we're obviously seeing evidence of that in terms of where your margins are kind of troughing out. Is this about the level, I mean, 14% or so that you would expect to be able to hold?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would hope so. Our outlook for the year is higher than that, obviously. And we've had as high as 17% in the past. And we're not going to let up on the cost control and the continuous improvement initiatives. I just had 250 plus of our top leaders a
componenttext: Yes, I would hope so. Our outlook for the year is higher than that, obviously. And we've had as high as 17% in the past. And we're not going to let up on the cost control and the continuous improvement initiatives. I just had 250 plus of our top leaders across the company together for a couple of days in the first week of January, and that's one thing and we're really emphasizing. Let's not lose our cost containment when the markets do recover. Let's continue to push to be much leaner than we have been in the past when times had been better. And also, let's continue to really push the cash flow. We want to get that cash flow percentage above 100% in the future.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Robert Spingarn with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Robert Spingarn with Credit Suisse.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Guys, I don't know if this is for Marshall or for Scott, but I wanted to talk about something we all look at as a run rate and had to translate that into guidance. If we look at the quarter results and add back what would be viewed as one time, how do we
componenttext: Guys, I don't know if this is for Marshall or for Scott, but I wanted to talk about something we all look at as a run rate and had to translate that into guidance. If we look at the quarter results and add back what would be viewed as one time, how do we get to your guidance, to the midrange of your guidance? I suspect that the aftermarket growth, let's call that 5%, you've said in the past, that's about $0.06 per percentage point? So maybe that's $0.30, but how do we think about the real run rate in this fourth quarter, and then apply that $0.30?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's two slightly different questions. I mean, if you think about what we saw in the fourth quarter that is unusual, there's probably roughly $0.10 of share in the fourth quarter numbers that's unusual, non-operational if you will. And that relates to s
componenttext: That's two slightly different questions. I mean, if you think about what we saw in the fourth quarter that is unusual, there's probably roughly $0.10 of share in the fourth quarter numbers that's unusual, non-operational if you will. And that relates to some reserve activities that we've had and restructuring, environmental, compensation reserves, et cetera that are higher than we would expect on an ongoing basis; so about a $0.10 there. And then as we mentioned, you are starting from a pretty low level of aftermarket that we expect to improve on sequentially and get growth throughout the year 2010. So the run rate is clearly above the level that we've posted in Q4 of 2009 as a starting point. When we look at our full year, if you try to gap 2009 from continuing ops of $4.43 to our guidance for 2010, there's probably four items that I'd focus on. Two up, two down. Again, restructuring, compensation reserves, other reserves, foreign exchange, that probably adds about $0.15 to our 2010 numbers. The other positive is coming from the sales activity, as you mentioned, aftermarket sales, we do expect those to be up in 2010. They're high-margin sales. So if we achieve growth rates there, we'll get incremental margin from that. Our defense and space sales is also growing. If you strip out the effect of the acquisition, they're up well. Regional business, general aviation, OE sales however are down. So the net of that is probably somewhere around a quarter. And then on the downside, we had a pretty high level of contract accounting adjustments, deferred revenue adjustments in 2009 that we would expect not to repeat at that same level in 2010. And also, we'll have low-charge hardware going to the OEs as they start to ramp up production on 787 as we start to win positions on the 737 carbon programs as well. So higher level of that activity, and then higher tax rate in 2010 versus 2009. So that's roughly $0.40 or so of negative. So the pluses and minuses are about to offset, which is why our guidance is about flat in 2010 versus 2009. And the whole trend there will be focused on how fast the aftermarket improves sequentially going through 2010. We expect it to be better in the first quarter, and the pace of that recovery will define those results.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Would you say that aftermarket is your source of greatest either upside or downside?
componenttext: Would you say that aftermarket is your source of greatest either upside or downside?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say yes.
componenttext: I would say yes.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Rob, one of the things, if you look at our run rate here towards the end of the year, we've talked to you before about the majors in the nacelle side, they're very hard to predict and they're lumpy. But what we're counting on in our outlook for 2010 v
componenttext: And Rob, one of the things, if you look at our run rate here towards the end of the year, we've talked to you before about the majors in the nacelle side, they're very hard to predict and they're lumpy. But what we're counting on in our outlook for 2010 versus 2009 is no increase in those majors. And so far, as I indicated in my prepared marks, our piece parts sales and sales in interior systems has trended upward as January has progressed.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Joe Nadol with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Joe Nadol with JPMorgan.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, actually I'm going to ask you a similar question, but coming from a slightly different angle. Could you walk us through the changes in the 2010 forecast from October. This bridge, pension was one item, OE sales, just what the relative contributions
componenttext: Scott, actually I'm going to ask you a similar question, but coming from a slightly different angle. Could you walk us through the changes in the 2010 forecast from October. This bridge, pension was one item, OE sales, just what the relative contributions were? And then specifically, what you're seeing on OE to bring you down from, I think, close to 10% to around half that level? And then what other sort of swing items that are on OE?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, the bridge from where we were in October to where we are now for 2010 is real simple. It's frankly just two items, pension, improved from where our expectations were when we last spoke to the point where pension expense is now expected to be flat, t
componenttext: John, the bridge from where we were in October to where we are now for 2010 is real simple. It's frankly just two items, pension, improved from where our expectations were when we last spoke to the point where pension expense is now expected to be flat, that's worth about $0.14 a share favorable from our last outlook. And we're starting the year 2010 from a lower sales level and aftermarket. So our total full year 2010 estimated aftermarket sales are down from where we were. Same growth rate, but off of a lower base. So $50 million or so less aftermarket sales of the margins we've indicated is about $0.12 a share negative. So it basically offsets the gain that we had from pension. So that's why we've left our guidance exactly where it is. So really no other changes in the big pictures around corporate costs or margin expectations in our businesses, et cetera. Tax rates, all very consistent with where we were before.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so the OE is not enough of a change to move the needle on EPS, it may be offset by AIS or something?
componenttext: And so the OE is not enough of a change to move the needle on EPS, it may be offset by AIS or something?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well actually the OE side in dollar terms is about where we thought it was in October. In fact, it's really kind of the opposite of the aftermarket. We finished a little stronger in OE in the fourth quarter so the growth rate comes down just a little bit.
componenttext: Well actually the OE side in dollar terms is about where we thought it was in October. In fact, it's really kind of the opposite of the aftermarket. We finished a little stronger in OE in the fourth quarter so the growth rate comes down just a little bit. But the dollar sales are very consistent with what we thought before.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Robert Stallard with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll go next to Robert Stallard with Macquarie.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, you commented briefly about the cash position and you're targeting 85% conversion this year. On previous presentations you've done, you've shown at this stage of the cycle we could probably expect cash to be close to 100% or better. When do you
componenttext: Marshall, you commented briefly about the cash position and you're targeting 85% conversion this year. On previous presentations you've done, you've shown at this stage of the cycle we could probably expect cash to be close to 100% or better. When do you think Goodrich could get up to that level in the next couple of years?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well you're right about the previous presentations, and we were looking at this through the cycle. And normally, when the OE production rates turn down, that's when all the requirements for working capital and everything turn down and we go above 100%. We
componenttext: Well you're right about the previous presentations, and we were looking at this through the cycle. And normally, when the OE production rates turn down, that's when all the requirements for working capital and everything turn down and we go above 100%. We're not counting on much of a change in the near future in the OE production rates, but we're still pushing hard to get to that 100%. I don't know yet whether we can do it in 2011. But as you saw, our outlook for this year, it's greater than 85%. And it is right at the front of the hearts and minds of every one of our SBU presidents right now in working hard to really drive that in because we feel like we have more ability to generate cash then we've shown in the past.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll just add to that. In 2009, while our reported conversion was 87%, we did accelerate $50 million of pension contributions from 2010 into '09. So if you back that out, we would have reported 96%. So good performance. And we still are heavy on the devel
componenttext: I'll just add to that. In 2009, while our reported conversion was 87%, we did accelerate $50 million of pension contributions from 2010 into '09. So if you back that out, we would have reported 96%. So good performance. And we still are heavy on the development program for 787, A350, two big regional programs. So that's still at an elevated level.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was going to follow up on this because -- how much did the 787 alter this pattern because that starts to ship next year or later this year for you?
componenttext: I was going to follow up on this because -- how much did the 787 alter this pattern because that starts to ship next year or later this year for you?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In the latter part of this year, we're adding tooling to start early stages of production. We have higher cost than what we expect over the long term, so that adds to the cash flow inventory perspective as well. So if that starts to ramp up, that doe
componenttext: Yes. In the latter part of this year, we're adding tooling to start early stages of production. We have higher cost than what we expect over the long term, so that adds to the cash flow inventory perspective as well. So if that starts to ramp up, that does put pressure. But as Marshall said, the focus on the company is on the things that we can control; working capital, inventory, receivable, performance, et cetera. So we hope to offset most of that, hope to keep taxes below book, et cetera.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ronald Epstein with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ronald Epstein with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: I just want to dig down a little bit more on the aftermarket. So in the quarter year-over-year was down about 20%, is that right?

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: If we think about it sequentially, what happened from Q3 to Q4?

componenttext: It was about down 10%.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it was Q4 that's kind of potentially the trough?
componenttext: So it was Q4 that's kind of potentially the trough?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well the down 10% is not unusual because we were back the last several years sequentially. And we've been down about that each fourth quarter, spent 8% to 10% the last three years. It's not out of the ordinary in terms of the cycle of our products. Now so
componenttext: Well the down 10% is not unusual because we were back the last several years sequentially. And we've been down about that each fourth quarter, spent 8% to 10% the last three years. It's not out of the ordinary in terms of the cycle of our products. Now some of the -- a lot of the businesses were relatively flat in that third to fourth quarter. So if you look forward, as I said before, the running rate we did with the majors and nacelles doesn't have to go up during 2010 for us to hit our forecast.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the way I was trying to think about the 2010 outlook, if things are a little bit weak in the first half of the year, are you expecting potential double-digit growth in the second half of the year, are they aftermarket?
componenttext: I guess the way I was trying to think about the 2010 outlook, if things are a little bit weak in the first half of the year, are you expecting potential double-digit growth in the second half of the year, are they aftermarket?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well we've forecasted weak in the first half of the year, and we would expect that second half to be significantly more growth, we said 4% to 7% for the year. You'll see a lot less in the front end than you will in the back end. It's just the way we think
componenttext: Well we've forecasted weak in the first half of the year, and we would expect that second half to be significantly more growth, we said 4% to 7% for the year. You'll see a lot less in the front end than you will in the back end. It's just the way we think its going to recover because of the lag you get between some of the indicators out there and capacity.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, Scott, could you just talk about pricing, as far as pricing, I would think at this point 2010 pricing has gone through -- what kind of price increases did you get on spares this year relative to prior years? And did that kind of stayed with what
componenttext: Marshall, Scott, could you just talk about pricing, as far as pricing, I would think at this point 2010 pricing has gone through -- what kind of price increases did you get on spares this year relative to prior years? And did that kind of stayed with what you've got baked into your 4% to 7% aftermarket forecasts?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well we're not counting on a lot of pricing here in 2010. The market is still soft, and we're working with airline customers to have win-win situations. Sometimes that means you're not going to get any real pricing in order to get more share. And that wil
componenttext: Well we're not counting on a lot of pricing here in 2010. The market is still soft, and we're working with airline customers to have win-win situations. Sometimes that means you're not going to get any real pricing in order to get more share. And that will come back at some point in time, and we will get to select price increases. But we're not counting on a lot of price increase for this next year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on 787, can you talk about where you are in terms of negotiations with Boeing in terms of any release? And also, when would you expect to start to -- I guess, what shipset are you on for 787? When would you actually start to see the impact of a ramp u
componenttext: And on 787, can you talk about where you are in terms of negotiations with Boeing in terms of any release? And also, when would you expect to start to -- I guess, what shipset are you on for 787? When would you actually start to see the impact of a ramp up there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to negotiations, me and all my friends at Boeing agreed not to discuss it publicly, but it's ongoing and making progress. And on the second question on what shipset is what?
componenttext: With regards to negotiations, me and all my friends at Boeing agreed not to discuss it publicly, but it's ongoing and making progress. And on the second question on what shipset is what?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: Where are you in terms of shipsets on -- what number are you on 787? When would you actually start to see a pick up there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: It kind of varies, David, depending on which products we're on, and which engine type, et cetera. But we're somewhere between 17 to 23.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, what have you assumed, if anything, for contract revisions in nacelles in 2010?
componenttext: Scott, what have you assumed, if anything, for contract revisions in nacelles in 2010?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're assuming that they'll be positive, but not at the same level that we've had in 2009. Between nacelles, we don't break where we have adjustments in the deferred revenue side. We had about $45 million of positive free tax adjustments in 2009. We think
componenttext: We're assuming that they'll be positive, but not at the same level that we've had in 2009. Between nacelles, we don't break where we have adjustments in the deferred revenue side. We had about $45 million of positive free tax adjustments in 2009. We think they'll be still positive, but at a much lower level in 2010.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: When we listened to Boeing yesterday, we sort of sensed a little bit more upbeat tone on narrowbody, and they actually gave us deferral numbers that did decelerate in the quarter. And as you guys mentioned, the airline traffic numbers are getting better.
componenttext: When we listened to Boeing yesterday, we sort of sensed a little bit more upbeat tone on narrowbody, and they actually gave us deferral numbers that did decelerate in the quarter. And as you guys mentioned, the airline traffic numbers are getting better. Do you sense the same and can you just give us your latest thinking on the likely outcome on narrowbody here?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's right. We sense the same for both manufacturers for narrowbody. At one time, last October, we were saying, "Well, gosh, you could see a downturn in the fourth quarter.", I don't see that now. I think the OE, just like they say, is going
componenttext: No, I think that's right. We sense the same for both manufacturers for narrowbody. At one time, last October, we were saying, "Well, gosh, you could see a downturn in the fourth quarter.", I don't see that now. I think the OE, just like they say, is going to continue. Boeing sold out for the year. So that means if there is a downturn down the road in 2011, that it's going to be further down the road. And we'll just have to see how orders happen over this next year. But I think its a better position OE now than it was three months ago.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the language in your press release, I think is the assumption that they're unchanged through at least '11. Is '12 more likely higher, flat or lower?
componenttext: So the language in your press release, I think is the assumption that they're unchanged through at least '11. Is '12 more likely higher, flat or lower?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not very good at predicting that far out, especially for my customers. But it does look a lot like the cycle got extended.
componenttext: I'm not very good at predicting that far out, especially for my customers. But it does look a lot like the cycle got extended.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But can you update us on what the 2011 pension tailwind would be as of the new assumptions?
componenttext: But can you update us on what the 2011 pension tailwind would be as of the new assumptions?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think I have that. I think the normal pace, if you just hold discount rates and you get normal returns, it's typically, $10 million to $15 million pretax. So if you envision a higher discount rate environment as you go forward, it would add to tha
componenttext: I don't think I have that. I think the normal pace, if you just hold discount rates and you get normal returns, it's typically, $10 million to $15 million pretax. So if you envision a higher discount rate environment as you go forward, it would add to that. But I think the normal trend down in pension expense from just hitting your 8.75% return in flat discount rate is about $10 million pretax.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: We'll go next to Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you indicate what -- if any discussions you're having with the customers regarding kind of ramping up purchases in the back part of the year, and are you worried that while traffic demand is picking up, airlines aren't going to be adding capacity beca
componenttext: Can you indicate what -- if any discussions you're having with the customers regarding kind of ramping up purchases in the back part of the year, and are you worried that while traffic demand is picking up, airlines aren't going to be adding capacity because of the pricing environment? Can you just kind of help us understand that a little bit?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are you talking primarily with the airlines or with the OEs?
componenttext: Are you talking primarily with the airlines or with the OEs?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: With the airlines adding capacity.
componenttext: With the airlines adding capacity.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Troy, I think that if you think about -- we don't have to add bricks and mortar capacity, because we're open rating at a level that significantly below where we were operating last year. So we've got the capacity to do a whole lot more in terms of afterma
componenttext: Troy, I think that if you think about -- we don't have to add bricks and mortar capacity, because we're open rating at a level that significantly below where we were operating last year. So we've got the capacity to do a whole lot more in terms of aftermarket support. Our aftermarket sales are down 16% this year from where they were last year. So the capacity there...

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean as airlines add capacity. I mean, do you think airlines do add capacity or do you think they're a little more controlled coming out of this? And are you really having discussions with airlines that are talking about, yes, we'd like to purchase some
componenttext: I mean as airlines add capacity. I mean, do you think airlines do add capacity or do you think they're a little more controlled coming out of this? And are you really having discussions with airlines that are talking about, yes, we'd like to purchase some parts in the back part of the year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the point is on the aftermarket, it a very short cycle between order to delivery. So we're out anywhere from days and weeks on some of our products, to the very long end are majors and are in nacelle, and Thrust Reverser business are months. But i
componenttext: I think the point is on the aftermarket, it a very short cycle between order to delivery. So we're out anywhere from days and weeks on some of our products, to the very long end are majors and are in nacelle, and Thrust Reverser business are months. But it's not -- they wouldn't be talking to us yet about anticipated orders in the back half of the year. We're talking to them about Q1 and maybe Q2 at this point.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing they would talk to us about is if they were going to do some kind of retrofit program on a current fleet that they had, whether it was evacuation slides or something like that. But we've not had any kind of discussions, scott's right. It's
componenttext: The only thing they would talk to us about is if they were going to do some kind of retrofit program on a current fleet that they had, whether it was evacuation slides or something like that. But we've not had any kind of discussions, scott's right. It's a very short cycle of capacity, I mean, the order environment, and we've got plenty of capacity to deal with it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we're kind of waiting around until June maybe for kind of some orders to support the back-half growth?
componenttext: So we're kind of waiting around until June maybe for kind of some orders to support the back-half growth?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. We will just keep watching the trends of the orders that come in daily, and what our book-to-bill ends up in our various SBUs. We've seen some positive signs of that and we'll continue to monitor it. But airlines are not ordering before they have to.
componenttext: No. We will just keep watching the trends of the orders that come in daily, and what our book-to-bill ends up in our various SBUs. We've seen some positive signs of that and we'll continue to monitor it. But airlines are not ordering before they have to. They're in the last quarter, and it's bigger the last month or so, we've seen some better activity in some of our businesses. I mean, actuation for one with a very positive upward in terms of the fourth quarter this year. So we're seeing it in different businesses.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll go next to Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, the trends just noted actually sounds pretty positive in December and January in terms of -- I know its early yet, for the aftermarket. But I guess, can you talk a little bit about why back in October you would've expected probably less of a seq
componenttext: Marshall, the trends just noted actually sounds pretty positive in December and January in terms of -- I know its early yet, for the aftermarket. But I guess, can you talk a little bit about why back in October you would've expected probably less of a sequential decline and less of a year-over-year decline in this fourth quarter than the year before? And really, what changed and why didn't those sales come in as expected?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the biggest reason why the fourth quarter wasn't as good, and we did say this back in the third quarter, that it was hard to predict the major -- major, these are big nacelle pieces like fan cowls and thrust reversers and things like that are high
componenttext: I think the biggest reason why the fourth quarter wasn't as good, and we did say this back in the third quarter, that it was hard to predict the major -- major, these are big nacelle pieces like fan cowls and thrust reversers and things like that are high dollar content but don't happen on a regular basis, and they're very much tied to a lot of how many spare engines are out there too. So right now, there are a lot of spare engines. I mean, if you looked at some of the aftermarket results of the engine makers, you'd see that. So that's why we're not counting on, in 2010, getting a higher run rate in those than we've experienced in 2009. Because we think it will take a while for that to be pushed through the system. But on the piece parts, we will see added piece part sales, in part because utilization of aircraft is going up. For one thing, we've seen in the fourth quarter, a better utilization rate on the narrow bodies than we saw in the first half of 2009. That means, there's going to be more piece part sales as time goes on.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when do we see the majors? Does that require an engine shop visit and kind of major overhaul? Is that when it gets...
componenttext: And when do we see the majors? Does that require an engine shop visit and kind of major overhaul? Is that when it gets...

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. It's just -- if they're really running the fleet full out, which they haven't then, because utilization's been down, then they've got less spare engines, and less spare nacelle major components. When that utilization starts to get back up. They'll sta
componenttext: No. It's just -- if they're really running the fleet full out, which they haven't then, because utilization's been down, then they've got less spare engines, and less spare nacelle major components. When that utilization starts to get back up. They'll start using those and we'll have less spares out there, and that's when we'll start seeing those major orders start to happen. So because it's so hard to predict, that's why we're not counting on anything greater than flat. And if we get surprised, I hope we get surprised to the upside.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the inventory level, and I guess with topline pressure, why aren't we seeing less of an inventory build? I'm just trying to think about how much of that -- not just the capitalized cost, it seems like even beyond that, there is some actual inventory bu
componenttext: On the inventory level, and I guess with topline pressure, why aren't we seeing less of an inventory build? I'm just trying to think about how much of that -- not just the capitalized cost, it seems like even beyond that, there is some actual inventory build. And sort of related to that, is when does that preproduction peak and start to decline?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The inventory build that we saw in -- if you just look at the balance sheet numbers, it passed [ph] a little bit because foreign exchange -- our inventory outside of the non-product stuff at aerostructures that's related to contract accounting, on the bal
componenttext: The inventory build that we saw in -- if you just look at the balance sheet numbers, it passed [ph] a little bit because foreign exchange -- our inventory outside of the non-product stuff at aerostructures that's related to contract accounting, on the balance sheet, was up $135 million this year. But 2/3 of that growth was due to FX or acquisitions as we bring the inventory that comes with the acquisition on to our balance sheet. So our actual product inventory growth in 2009, from a cash flow standpoint, was only $40 million. We can still do better than that, frankly, but that was not a bad performance. And some of what you're doing there is -- when the aftermarket, if it declines, you still have new order intake in excess of the declining sales. So we built a little bit of inventory there, and we still a lot of inventory to support A380 and 787 entry into service. So that will wind down over the next few years as well, or at least not grow as much as the sales grow.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Joe Campbell with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: We'll go next to Joe Campbell with Barclays Capital.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, the Airbus is telling us that we should be looking for re-engining announcements during 2010, they're not more specific. But it's clear that they would like to do this if they could get whatever it is they're looking for, nail down with the engi
componenttext: Marshall, the Airbus is telling us that we should be looking for re-engining announcements during 2010, they're not more specific. But it's clear that they would like to do this if they could get whatever it is they're looking for, nail down with the engine guys. What that does it mean? And Boeing has said, well, we're not leading this charge but we'll do what we need to do, we'll follow with the right responses. What are the risks and the opportunities for you as a nacelle guy, if we see the single aisle planes have either improved engine, I don't know if they have the same nacelles and everything is inside, or whether there's new nacelles that go with these things, and what does GTF mean?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, if Airbus made a decision to re-engine the A320 family, they'd only do it if they get enough of a efficiency increase out of the engine. And so if they believe they can get that out of an engine maker, then they would consider it. And for G
componenttext: Well, I think, if Airbus made a decision to re-engine the A320 family, they'd only do it if they get enough of a efficiency increase out of the engine. And so if they believe they can get that out of an engine maker, then they would consider it. And for Goodrich, that means that we would probably work hard to win a nacelle on that engine.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It would be recompeted, though we would -- I mean, if there was a lead X [ph] or an improved B2500 or GTF, they wouldn't -- even if they have the same form, fit and function to, say an existing CFM56. New nacelles will be [indiscernible] .
componenttext: It would be recompeted, though we would -- I mean, if there was a lead X [ph] or an improved B2500 or GTF, they wouldn't -- even if they have the same form, fit and function to, say an existing CFM56. New nacelles will be [indiscernible] .

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's only possible if they'd have the same form, fit and function. It would have to be customized nacelle for a new engine. So Airbus would more than likely recompete it.
componenttext: It's only possible if they'd have the same form, fit and function. It would have to be customized nacelle for a new engine. So Airbus would more than likely recompete it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And do you see -- I mean is this something that from your perspective, you're getting ready for? Or is this something that they seem to be unsure of what they're up to. And so when you know -- when they know, you'll know how behave? Or is this something t
componenttext: And do you see -- I mean is this something that from your perspective, you're getting ready for? Or is this something that they seem to be unsure of what they're up to. And so when you know -- when they know, you'll know how behave? Or is this something that's consuming time inside your shop?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Whether they make the decision to go ahead or not, we're preparing, because we want to be ready if and when they make that decision.
componenttext: Whether they make the decision to go ahead or not, we're preparing, because we want to be ready if and when they make that decision.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what's the competition for them to do it in-house or is there another shop that would...
componenttext: And what's the competition for them to do it in-house or is there another shop that would...

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. It would be the usual competition. It would Safran, could be a Spirit.
componenttext: No. It would be the usual competition. It would Safran, could be a Spirit.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Doug Horn [ph] with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: We'll go next to Doug Horn [ph] with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have been systematically moving supplier content from high costs regions of the world and to low costs regions, places like China, Indonesia, Mexico, India, that will be sustaining. And we continue to move more part numbers there every year. So we
componenttext: Yes. We have been systematically moving supplier content from high costs regions of the world and to low costs regions, places like China, Indonesia, Mexico, India, that will be sustaining. And we continue to move more part numbers there every year. So we would expect to be able to maintain that kind of a relative cost differential. All of our businesses work hard on the Toyota manufacturing system continuous improvement. So even in our higher cost regions, we're still bringing waste out of the system. We also have looked for ways to better leverage overhead cost through greater centralized data processing with our SAP system, which is about 60% there now in terms of covering the whole company. We've been able to consolidate a number of our financial transaction functions that way, that should be lasting. We've taken our indirect cost down pretty substantially over the last year, some of that will come back. But that's was what I was referring to early on in my remarks about trying to keep as much as that as possible, because we're learning ways to operate, that are leaner than when we we're growing rapidly when the market was on the uptick. So we're working very hard on sustaining a good percentage of those costs.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've got larger opportunities to bring cost down in our European businesses because it is a high cost environment over there. And it's a double whammy when you have a weak dollar, because your manufacturing in dollars and paying in dollars
componenttext: Well, I think we've got larger opportunities to bring cost down in our European businesses because it is a high cost environment over there. And it's a double whammy when you have a weak dollar, because your manufacturing in dollars and paying in dollars and you're getting your revenues in -- I mean you're [ph] manufacturing in pound sterling and euros, but you're getting paid in dollars, so you got a squeeze on the margin. And so in addition to becoming more efficient, particularly on the supply base, it also reduces our FX exposure.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's a good possibility. We'll just have to see whether or not we -- we always use some of the margin to get more business out of customers. So in order to drive that top line more and we do it the best we can on the cost to leverage to the bott
componenttext: I think that's a good possibility. We'll just have to see whether or not we -- we always use some of the margin to get more business out of customers. So in order to drive that top line more and we do it the best we can on the cost to leverage to the bottom.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Herbert with Wedbush.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Herbert with Wedbush.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: A question specifically on the 787, it seems like if I remember from what you said earlier in the call, your give or take, depending on configuration, ships at soft of 18 to 20, 22 somewhere in there. Boeing indicated they're looking for having about 30 o
componenttext: A question specifically on the 787, it seems like if I remember from what you said earlier in the call, your give or take, depending on configuration, ships at soft of 18 to 20, 22 somewhere in there. Boeing indicated they're looking for having about 30 or so ready by the end of 2010, can you just talk about, from over the course of 2010 within aerostructures and the nacelles, particularly, sort of the production ramp and what we should be looking for in terms of volume specifically for the 787.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a little hard to hear but I thought heard you say can we support the production ramp up?
componenttext: It's a little hard to hear but I thought heard you say can we support the production ramp up?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I know you can support the production ramp, but just what we should be looking for in terms of the volume ramp, considering where you are now versus sort of the 30 that Boeing has talked about having ready by the end of 2010?
componenttext: No. I know you can support the production ramp, but just what we should be looking for in terms of the volume ramp, considering where you are now versus sort of the 30 that Boeing has talked about having ready by the end of 2010?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we're not trying to build ahead, let's put it that way. We're trying to build in time for their aircraft and we're pretty confident we can do that, going forward. So we have to rely on Boeing's estimate for the number of aircraft that they'r
componenttext: Well, I mean, we're not trying to build ahead, let's put it that way. We're trying to build in time for their aircraft and we're pretty confident we can do that, going forward. So we have to rely on Boeing's estimate for the number of aircraft that they're going to build, and that's what we're prepared to do.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Because it's looking like the ramp isn't -- I mean, it's clearly there but not as maybe significant over the course of the year as maybe initially anticipated?
componenttext: Okay. Because it's looking like the ramp isn't -- I mean, it's clearly there but not as maybe significant over the course of the year as maybe initially anticipated?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, right now, we're not seeing that. We're right in line with what Boeing is asking us to do.
componenttext: Well, right now, we're not seeing that. We're right in line with what Boeing is asking us to do.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: One quick question on Airbus. I mean obviously, after yesterday, it seems like there's a lot of confidence, especially around 2010, for Boeing and Single Island [ph] in particular. Do you have the same confidence level or what's your confidence around del
componenttext: One quick question on Airbus. I mean obviously, after yesterday, it seems like there's a lot of confidence, especially around 2010, for Boeing and Single Island [ph] in particular. Do you have the same confidence level or what's your confidence around delivery schedules for Airbus, specifically the A320 in 2010 and 2011?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, I think they're going to hang right in there too.
componenttext: Actually, I think they're going to hang right in there too.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you're not seeing any additional softness maybe in some of their statements than what we've seen from Boeing?
componenttext: So you're not seeing any additional softness maybe in some of their statements than what we've seen from Boeing?

componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Howard Rubel with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to just follow-up on development programs, Marshall, as you look out at what you're needing to do in order to support a number of these new development programs. Are you finding disruptions declining? Or are there still some areas where you are fin
componenttext: I want to just follow-up on development programs, Marshall, as you look out at what you're needing to do in order to support a number of these new development programs. Are you finding disruptions declining? Or are there still some areas where you are finding late engineering releases?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think we have -- we're definitely on the downslope here, in terms of finishing up on our major programs that go on like 787, and obviously on A380, we're already there. So no. I don't see any major disruptions on our part right now.
componenttext: No. I think we have -- we're definitely on the downslope here, in terms of finishing up on our major programs that go on like 787, and obviously on A380, we're already there. So no. I don't see any major disruptions on our part right now.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Eric Hugel with Stephens.
componenttext: We'll go next to Eric Hugel with Stephens.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, I just wanted to follow up on your earlier comment, where you said that Q4 part sales were consistent with your expected 2010 levels. I just want to make sure I'm not being too simplistic or not looking at the whole of the aftermarket, but the i
componenttext: Marshall, I just wanted to follow up on your earlier comment, where you said that Q4 part sales were consistent with your expected 2010 levels. I just want to make sure I'm not being too simplistic or not looking at the whole of the aftermarket, but the implication in your commercial aftermarket guidance of 4% to 7% growth, does that really just reflect sort of flat demand? And really, what you're seeing that 4 to 7% growth, that's really just sort of easier comps, and if you actually do see on underlying activity pick up, we could see better numbers?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just clarify for you and everyone, the majors, the nacelle majors, a whole nacelle, thrust reverser, fan cowl, that kind of thing are difficult to predict. We're down a fair amount in '09 and what we're predicting for '10 is no recovery in that ove
componenttext: Let me just clarify for you and everyone, the majors, the nacelle majors, a whole nacelle, thrust reverser, fan cowl, that kind of thing are difficult to predict. We're down a fair amount in '09 and what we're predicting for '10 is no recovery in that overall sales level. That is not true for the rest of the aftermarket parts and services that we're predicting. That's why were predicting 4% to 7% increase in overall revenues in the aftermarket, because we will get piece part increase. We will see increased revenues in the aftermarket for 2010. It's just that, because of the number of surplus engines out there, we've chosen not to up our forecast on the majors.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, what's your D&A expectations for the year with AIS in the mix?
componenttext: Scott, what's your D&A expectations for the year with AIS in the mix?

componenttextpreview: Yes, for 2010, D&A should be around $290 million. It's up about $40 million from this year.
componenttext: Yes, for 2010, D&A should be around $290 million. It's up about $40 million from this year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: We'll go next to George Shapiro with Access 342.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, I want to pursue a little bit more the aftermarket. End of October, early November, you lowered your aftermarket forecast to decline 13% to 15%. And then we came out, down 16%. So it was only like two months to go in the year. Now did that just
componenttext: Marshall, I want to pursue a little bit more the aftermarket. End of October, early November, you lowered your aftermarket forecast to decline 13% to 15%. And then we came out, down 16%. So it was only like two months to go in the year. Now did that just suggest that this aftermarket is that unpredictable or was there something that actually happened in the last two months?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, it was primarily the weakness in the service side, MRO. Our piece parts held in there pretty darn well. And as I said before, the majors are hard to predict. I mean, they're very lumpy when they come in. But it's primarily on the service side.
componenttext: No, it was primarily the weakness in the service side, MRO. Our piece parts held in there pretty darn well. And as I said before, the majors are hard to predict. I mean, they're very lumpy when they come in. But it's primarily on the service side.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've said that down 10% sequentially is what you've seen in the past. The data I have, which suggest that's greater than normal. I mean, I show that in '06, '07, '08, respectively, sequentially, you were up three, down two, and then, down nine. Maybe I
componenttext: You've said that down 10% sequentially is what you've seen in the past. The data I have, which suggest that's greater than normal. I mean, I show that in '06, '07, '08, respectively, sequentially, you were up three, down two, and then, down nine. Maybe I don't have a long enough perspective but I just want to...

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: George, just 2008, was down 9%. So we were trying to say that it was not inconsistent with what we saw from fourth quarter 2008. We saw about the same relative impact in 2009. But the overall plan was the aftermarket declined sequentially in the fourth qu
componenttext: George, just 2008, was down 9%. So we were trying to say that it was not inconsistent with what we saw from fourth quarter 2008. We saw about the same relative impact in 2009. But the overall plan was the aftermarket declined sequentially in the fourth quarter of '09 was highly concentrated in our business, specifically just in nacelles and interiors and primarily associated with majors. Some of which we expected, some of which we didn't. And the MRO side, the rest of the business, the other market channels that we supply were fairly flat from Q3 to Q4. So we're concentrated and we think at least, on the majors as Marshall said, they're at a level that we expect to be at for the rest of 2010. So the growth is coming in the right areas. And we've seen stabilization in those other market channels.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: '08 was comparable, fourth quarter downward in '09 to 10%. And historically, the fourth quarter is our weakest.
componenttext: '08 was comparable, fourth quarter downward in '09 to 10%. And historically, the fourth quarter is our weakest.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I recognize that. I just had '06 and '07 were down much less.
componenttext: I recognize that. I just had '06 and '07 were down much less.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I didn't mean to imply they were comparable to the 9% or 10%. They were just generally weaker than the other quarters.
componenttext: I didn't mean to imply they were comparable to the 9% or 10%. They were just generally weaker than the other quarters.

componenttext: We'll go next to Carter Leake with Davenport & Company.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've often referred to the maintenance sweet spot of five to seven, 10 to 15-year old aircraft  rolling through there maintenance-intensive windows. But given that aftermarket does not track as any of us had expected, should we assume the sweet spot is
componenttext: You've often referred to the maintenance sweet spot of five to seven, 10 to 15-year old aircraft  rolling through there maintenance-intensive windows. But given that aftermarket does not track as any of us had expected, should we assume the sweet spot is still ahead of us or is it currently ongoing and providing a positive offset to currently depressed utilization-driven demand?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're going to see a gradual increase in utilization. I think that will be the first thing that comes back. We did see some increase in utilization from the first half of '09 into the third quarter of '09 through the narrow bodies, which is
componenttext: Well, I think we're going to see a gradual increase in utilization. I think that will be the first thing that comes back. We did see some increase in utilization from the first half of '09 into the third quarter of '09 through the narrow bodies, which is good news. And so as we gave our outlook in October for 2010, we expect that utilization would be about flat from where it was in 2009. If we're fortunate, we'll actually see an increased utilization going forward. And that should add more in terms of MRO and piece part sales.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But don't you view this as separately, the sweet spot thesis is a bit different than utilization driven? The sweet spot would be that the aircraft is due, sort of if you evaluate [ph] of demand. Am I looking at that correctly?
componenttext: But don't you view this as separately, the sweet spot thesis is a bit different than utilization driven? The sweet spot would be that the aircraft is due, sort of if you evaluate [ph] of demand. Am I looking at that correctly?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what you're referring to, as we've said in the past about the A320, that when they get to that five to seven years in life, that they start getting in that sweet spot of overhaul of the nacelle system. That will still take place during 2010.
componenttext: Well, I think what you're referring to, as we've said in the past about the A320, that when they get to that five to seven years in life, that they start getting in that sweet spot of overhaul of the nacelle system. That will still take place during 2010. It's just that if you're not utilizing the aircraft as much, it takes a little longer. And that's why we're very focused on the utilization.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also, Carter, when the Airlines get under some pressure, they're able to defer some of these repairs a little bit. So if you're driving for cash, and try to keep your head above water, and some of these things can be pushed out six months or a year. T
componenttext: And also, Carter, when the Airlines get under some pressure, they're able to defer some of these repairs a little bit. So if you're driving for cash, and try to keep your head above water, and some of these things can be pushed out six months or a year. That's why we say five to seven years in that window somewhere. So in this environment, it's not a surprise that things edge [ph] out. But you absolutely will still see that occur. It's just a little later.

componenttext: No, it's right in line with utilization rates.

componenttext: I hate to do this, you give a great disclosure and your answers are clear. I'm just confused. And that is the run rate of piece parts in the fourth quarter. I think I've heard you say is consistent with the outlook you have for '10. We know the larger parts are going to be down in '10 just by the math, right? It's declining all year and then flat as the current run rate. Does that imply the MRO is up a lot or am I misunderstanding something there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're misunderstanding it. What we're saying is that the very large sections of the nacelle, which we call majors, that's not a steady drumbeat of orders. Never has been even in -- when the market was going up. So what we've seen in '09 is a lot less maj
componenttext: You're misunderstanding it. What we're saying is that the very large sections of the nacelle, which we call majors, that's not a steady drumbeat of orders. Never has been even in -- when the market was going up. So what we've seen in '09 is a lot less majors because there are a lot more spare engines out there to be cannibalized if they need it. And it's really kind of flattened out here in the last quarter or so. And what we're seeing -- we're not predicting any higher level of major sales for Goodrich for 2010 than we have seen here in the last number of months.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So that implies, for the year, it's down. Correct?
componenttext: So that implies, for the year, it's down. Correct?

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Because it was declining during '09.
componenttext: Because it was declining during '09.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. So we've actually have the majors down for the full year. But they're at probably a run rate that we think we can sustain. Now in the piece parts, whether it's nacelles or any other one of our businesses, we will see growth in those.
componenttext: Right. So we've actually have the majors down for the full year. But they're at probably a run rate that we think we can sustain. Now in the piece parts, whether it's nacelles or any other one of our businesses, we will see growth in those.

componenttext: MRO is significantly lower in terms of margin because most of what you do there is selling the labor content. The piece parts go whether we repair a nacelle or wheel, break or whatever or somebody else does. The parts -- there still our parts. So those attracted better margin than the MRO side. There's much more competition there.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Would you just remind me of the shipset value on the 787 and the A350, please? And maybe just talk me through the margin on the early sales to both of these aircraft?
componenttext: Would you just remind me of the shipset value on the 787 and the A350, please? And maybe just talk me through the margin on the early sales to both of these aircraft?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In both cases, we've got $3 million to $4 million of OE shipset content on those aircraft. And we've got wheels and brakes, which have a very low OE content but they generate very quick turn on the aftermarket. So there's little content attributed to that
componenttext: In both cases, we've got $3 million to $4 million of OE shipset content on those aircraft. And we've got wheels and brakes, which have a very low OE content but they generate very quick turn on the aftermarket. So there's little content attributed to that in those numbers that I just gave you. From a margin standpoint though, as 787 enters into service, we expect very low OE margins on those products. And that's not atypical for companies like us that provide major systems to the OEs. They're typically very price competitive, especially early on in the program. As those programs mature, and you drive cost out, you can get margin on the OE side. But early on, they're typically low to no margin. And that's what we would expect for 787 as it enters service.

componenttext: No, it's usually a year for it to build. Remember, these are 20-, 30-year production programs. It takes time to optimize your production, lean out your manufacturing, optimize your supply chain, et cetera..

componenttext: What you count on is in-fill [ph] volume. It's getting the aftermarket over time. So the overall margin is very good.
