headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day everyone and welcome to the Goodrich first quarter 2010 earnings release results conference call. Today’s call is being recorded. The press has been invited to participate in today’s conference in a listen-only mode. At this time for opening
componenttext: Good day everyone and welcome to the Goodrich first quarter 2010 earnings release results conference call. Today’s call is being recorded. The press has been invited to participate in today’s conference in a listen-only mode. At this time for opening remarks and introductions I would like to turn the call over to your Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Paul Gifford; please go ahead, sir.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you for joining today as we discuss our first quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO.We will start with brief prepared remarks followed by Q&A
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you for joining today as we discuss our first quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO.
We will start with brief prepared remarks followed by Q&A. The presentation is available on our website www.goodrich.com, which together with our press release provides the basis for most of our remarks. Before we start, let me remind you that today’s remarks include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties and actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements.
The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time-to-time in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our Annual Report on Form 10-K and Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q. They are also detailed in today’s earnings press release. I urge you to read them carefully.
This conference call is being web cast and replays will be available at our internet site beginning this afternoon. Once again we ask that callers limit themselves to one question each, so that we can have time to allow all of you to ask your questions. If you have further unanswered questions, you can get back into the queue and ask another question time permitting.
Now I’ll turn the call over to Marshall, who will provide with you an overview of our first quarter 2010 results and our updated full year outlook for 2010.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul and good morning everyone. I assume you’ve all had the opportunity to review today’s earnings release and the related presentation. There’s a lot of information in both these documents that you’ll find helpful as you think about Goodr
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul and good morning everyone. I assume you’ve all had the opportunity to review today’s earnings release and the related presentation. There’s a lot of information in both these documents that you’ll find helpful as you think about Goodrich. So, rather than spend all of my prepared remarks on the information already contained in the press release, today I will only spend a few minutes on our first quarter results and our outlook for 2010.
Then I’ll focus on trends and indicators of what we are seeing in our markets right now and what we think those trends mean for Goodrich. Let’s start with a quick overview of our first quarter results and our outlook for the year.
Our first quarter results were consistent with our expectations. Earnings per share of $0.87 were solidly operational, and were impacted by tax expense of approximately $0.12 per share higher than our prior outlook for the full year tax rate. Specifically, we incurred additional tax expense of $0.08 in the quarter related to the passage of the healthcare reform legislation, and additional expense of $0.02 per share related to delays in extending the R&D tax credit.
Our first quarter 2010 sales were nearly the same as our first quarter 2009 sales. Large commercial original equipment market channel experienced a sales increase of 12%, which was mostly attributable to the impact of the Boeing strike on quarter one 2009 sales. Our regional business and general aviation original equipment sales decreased by about 31% compared to the first quarter of 2009.
Sales in this market channel declined abruptly in the first three quarters of 2009, stabilized in the fourth quarter, and we experienced sequential growth in quarter one of 2010. Sales in our commercial aftermarket channel decreased 10% in the first quarter of 2010 compared to the first quarter of 2009. However, three of our eight commercial businesses reported higher aftermarket sales in the first quarter 2010 compared to the first quarter of 2009.
Sequentially, commercial aftermarket sales were 9% higher in the first quarter 2010 than during the fourth quarter of 2009 with seven of our eight commercial businesses recording higher aftermarket sales in Q1 2010 than Q4 of 2009.
Our defense and space sales exhibited strong growth in the first quarter of 2010, increasing by 13% compared to the first quarter of 2009. Our acquisition of AIS contributed 8% of this growth, in organic sales about 5%, driven primarily by strong sales in our sensors and integrated systems business, in our intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance business.
In the first quarter 2010, we achieved segment operating income margins of 15.3% compared to 17.2% in the first quarter of 2009. Sequentially, segment operating income margins were more than 1% higher than the fourth quarter of 2009. The sequential improvement was due to higher aftermarket sales and continuing emphasis on cost containment.
Net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures for the first quarter 2010 was $9 million. During the first quarter 2010, we contributed $105 to our worldwide pension plans compared to contributions of $8 million in the first quarter of 2009. Excluding the first quarter 2010 pension contribution, net cash provided by operating activities, minus capital expenditures, was more than 100% of net income.
Now I will shift to our full year outlook for 2010. Our full year 2010 outlook for sales remains at approximately $7.1 billion and represents growth of about 6% compared to 2009. The outlook for 2010 net income per diluted share remains in a range of $4.15 to $4.40, even though we now expect a higher effective tax rate for the year.
We continue to expect large commercial airplane original equipment sales to increase by about 5%, assuming the 787 deliveries begin in late 2010. We expect regional business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales to decrease by more than 10%, reflecting flat performance versus the second half of 2009. We have not changed our expectations for large commercial regional business and general aviation aftermarket sales growth of about 4% to 7%, assuming that worldwide available seat miles, ASMs, increasing in the range of 1% to 3% in 2010.
We continue to expect sequentially higher aftermarket sales each quarter as we progress through the year, but don't expect sales to be higher than the year ago quarter until the second half. Finally, our outlook for defense and space sales growth is unchanged at about 15%, including sales generated by the AIS acquisition.
2010 outlook for earnings per diluted share includes a fully effective tax rate of about 31% for 2010, an increase from our prior outlook of 29% to 30%. Our tax rate outlook continues to include a full year benefit of approximately 1.5% related to an assumed extension of the US R&D tax credit, retroactive to the beginning of the year.
For 2010, we expect net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures to exceed 85% of net income, and we expect capital expenditures for 2010 to be in a range of $250 million to $275 million, and expect worldwide pension contributions to be $100 million to $150 million. Approximately $105 million has been funded year-to-date.
Now I will spend a few minutes on current activities and trends in our primary market channels. Large commercial OE production outlook has improved significantly over the last three months. Airbus announced that it is increasing A320 production rate about 6% to 36 per month later this year, and Boeing has announced that it will increase 777 production from 5 per month to 7 per month in the middle of next year, and that it will accelerate its 747-8 rate increase to 2 per month from 2013, moving forward to 2012.
For the commercial aftermarket, some of the macro indicators are showing improvements. Our sequential sales improvement from the fourth quarter 2009 was the first sequential improvement since the third quarter of 2008, and we continue to believe that each quarter this year will show sequential improvements over the previous quarter. We expect strong commercial aftermarket growth beyond 2010. Over the last two years, the active fleet of commercial aircraft has grown by about 6%. As the fleet continues to grow and airline maintenance practices return to more normal levels they should see very good growth rates driven by both catch up demand and normal ageing.
Passenger airline and freight trains continue to improve. Airline load factors remain at high levels especially in the US and RBM [ph] data continues to show positive trends. Within our businesses, we are also seeing some positive developments that indicate recovery in the aftermarket is under way. During the first quarter, our wheels and brakes business saw a pickup in activity on 747 and A330 airplanes, an indicator of good international and freight traffic trends.
In our aerostructures business, piece part sales trends continued to be favorable. Major part sales in the first quarter were consistent with our expectations for the year. Order intake and coding [ph] activity in most of our MRO shops is also improving. We are also seeing favorable code aging trends, indicating that airplanes, airlines rather are making decisions to order parts repairs faster than they were last year.
Market for our defense and space products remains strong. Our first quarter defense and space sales growth of 13% included 5% organic growth and was in line with our expectations. Overall, our performance during the first quarter was in line with our expectations and the quarter was a good step towards this being a year in which we returned to growth trends in most of our markets.
We have been able to maintain strong margins despite our class of aftermarket sales through a continued focus on cost control and operational excellence. Our longer-term prospects for sustainable growth are also excellent, fuelled by our significant market share gains on new commercial and military aircraft currently in development.
As I noted in our investor conference last year, I believe that Goodrich can grow to a company with more than $10 billion in sales and higher segment operating income margins by 2014. Our financial position remains excellent with almost $800 million of cash on our balance sheet, and significant cash flow generation expectations for 2010. This allows us to continue to seek acquisition opportunities that would further enhance our growth rates and cash generation and drive shareholder value. I look forward to talking to all of you through 2010 as we continue to tell the Goodrich story.
And now we will open it up for questions.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) And now we will go to our first question from the line of Troy Lahr with Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) And now we will go to our first question from the line of Troy Lahr with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. I was wondering if you guys could just talk maybe a little bit how aftermarket gets to 4% to 7% for the year coming off of a down 10%, and it looks like there is going to be a really big pick up there. Is that - do you think that that is aircraft
componenttext: Thanks. I was wondering if you guys could just talk maybe a little bit how aftermarket gets to 4% to 7% for the year coming off of a down 10%, and it looks like there is going to be a really big pick up there. Is that - do you think that that is aircraft coming out of the desert and then there is going to be spare parts, or do you think airlines slowly are adding that much more capacity in the back half of the year. Maybe just kind of walk through your assumptions there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I can give you the assumptions and between Marshall and I, we can give you a little bit more color on what is developing in the aftermarket. In terms of assumptions, we did see the 9% growth from the fourth quarter of 2009. So that sets us on a real solid
componenttext:
I can give you the assumptions and between Marshall and I, we can give you a little bit more color on what is developing in the aftermarket. In terms of assumptions, we did see the 9% growth from the fourth quarter of 2009. So that sets us on a real solid growth trend sequentially. To get to the 4% to 7%, we need to average somewhere in the 4% to 5% sequential growth for each of the next three quarters to get into that range.
And based on the trends that we have seen so far developing in the first quarter with respect to order backlog, the pace of orders, code activities, things like that as well as the breath that we’ve seen across all of our commercially oriented businesses. We have pretty good confidence that at least moving into Q2, we are on that same kind of a track. We don't have a lot of visibility going out to Q3 and Q4, but if you look at the kind of macro trends, the recovering schedules that the airlines have posted through the middle of the year et cetera, it seems to be shaping up very consistent with those expectations.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. And then just lastly with Boeing and Airbus looking to reengine A320s and 737s possibly, what opportunities do you have out there, do you think you can take some market share gains, and is there a possibility Boeing could add two engines as
componenttext: Okay, thanks. And then just lastly with Boeing and Airbus looking to reengine A320s and 737s possibly, what opportunities do you have out there, do you think you can take some market share gains, and is there a possibility Boeing could add two engines as an option and that could really help you out a lot?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you are going to have to talk to Boeing about what options they might do, but I think that on a Boeing re-engining, we don't have the sales on that. We do supply spirit on parts of those nacelles. We would expect to try to maintain that kind of re
componenttext:
I think you are going to have to talk to Boeing about what options they might do, but I think that on a Boeing re-engining, we don't have the sales on that. We do supply spirit on parts of those nacelles. We would expect to try to maintain that kind of relationships, especially if they term this a derivative and it is another single engine procurement. If it is two engine procurement that opens up opportunities, more opportunities.
As far as Airbus goes, we would intend to bid on that. We currently have the nacelles on both the v2500 and CFM56. And we think there will be lot of aircraft even with the old model that will overlap for a while. We think there will be probably at least 6000 of those aircraft eventually flying made through 2015, and aftermarket long after that. So even if we worked on the new one, we are still going to get lot of aftermarket, but we would expect to be on the new one if they decide to reengine. And I don't think - those decisions haven't been made. So a lot of this is pure speculation at this point. So that is about all I can tell you.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I appreciate that. Thanks guys.
componenttext: No, I appreciate that. Thanks guys.

componenttext: Good morning.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You said that three of your eight businesses were seeing better aftermarket, and were up in their aftermarket sales, could you talk about the differences between the three, what the three are and the differences between the ones that are improving and the
componenttext: You said that three of your eight businesses were seeing better aftermarket, and were up in their aftermarket sales, could you talk about the differences between the three, what the three are and the differences between the ones that are improving and the ones that have not yet seen that improvement?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, a couple of the businesses that saw improvement year-over-year, wheels and brakes saw improvement, our actuation systems business did, and our sensors and integrated systems business also saw improvement year-over-year, and at least the first two of
componenttext: Yes, a couple of the businesses that saw improvement year-over-year, wheels and brakes saw improvement, our actuation systems business did, and our sensors and integrated systems business also saw improvement year-over-year, and at least the first two of those - I think there is a good tailwind from the secular trend of just ageing at aircraft, where we have a lot of content. We have got the flight control actuation systems on the A320 aircraft and as they continue to age you know, we just see good year-over-year growth in that particular business. The wheels and brakes business is one of the earlier businesses to turn because it is got the shorter cycle from airline activity to aftermarket sales. So, you know we think that is being driven by the upturn in aircraft activity and actuation actually driven more by the longer term trend of lot of content on high-volume production airplanes that are aging, and therefore are driving a lot of additional aftermarket.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: If you think about wheels and brakes in particular, that is a total aftermarket business, because as you well know we give away the wheels and brakes to the OE. So you don't get any sales credit on that side of it. So as activity picks up in the worldwide
componenttext: If you think about wheels and brakes in particular, that is a total aftermarket business, because as you well know we give away the wheels and brakes to the OE. So you don't get any sales credit on that side of it. So as activity picks up in the worldwide fleet, you are going to see an increase in the wheels and brakes activity.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: But if you go to the five that you did not see the growth, how would you describe those, in other words what is different there?
componenttext: But if you go to the five that you did not see the growth, how would you describe those, in other words what is different there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Doug, I would say first of all it is a very hard comp from the first quarter of ’09, because remember when we got towards the end of ’08, those were peak aftermarket sales for Goodrich. So some of them had tremendous sales during that first quarter al
componenttext: Doug, I would say first of all it is a very hard comp from the first quarter of ’09, because remember when we got towards the end of ’08, those were peak aftermarket sales for Goodrich. So some of them had tremendous sales during that first quarter also. And so it is just a harder comp, which doesn't mean as we said almost every business you had sequentially greater sales from the fourth quarter. So we are on the right trend. It is just a tough comp.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: There is nothing special about those businesses, in other words different types of trends that you are seeing there?
componenttext: There is nothing special about those businesses, in other words different types of trends that you are seeing there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: All of them are a little bit different because they have a little bit different percentage of their business, [inaudible]. That is why I went back and talked about the wheels and brakes; given it is 100% aftermarket. It is a very good indicator.
componenttext: All of them are a little bit different because they have a little bit different percentage of their business, [inaudible]. That is why I went back and talked about the wheels and brakes; given it is 100% aftermarket. It is a very good indicator.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay, great. Thank you.

componenttext: We have been trying to work with airlines, and make sure we are very competitive, and we are seeing volume come back [ph], and we are very pleased with that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to follow up on Troy’s question about the sequential trend you expect to see, this would mean that you would end this year with a pretty healthy aftermarket growth rate. Do you expect that trend to continue into 2011?
componenttext: Okay. And just to follow up on Troy’s question about the sequential trend you expect to see, this would mean that you would end this year with a pretty healthy aftermarket growth rate. Do you expect that trend to continue into 2011?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: You mean - I would expect the trend to be even better than 2011 from the standpoint of further amount of economic recovery worldwide. I think we will have a greater amount of activity, airline activity in 2011 than we have in 2010.

componenttextpreview: No, we are basing that 4% to 5% on 1% to 3% ASMs worldwide. We get ASMs back in that 4% to 5% normal rate. I would expect us to be able to grow at a faster rate.
componenttext: No, we are basing that 4% to 5% on 1% to 3% ASMs worldwide. We get ASMs back in that 4% to 5% normal rate. I would expect us to be able to grow at a faster rate.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, yes. Thank you very much. You mentioned you took 3 million of step up in the electronics, and if you add that back you had a 14% margin. It looked pretty good. Given that is military; should we assume that that sort of level is sustainable going forwa
componenttext: Hi, yes. Thank you very much. You mentioned you took 3 million of step up in the electronics, and if you add that back you had a 14% margin. It looked pretty good. Given that is military; should we assume that that sort of level is sustainable going forward?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Cai, in fact, even - it may be even a little better than that because we also had a contract adjustment in that electronics systems segment that cost us about a point in margin. So if you eliminate both the inventory step up and that contract adjustm
componenttext: Yes, Cai, in fact, even - it may be even a little better than that because we also had a contract adjustment in that electronics systems segment that cost us about a point in margin. So if you eliminate both the inventory step up and that contract adjustment, normalized margins in electronics were actually closer to 15%. And that is kind of where we have guided for the full year 2010, and very consistent with what we would expect going forward.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: So, even with the intangibles you can do 15%?
componenttext: So, even with the intangibles you can do 15%?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the business that we've bought is a good margin business, and very high EBITDA margins, and also lot of growth that we expect in that business, and through the first three months of operation, it has performed very well, very much on track with what
componenttext: Yes, the business that we've bought is a good margin business, and very high EBITDA margins, and also lot of growth that we expect in that business, and through the first three months of operation, it has performed very well, very much on track with what we had anticipated. So, that is not going to be a margin degradation for us, for that business. It should add to the growth rate and should not affect our margins going forward.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: I think, you know, your guidance implied that overall operating margins would be down a little bit year-to-year and fairly it looks like because the intangibles in this area might have been. This area is flat and aftermarket is coming back in the other areas, because it now looked like operating margins may be flat to up for the year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We kind of said 15% to 16% margins is what we expect for the year. So that's flat you know, maybe toward the end of the year. You know, it could be a little bit better. We think we’ll still be in that 15% to 16% for the full year though.
componenttext: We kind of said 15% to 16% margins is what we expect for the year. So that's flat you know, maybe toward the end of the year. You know, it could be a little bit better. We think we’ll still be in that 15% to 16% for the full year though.

componenttextpreview: Okay.
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Towards the end of the year you know, when we start to get some 787s shipments coming in that will be a little bit of a drag on margins, but by that time we’ll start see higher aftermarket. So I think you know that 15% to 16% to me looks pretty solid an
componenttext: Towards the end of the year you know, when we start to get some 787s shipments coming in that will be a little bit of a drag on margins, but by that time we’ll start see higher aftermarket. So I think you know that 15% to 16% to me looks pretty solid and based on the good performance in the first quarter, I think there is you know, every reason to believe that will be well within that range.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Last one is if you look at corporate G&A it was high close to $34 million in the first quarter, why was it that high and what are we now looking for for the full year?
componenttext: Last one is if you look at corporate G&A it was high close to $34 million in the first quarter, why was it that high and what are we now looking for for the full year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: There are a few unusual things in the G&A area in the first quarter. We fully expect that to go back to the level that we guided towards of $31 million to $32 million per quarter from the second, third, and fourth quarter rest of the year. But the couple
componenttext: There are a few unusual things in the G&A area in the first quarter. We fully expect that to go back to the level that we guided towards of $31 million to $32 million per quarter from the second, third, and fourth quarter rest of the year. But the couple of unusual items in the first quarter were related to foreign exchange and some compensation accruals and some timing differences, things like vacation accrual where we had higher expense in the first quarter, but that’ll actually lead back and be favorable during the last three quarters of a year. So the message there is you know, we were $38 million in the first quarter. We’ll be back down to $31 to $32 we think for the rest of the year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, good morning Marshall, Scott, Paul. Marshall, regarding the aftermarket I guess what I want to drill in I guess a little more as you said you're seeing the increase in the piece parts. Could you give us maybe just a little more color like where you'r
componenttext: Yes, good morning Marshall, Scott, Paul. Marshall, regarding the aftermarket I guess what I want to drill in I guess a little more as you said you're seeing the increase in the piece parts. Could you give us maybe just a little more color like where you're seeing that, if it is particular regions that you are starting to get some strength from more than others or is it more broad-based, and then also regarding back to Rob’s question about faster growth in 2011, would that be an assumption that you’ll start to see a pick up from the majors?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as piece parts, when we say piece parts, we're talking about aerostructures, all right, our largest business, and that is seeing an up-tick in the piece parts and we track those daily. So we monitor it very, very closely, and so that is tracking ve
componenttext: As far as piece parts, when we say piece parts, we're talking about aerostructures, all right, our largest business, and that is seeing an up-tick in the piece parts and we track those daily. So we monitor it very, very closely, and so that is tracking very nicely to our forecast. The majors, which are very large pieces of the nacelle structure or the thrust reverser have always been lumpy in terms of sales during the year, but what we've seen so far in the first quarter is absolutely consistent with the rate we were in the last half of 2009, and so when we get to 2011 and there is more activity, we get back to more normal ASMs in some of these, and we get through the kind of engine destocking. I think we'll see a greater amount of major sales by the time we get to 2011.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, now that's helpful, and Scott just quickly on cash conversion, how should we think about this going forward now that we're starting to see a real increase on the OE side. You know, this is obviously different from reengining just in general higher O
componenttext: Okay, now that's helpful, and Scott just quickly on cash conversion, how should we think about this going forward now that we're starting to see a real increase on the OE side. You know, this is obviously different from reengining just in general higher OE rates going forward?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You know, we'll have to see how that plays out on the working capital side, but I think we'll be able to manage that and still get above our 85%.
componenttext: You know, we'll have to see how that plays out on the working capital side, but I think we'll be able to manage that and still get above our 85%.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: Okay, great. Thank you.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. I was wondering if you could just dig into the nacelle aftermarket business specifically. Looks like it didn't do as well as some of the others, and I was wondering maybe Marshall if you could characterize that business a little bit. It's, y
componenttext: Good morning. I was wondering if you could just dig into the nacelle aftermarket business specifically. Looks like it didn't do as well as some of the others, and I was wondering maybe Marshall if you could characterize that business a little bit. It's, you know, it's more demographically driven, I suppose that some other businesses. When do you think that's going to pick up and how much more visibility do you have in that one than you do maybe in some of the others.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: As I said the piece parts have picked up. We see a good trend there, and that's the vast majority of the aftermarket, but kind of the icing on the cake are the majors and as we progress in the year, you know, we'll update our forecast, but so far we are r
componenttext: As I said the piece parts have picked up. We see a good trend there, and that's the vast majority of the aftermarket, but kind of the icing on the cake are the majors and as we progress in the year, you know, we'll update our forecast, but so far we are right on track to hit the forecast that we had in our EPS range, and that I think is more of a function of the number of aircraft flying, when those increase then the need for majors will increase. We've seen you know, a reasonable order rate that gives us confidence that we will hit our forecast for the year. We just have to see how quickly activity picks up in the rest of the year to determine whether or not that could go higher.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just to clarify from an earlier question, in terms of the sequential growth, Marshall you mentioned, or actually Scott you mentioned 4% to 5% sequentially this year is your guidance from, obviously from a very low base, and that's reasonable. So
componenttext: Okay, and just to clarify from an earlier question, in terms of the sequential growth, Marshall you mentioned, or actually Scott you mentioned 4% to 5% sequentially this year is your guidance from, obviously from a very low base, and that's reasonable. Is that what you're guiding or you're looking, are you saying that the year-on-year growth rates are going to pick up?

componenttext: I think what I gave was year-on-year growth rates, you know, picking up. You know, when we're talking about 4 to 7 this year we would expect ’11 to be substantially better than that.

componenttext: Right, okay.

componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones. Obviously, Boeing had this discussion of considering two different rate increases on the 73 and you know, I assume that means we're looking at both 34 and something higher than that. What is your confidence in your ability to ramp to some of those rates, especially on some of the longer lead stuff like landing gear? How are you thinking about it, have you talked with Boeing about it you know, can you just give us some color there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You know, they’ve given us a lot of lead time on the 777. So that's not a problem with our long lead item forgings for landing gear. And it doesn’t - we don't have that long a lead time on the 777 gear component. So I don't think we’ll have any trou
componenttext: You know, they’ve given us a lot of lead time on the 777. So that's not a problem with our long lead item forgings for landing gear. And it doesn’t - we don't have that long a lead time on the 777 gear component. So I don't think we’ll have any trouble ramping up if they make the decision to raise the rate.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and a couple of others. Just to clarify here, you made the comment around the coding activity for some of the aftermarket stuff. Were you saying - the activity itself was up or the nature of the activity had an expedited kind of feel to it that was
componenttext: Okay, and a couple of others. Just to clarify here, you made the comment around the coding activity for some of the aftermarket stuff. Were you saying - the activity itself was up or the nature of the activity had an expedited kind of feel to it that was faster in a sort of pulling demand forward. Could you clarify that for me really quickly?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: It was both. We keep these statistics in our customer service organization as services, you know, almost every one of our original equipment businesses for parts of the aftermarket, and what we were seeing during the downturn in ‘09 in particular was th
componenttext: It was both. We keep these statistics in our customer service organization as services, you know, almost every one of our original equipment businesses for parts of the aftermarket, and what we were seeing during the downturn in ‘09 in particular was that we would get less code activity, and what we did get, they would send it in and then they would not authorize the repair until the last minute when they had to have it. What we're seeing now is greater code activity in a shorter time between the time it arrives in our MRO facility and when the airline wants it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And lastly, have you settled all of your various outstanding claims for nonrecurring cost and delays and whatnot with Boeing on the 787?
componenttext: Okay, great. And lastly, have you settled all of your various outstanding claims for nonrecurring cost and delays and whatnot with Boeing on the 787?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We are still in the process of working with Boeing, and I think both sides are working very well together.
componenttext: We are still in the process of working with Boeing, and I think both sides are working very well together.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks guys.
componenttext: Okay, thanks guys.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We’ll go to our next question from Howard Rubel from Jefferies & Co.
componenttext: We’ll go to our next question from Howard Rubel from Jefferies & Co.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Two things, Marshall, first could you talk a little bit about some productivity measures, and maybe either give it to us in terms of you know, some of the metrics that you might consider you know, important from an operational point o
componenttext: Thank you very much. Two things, Marshall, first could you talk a little bit about some productivity measures, and maybe either give it to us in terms of you know, some of the metrics that you might consider you know, important from an operational point of view whether it's you know, turn - your revenues per employee or some factory utilization measures that you might use and I have a follow-up.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I haven't looked at the revenue per employee lately, but I know it's going up because we reduced our employment base by about 1000 people out of 25,000, and we've been able to keep flat our sales, but we look more at on-time delivery and quality measures
componenttext: I haven't looked at the revenue per employee lately, but I know it's going up because we reduced our employment base by about 1000 people out of 25,000, and we've been able to keep flat our sales, but we look more at on-time delivery and quality measures as well as what we are doing in terms of the Toyota production system on continuous improvements. So they are very internally driven metrics that result in better financial metrics, and a lot of the cost downturn that we have been able to achieve in the last year has been through the continuous improvement process. So, I don't see all that cost coming back because we are figuring out ways to better run the business without it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on cash, two things, in terms of deployment, one is you talked about the funding of the pension plan, and the second I noticed you bought back about $42 million worth of stock in the quarter, a little bit, with a run rate that is probably a recor
componenttext: And then on cash, two things, in terms of deployment, one is you talked about the funding of the pension plan, and the second I noticed you bought back about $42 million worth of stock in the quarter, a little bit, with a run rate that is probably a record for you, but first how funded is the pension plan and what were your plans in terms of share repurchase. I know, you hinted you might do some.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I would just say, I talk about the share repurchase just for a moment and let Scott go through the [inaudible] share repurchase, but basically what we're doing is just trying to combat the dilution that happens because of incentive compensation equity sys
componenttext: I would just say, I talk about the share repurchase just for a moment and let Scott go through the [inaudible] share repurchase, but basically what we're doing is just trying to combat the dilution that happens because of incentive compensation equity systems. So there hasn't been a change in our policy so far.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Howard, what we typically see is a lot of activity in the first quarter when we are issuing you know, restricted stock units and you know, the conversions of options and things like that. So that activity was higher in the first quarter. So we elimin
componenttext:
Yes, Howard, what we typically see is a lot of activity in the first quarter when we are issuing you know, restricted stock units and you know, the conversions of options and things like that. So that activity was higher in the first quarter. So we eliminated that dilution effect by being more active on the repurchase side. That said, that doesn't signal anything more than that.
On the pension side, we put our entire planned US pension contribution for 2010 into the plan in the first quarter. We had, you know, cash available to do that and we thought that given the recovery in the economy that it was timing to our advantage to put it in earlier rather than later in the year. So that's why we did that. From a pension standpoint, we've got $105 million already funded and there is probably another $35 million or so to go during the balance of the year to hit our plans for funding in 2010. So, right on track with that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: What I meant is your percentage of funding now, where are you in there? Thank you.
componenttext: What I meant is your percentage of funding now, where are you in there? Thank you.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are about 83% funded on the US plans on an ABO basis, and that's assuming a discount rate of 5.81% which is a little bit lower than where we ended the year.
componenttext: Yes, we are about 83% funded on the US plans on an ABO basis, and that's assuming a discount rate of 5.81% which is a little bit lower than where we ended the year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you gentlemen. Thank you very much.
componenttext: Thank you gentlemen. Thank you very much.

componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

componenttext: All right. I'll ask another question. Maybe make it briefer. If Airbus does A320GTF, can you talk to us about how you are thinking about the potential for accelerated retirements. Did that impede any of the expected aftermarket volumes that you're looking for downstream?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: I'm going to restate that, you tell me if I got it right.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: Okay.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You're talking about if Airbus re-engines the A320, basically the effect on us. I know you had a follow-on question there we just couldn't hear.
componenttext: You're talking about if Airbus re-engines the A320, basically the effect on us. I know you had a follow-on question there we just couldn't hear.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Would that cause an acceleration in the retirement which would then maybe impede the expected aftermarket volumes down?
componenttext: Would that cause an acceleration in the retirement which would then maybe impede the expected aftermarket volumes down?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we don't really think that it will cause an acceleration in retirements. You're going to have close to 6000 of those A320s in the fleet by the end of 2015, and aftermarket would continue to grow because they're still very efficient aircraft, especiall
componenttext: No, we don't really think that it will cause an acceleration in retirements. You're going to have close to 6000 of those A320s in the fleet by the end of 2015, and aftermarket would continue to grow because they're still very efficient aircraft, especially on the short haul side, and we think just like when the 737 MG came in they kept making the classic for several years. There will be an overlap in it. They may - I don't know if they'll have to discount but I'm sure there'll be some differentiation there, but we see a continuation of the current aircraft for several years as they phase in the production of the new aircraft if they make this decision, and we're prepared if we need to and to win business on the new one and continue to be able to deliver on the old one.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great, and you don't have the sales on the current 737, but many of us when we look at the options that Boeing has in addition to GTF, I think they are seriously looking at doing a clean sheet of paper 737 replacement. Can you give us a sense Marsha
componenttext: Okay, great, and you don't have the sales on the current 737, but many of us when we look at the options that Boeing has in addition to GTF, I think they are seriously looking at doing a clean sheet of paper 737 replacement. Can you give us a sense Marshall as to kind of how do we think about the bandwidth of potential R&D for you going forward if that were to be announced?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think if there was a brand-new airplane announced instead of a re-engining for Boeing, we would be right in there bidding on all of the major systems that we have and we certainly have the technical and financial resources to do it.
componenttext: I think if there was a brand-new airplane announced instead of a re-engining for Boeing, we would be right in there bidding on all of the major systems that we have and we certainly have the technical and financial resources to do it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: All right, great. Thanks very much.
componenttext: All right, great. Thanks very much.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You are welcome.
componenttext: You are welcome.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: We’ll go to David Strauss from UBS.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning.
componenttext: Good morning.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning Sam.
componenttext: Good morning Sam.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi David.
componenttext: Hi David.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, it is David.
componenttext: Oh, it is David.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, can you give us some color on the contract adjustments that you took, most of them were in the sales business. Can you just give us some color there and also talk about what you're expecting in terms of the full-year from positive contract adjustme
componenttext: Scott, can you give us some color on the contract adjustments that you took, most of them were in the sales business. Can you just give us some color there and also talk about what you're expecting in terms of the full-year from positive contract adjustments?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The contract adjustments were pretty favorable not only in the sales, but they were also favorable in our wheels and brakes business, although they were negative as I mentioned earlier in electronic systems. So the total for the first quarter was about $1
componenttext:
The contract adjustments were pretty favorable not only in the sales, but they were also favorable in our wheels and brakes business, although they were negative as I mentioned earlier in electronic systems. So the total for the first quarter was about $16 million positive, which compared favorably to the year ago period, up about $12 million. You know, we had guided I think last year's total was about $45 million and our expectation is that they would be positive in 2010 but less than last year of 45, and we're still tracking you know pretty well with that.
The nature of the contract adjustments is similar to what we've seen before, you know, when contracts roll over and they are repriced, we get a benefit there as some contracts that are shorter cycle add volume or they get extended you know, three months at a time, et cetera we add volume to those units. That’s a help and we continue to work the cost side you know, very diligently within our aerostructures business in particular. So they continue to drive you know, overheads down, drive you know, production costs down, you know, continue to move products where we can to low-cost countries and low-cost suppliers. So we continue to get benefit there as well.
And on the wheels and brakes side, you know, it has been a longer-term story that continues which is the quality of the brake material and the life that we get on that material has continued to be better than expected and we are seeing benefits there.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up on 787, can you tell us where you are in terms of how many ships that you produced at this point. When you start to benefit from a ramp up in production there, and then also does your 4% to 7% aftermarket growth number this year, does that
componenttext: As a follow-up on 787, can you tell us where you are in terms of how many ships that you produced at this point. When you start to benefit from a ramp up in production there, and then also does your 4% to 7% aftermarket growth number this year, does that include anything for initial spares provisioning on the 787?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does include some initial provisioning related to spares for the 787 introduction. It's not a huge part of that component, but there is some that we expect towards the end of the year as that airplane enters service. You know, in terms of where we
componenttext: Yes, it does include some initial provisioning related to spares for the 787 introduction. It's not a huge part of that component, but there is some that we expect towards the end of the year as that airplane enters service. You know, in terms of where we are at on the production side, I think we are producing today close to the two per month level that you know, Boeing has talked about externally. In terms of where we are at in shipsets I think we’re in 15 to 20 range, but I haven't heard, maybe a little higher than that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Real answer is that we’re keeping up with what Boeing is asking us to do, so that we are prepared to hit you know, the manufacturing production drumbeat, you know, when it really ramps up.
componenttext: Real answer is that we’re keeping up with what Boeing is asking us to do, so that we are prepared to hit you know, the manufacturing production drumbeat, you know, when it really ramps up.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And so you're actually delivering those today Marshal, and the negative, you know, the negative margin impact of 787 is actually flowing through your numbers today?
componenttext: And so you're actually delivering those today Marshal, and the negative, you know, the negative margin impact of 787 is actually flowing through your numbers today?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: It goes through on the non-product inventory, but it doesn't flow through in terms of sales, because the sales haven't been booked yet because they don't go to the final customer in the form of an airplane for flight test programs…
componenttext: It goes through on the non-product inventory, but it doesn't flow through in terms of sales, because the sales haven't been booked yet because they don't go to the final customer in the form of an airplane for flight test programs…

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Like on wheels and brakes, I mean, those are going in there at you know, typical margin on those.
componenttext: Like on wheels and brakes, I mean, those are going in there at you know, typical margin on those.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We’ll now go to our next question from Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: We’ll now go to our next question from Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning.
componenttext: Hi, good morning.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi Sam.
componenttext: Hi Sam.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you guys talk a little bit about as we go forward with the aftermarket going through the year, I'm trying to just think through it, you know, I'm surprised that you would see the inventories ex- the preproduction and access over average but that's not
componenttext: Can you guys talk a little bit about as we go forward with the aftermarket going through the year, I'm trying to just think through it, you know, I'm surprised that you would see the inventories ex- the preproduction and access over average but that's not really growing yet. Wouldn't you be building inventories in anticipation of the airline starting to take more product and so from a cash perspective in inventories, how does that play out through the year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sam that will build during the rest of the year. You know, some of it will be in the form of our you know, preproduction excess over average or what we call our nonproduct inventory. That grew by about $50 million in total, not just 787 but across all pla
componenttext: Sam that will build during the rest of the year. You know, some of it will be in the form of our you know, preproduction excess over average or what we call our nonproduct inventory. That grew by about $50 million in total, not just 787 but across all platforms in the first quarter, and that will grow at a faster pace as we get towards the back end of the year. You know, we've got I think close to around $200 million of production inventory you know, already on the books to support 787. So, you know, there will be some further ramp up as we go through the year, but we've got a lot of inventory already in place to support ramp up in production.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: But in terms of the aftermarket itself, would you be booking, and I guess shipping in the same quarter or would we see a growth on the aftermarket pieces ahead of the delivery?
componenttext: But in terms of the aftermarket itself, would you be booking, and I guess shipping in the same quarter or would we see a growth on the aftermarket pieces ahead of the delivery?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sam, we don't get very long visibility on orders in the aftermarket for in-production aircraft, so like on an A320 or 737NG. We - lot of times will get the order and ship it in the same month, and what we try to do is be very efficient about the inventory
componenttext: Sam, we don't get very long visibility on orders in the aftermarket for in-production aircraft, so like on an A320 or 737NG. We - lot of times will get the order and ship it in the same month, and what we try to do is be very efficient about the inventory because of its in-production. Lot of times we can put it right off the OE line and service the airline as opposed to have already put it in the inventory. So we don’t - I don't anticipate a big buildup in inventory for the aftermarket this year, the buildup that Paul - that Scott was talking about was on 787 and that's typical on our contract accounting.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then separately just on the taxes and the R&D tax credit, should we see a still fairly, I guess high tax rate in Q2 and Q3, and then a step down in Q4 assuming the timing of when that credit gets renewed?
componenttext: Okay, and then separately just on the taxes and the R&D tax credit, should we see a still fairly, I guess high tax rate in Q2 and Q3, and then a step down in Q4 assuming the timing of when that credit gets renewed?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, you hit one of the key factors which is when does it get renewed. If it gets renewed in the second quarter, retroactive to the first of the year then we will have a catch-up benefit in Q2, and a lower rate, normal rate going forward in the ne
componenttext:
Yes, I mean, you hit one of the key factors which is when does it get renewed. If it gets renewed in the second quarter, retroactive to the first of the year then we will have a catch-up benefit in Q2, and a lower rate, normal rate going forward in the next two quarters. If it doesn't get passed until the end of the year, then you are catching up for the full year.
We also have some one-time adjustments that we expect as we settle various disputes and cases with the IRS, here as well as outside the US. If those cases settle during the year they create some lumps in terms of the timing and the tax rate in any particular quarter. What we have guided to is a 31% rate roughly for the full year, which implies on average about 29% for each of the next three quarters. But no one of those quarters is going to be exactly at that number. It is going to be just depending on the timing of those settlements and the extension of the R&D credit.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you quantify just in order of magnitude of how big those settlements are?
componenttext: Okay. Can you quantify just in order of magnitude of how big those settlements are?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the R&D piece, I think it is about $0.08 a share for the full year. So it can come all at once or it can come in phases. The other settlements, I can't give you specific numbers on that, but it basically bridges the difference between your normal ra
componenttext: Well, the R&D piece, I think it is about $0.08 a share for the full year. So it can come all at once or it can come in phases. The other settlements, I can't give you specific numbers on that, but it basically bridges the difference between your normal rate and the effective rate that we published.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thanks a lot.
componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks a lot.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: We will go next to Ken Herbert with Wedbush.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hi, good morning.
componenttext: Yes. Hi, good morning.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning.
componenttext: Good morning.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to see if you can provide some more detail on the defense business. It looked like obviously another good quarter for the first quarter, specifically for the aftermarket and the OE side, and anything you are seeing moving forward through the
componenttext: I just wanted to see if you can provide some more detail on the defense business. It looked like obviously another good quarter for the first quarter, specifically for the aftermarket and the OE side, and anything you are seeing moving forward through the year that might change within the mix within that business as you look to your up 15% for the year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Remember that 15% is divided about 8 points of that is the acquisition at the end of last year of Atlantic Inertial Systems. 5% was organic on the rest of our businesses, and this is right in line with the expectations, particularly in our sensors and int
componenttext: Remember that 15% is divided about 8 points of that is the acquisition at the end of last year of Atlantic Inertial Systems. 5% was organic on the rest of our businesses, and this is right in line with the expectations, particularly in our sensors and integrated systems business and our intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance businesses that are kind of playing more in the sweet spots of the defense budget. So right now we're right in line with our 5% for the first quarter organically. We expected 5% organic for the year, plus the Atlantic Inertial Systems. So right on track.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And when you look at the mix then for the organic growth say aftermarket, there was nothing in terms of the aftermarket or the OE shift that particularly stood out in the quarter?
componenttext: And when you look at the mix then for the organic growth say aftermarket, there was nothing in terms of the aftermarket or the OE shift that particularly stood out in the quarter?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: No, not at all, just business as usual.
componenttext: No, not at all, just business as usual.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one quick other question, as you look to follow on to some of the previous questions, when should we start to see then working capital start to work down or what is your timeframe for that through the rest of the year and into 2011.
componenttext: Okay. And then just one quick other question, as you look to follow on to some of the previous questions, when should we start to see then working capital start to work down or what is your timeframe for that through the rest of the year and into 2011.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it is going to depend on the market here. As OE rates increase, there will be a requirement for more working capital and as the aftermarket starts to go we will go - we try to keep that as low as we can in service production line, but if it
componenttext: Well, I think it is going to depend on the market here. As OE rates increase, there will be a requirement for more working capital and as the aftermarket starts to go we will go - we try to keep that as low as we can in service production line, but if it really does take off, we might have to lay in a little bit more, but it will more than pay for itself.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, excellent. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay, excellent. Thank you.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We will go next to Eric Hugel from Stevens.
componenttext: We will go next to Eric Hugel from Stevens.

componenttext: Good morning Eric.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Want to talk about the actuation and landing systems business, the margins if you look sequentially have improved nicely. I just wanted to sort of talk about the drivers. I'm assuming that two of those three businesses that you talked about seeing improve
componenttext: Want to talk about the actuation and landing systems business, the margins if you look sequentially have improved nicely. I just wanted to sort of talk about the drivers. I'm assuming that two of those three businesses that you talked about seeing improvement actuation and the wheels and brakes business, is that really the key driver here. And looking forward should that translate into further margin expansion here or is there some other trends that we should take into consideration?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean if you look sequentially in actuation landing systems, we got about seven tenths improvement in margins from the fourth quarter, and there were up a bit from where we were in Q2 and Q3 of last year.
componenttext: I mean if you look sequentially in actuation landing systems, we got about seven tenths improvement in margins from the fourth quarter, and there were up a bit from where we were in Q2 and Q3 of last year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And aftermarket is a good driver of the sequential improvement, and we were up about $25 million or 13% in aftermarket sales in the quarter. So that clearly helped. That business is kind of average in terms of aftermarket mix to total sales. It doesn't ha
componenttext:
And aftermarket is a good driver of the sequential improvement, and we were up about $25 million or 13% in aftermarket sales in the quarter. So that clearly helped. That business is kind of average in terms of aftermarket mix to total sales. It doesn't have quite as much aftermarket exposure, content as the sales in interior. So some other businesses may benefit just as much or more from the aftermarket recovery, but they will clearly be a participant.
You know that business - we’ve kind of said 10% or 11% margins in that business is where we expected it to be, and as we continue to drive cost efficiency, make investments in new product into lower cost countries, make a move those margins up over time. But it is a slower process in that business because it is a little bit more capital intensive business.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Is this going to be one of the business that are going to be impacted by sort of more than as sort of OEM production ramps up?
componenttext: Is this going to be one of the business that are going to be impacted by sort of more than as sort of OEM production ramps up?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly, as the rates ramp up particularly with Boeing, where we get more gear sales, it helps on the overall spreading of absorption in that very capital intensive landing gear business. For Airbus we don't have gear except on the A380. So it is not go
componenttext: Certainly, as the rates ramp up particularly with Boeing, where we get more gear sales, it helps on the overall spreading of absorption in that very capital intensive landing gear business. For Airbus we don't have gear except on the A380. So it is not going to affect it as much there, but wheels and brakes services both 737 and A320. So they will get more free of charge, but they are also going to have greater aftermarket to make up for that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And Marshall bit of a vague question, but maybe you can take a slight bet, if you look at all the cost that you have taken out of the business let us say over the downturn, can you sort of bucket how much of that is sort of structural, not coming back ver
componenttext: And Marshall bit of a vague question, but maybe you can take a slight bet, if you look at all the cost that you have taken out of the business let us say over the downturn, can you sort of bucket how much of that is sort of structural, not coming back versus volume related?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I got to think a good portion of it, over half of it is structural. I mean we have done restructuring. We have taken out a plant in Arizona, moved to Mexico. We keep moving more product to low-cost country. We are really driving continuous improveme
componenttext:
Well, I got to think a good portion of it, over half of it is structural. I mean we have done restructuring. We have taken out a plant in Arizona, moved to Mexico. We keep moving more product to low-cost country. We are really driving continuous improvement in our factories worldwide. We certainly have had a fair amount of indirect cost come out and we were - like everyone else our travel was reduced and our travel and entertainment expenses. But some of that will have to comeback as you got to go see your customer.
But a lot of the other stuff isn’t coming back, and that is the idea on the continuous improvement. We want to keep getting more and more efficient. I think one of the reasons that we didn't have the same reduction in force on this recession, with only 1000 people out of 25,000 as opposed to 5000 after 9/11, when SARS and the Iraqi war hit back in 2003. It is because we have gotten much, much more efficient and we just haven't hired people as rapidly as in the past, because we are able to do more with less.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks a lot guys.
componenttext: Great. Thanks a lot guys.

componenttext: Marshall, I want to follow up on what you were just discussing with how different the business is as we enter the next cycle from a profitability perspective. I think I heard you say in your prepared remarks that you are sort of thinking the margin of the company is going to be higher in any given point of the next cycle versus prior cycle. I think at your investor conference when you gave us the 10 billion revenue number you were a little reluctant to talk about the longer-term margin forecast. Is something different or have you just kind of thought about it more and I my hearing you correctly about the longer-term margins?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think one thing I did say whether it was at that conference or in past calls is that we had margins up to 17% plus in the peak of the cycle in ’08. I don’t see a reason why we can't get back there. I think we may even be able to exceed it at s
componenttext: Well, I think one thing I did say whether it was at that conference or in past calls is that we had margins up to 17% plus in the peak of the cycle in ’08. I don’t see a reason why we can't get back there. I think we may even be able to exceed it at some point in time. But it is going to be a slog. We have got to keep driving costs out of the business, because you don't get to keep everything you gain here. We got customers that expect certain pricing and we have to work with them on it, but you know I think we can get past that peak at some point in time. I can predict exactly when, but I think directionally that is where we are going.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich First Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to your Vice President of Investor Relations, M
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich First Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to your Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Paul Gifford. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our first quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks followed by Q
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our first quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks followed by Q&A. A presentation is available at our Web site www.goodrich.com, which together with our press release, provides the basis for most of our remarks.
Before we start, let me remind you that today's remarks include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. These actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. They are also detailed in today's earnings press release. I urge you to read them carefully. This conference call is being webcast and replays will be available at our Internet site beginning this afternoon. 
Once again, we ask that callers limit themselves to one question each so that we can have time to allow all of you to ask your questions. If you have further unanswered questions, you can get back into the queue and ask another question, time permitting. Now I'll turn the call over to Marshall, who will provide you with an overview of our first quarter 2010 results and our updated full year outlook for 2010.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul, and good morning, everyone. I assume you've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings press release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of these documents that you will find helpful as you think about
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul, and good morning, everyone. I assume you've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings press release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of these documents that you will find helpful as you think about Goodrich. So rather than spend all of my prepared remarks on the information already contained in the press release, today, I'll only spend a few minutes on our first quarter results and our outlook for 2010. Then I'll focus on trends and indicators of what we are seeing in our markets right now, and what we think those trends mean for Goodrich. Let's start with a quick overview of our first quarter results and our outlook for the year.
Our first quarter results were consistent with our expectations. Earnings per share of $0.87 were solidly operational and were impacted by tax expense approximately up $0.12 per share higher than our prior outlook for the full year tax rate. Specifically, we incurred additional tax expense of $0.08 in the quarter related to the passage of the healthcare reform legislation and additional expense of $0.02 per share related to delays in extending the R&D tax credit.
Our first quarter 2010 sales were nearly the same as our first quarter 2009 sales. Large commercial airplane original equipment market channel experienced a sales increase of 12%, which was mostly attributable to the impact of the Boeing strike on quarter one 2009 sales. Our Regional business and general aviation original equipment sales decreased by about 31% compared to the first quarter of 2009.  Sales in this market channel declined abruptly in the first three quarters of 2009, stabilized in the fourth quarter and we experienced sequential growth in quarter one of 2010. 
Sales in our Commercial AfterMarket channel decreased 10% in the first quarter of 2010 compared to the first quarter of 2009. However, three of our eight commercial businesses reported higher aftermarket sales in the first quarter of 2010, compared to the first quarter of 2009. Sequentially, commercial aftermarket sales were 9% higher in the first quarter 2010 than during the fourth 2009 with seven of our eight commercial businesses reporting higher -- aftermarket -- sales in Q1 2010 than Q4 2009.
Our defense and space sales exhibit strong growth in the first quarter of 2010, increasing by 13% compared to the first quarter of 2009. Our acquisition of AIS contributed 8% of this growth and organic sales about 5%, driven primarily by strong sales in our Sensors and Integrated Systems business and our Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance business.
The first quarter 2010, we achieved segment operating income margins of 15.3%, compared to 17.2% in the first quarter of 2009. Sequentially, segment operating income margins were more than 1% higher than the fourth quarter of 2009. The sequential improvement was due to higher aftermarket sales and continuing emphasis on cost containment. Net cash provided by operating activities, minus capital expenditures for the first quarter 2010 was $9 million. During the first quarter 2010, we contributed $105 million to our worldwide pension plans, compared to contributions of $8 million in the first quarter of 2009. Excluding the first quarter 2010 pension contribution, net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures was more than 100% of net income. 
Now let's shift to our full year outlook for 2010.  Our full year 2010 outlook for sales remains at approximately $7.1 billion and represents growth of about 6% compared to 2009. The outlook for 2010 net income per diluted share remains in a range of $4.15 to $4.40 a share, even though we now expect a higher effective tax rate for the year.
We continue to expect large commercial airplane original equipment sales to increase by about 5%, assuming that 787 deliveries begin in late 2010. We expect Regional business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales to decrease by more than 10%, reflecting flat performance versus the second half of 2009. We have not changed our expectations for large commercial regional business and general aviation aftermarket sales growth of about 4% to 7%, assuming that worldwide available seat miles, ASMs, increase in the range of 1% to 3% in 2010.
