headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich First Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to your Vice President of Investor Relations, M
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich First Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to your Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Paul Gifford. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our first quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks followed by Q
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our first quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks followed by Q&A. A presentation is available at our Web site www.goodrich.com, which together with our press release, provides the basis for most of our remarks.
Before we start, let me remind you that today's remarks include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. These actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. They are also detailed in today's earnings press release. I urge you to read them carefully. This conference call is being webcast and replays will be available at our Internet site beginning this afternoon. 
Once again, we ask that callers limit themselves to one question each so that we can have time to allow all of you to ask your questions. If you have further unanswered questions, you can get back into the queue and ask another question, time permitting. Now I'll turn the call over to Marshall, who will provide you with an overview of our first quarter 2010 results and our updated full year outlook for 2010.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul, and good morning, everyone. I assume you've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings press release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of these documents that you will find helpful as you think about
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul, and good morning, everyone. I assume you've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings press release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of these documents that you will find helpful as you think about Goodrich. So rather than spend all of my prepared remarks on the information already contained in the press release, today, I'll only spend a few minutes on our first quarter results and our outlook for 2010. Then I'll focus on trends and indicators of what we are seeing in our markets right now, and what we think those trends mean for Goodrich. Let's start with a quick overview of our first quarter results and our outlook for the year.
Our first quarter results were consistent with our expectations. Earnings per share of $0.87 were solidly operational and were impacted by tax expense approximately up $0.12 per share higher than our prior outlook for the full year tax rate. Specifically, we incurred additional tax expense of $0.08 in the quarter related to the passage of the healthcare reform legislation and additional expense of $0.02 per share related to delays in extending the R&D tax credit.
Our first quarter 2010 sales were nearly the same as our first quarter 2009 sales. Large commercial airplane original equipment market channel experienced a sales increase of 12%, which was mostly attributable to the impact of the Boeing strike on quarter one 2009 sales. Our Regional business and general aviation original equipment sales decreased by about 31% compared to the first quarter of 2009. Sales in this market channel declined abruptly in the first three quarters of 2009, stabilized in the fourth quarter and we experienced sequential growth in quarter one of 2010. 
Sales in our Commercial Aftermarket channel decreased 10% in the first quarter of 2010 compared to the first quarter of 2009. However, three of our eight commercial businesses reported higher aftermarket sales in the first quarter of 2010, compared to the first quarter of 2009. Sequentially, commercial aftermarket sales were 9% higher in the first quarter 2010 than during the fourth 2009 with seven of our eight commercial businesses reporting higher -- aftermarket -- sales in Q1 2010 than Q4 2009.
Our defense and space sales exhibit strong growth in the first quarter of 2010, increasing by 13% compared to the first quarter of 2009. Our acquisition of AIS contributed 8% of this growth and organic sales about 5%, driven primarily by strong sales in our Sensors and Integrated Systems business and our Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance business.
The first quarter 2010, we achieved segment operating income margins of 15.3% compared to 17.2% in the first quarter of 2009. Sequentially, segment operating income margins were more than 1% higher than the fourth quarter of 2009. The sequential improvement was due to higher aftermarket sales and continuing emphasis on cost containment. Net cash provided by operating activities, minus capital expenditures for the first quarter 2010 was $9 million. During the first quarter 2010, we contributed $105 million to our worldwide pension plans compared to contributions of $8 million in the first quarter of 2009. Excluding the first quarter 2010 pension contribution, net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures was more than 100% of net income. 
Now let's shift to our full year outlook for 2010. Our full year 2010 outlook for sales remains at approximately $7.1 billion and represents growth of about 6% compared to 2009. The outlook for 2010 net income per diluted share remains in a range of $4.15 to $4.40 a share, even though we now expect a higher effective tax rate for the year.
We continue to expect large commercial airplane original equipment sales to increase by about 5%, assuming that 787 deliveries begin in late 2010. We expect Regional business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales to decrease by more than 10%, reflecting flat performance versus the second half of 2009. We have not changed our expectations for large commercial regional business and general aviation aftermarket sales growth of about 4% to 7%, assuming that worldwide available seat miles, ASMs, increase in the range of 1% to 3% in 2010. We continue to expect sequentially higher aftermarket sales each quarter as we progress through the year but don't expect sales to be higher than the year-ago quarter until the second half. Finally, our outlook for defense and space sales growth is unchanged at about 15%, including sales generated by the AIS acquisition.
2010 outlook for earnings per diluted share includes a full year effective tax rate of about 31% for 2010, an increase from our prior outlook of 29% to 30%. Our tax rate outlook continues to include a full year benefit of approximately 1.5% related to an assumed extension of the U.S. R&D tax credit retroactive to the beginning of the year. For 2010, we expect net cash provided by operating activities, minus capital expenditures to exceed 85% of net income. We continue to expect capital expenditures for 2010 to be in a range of $250 million to $275 million and expect worldwide pension contributions to be $100 million to $150 million. Approximately $105 million has been funded year to date.
Now I'll spend a few minutes on current activity and trends in our primary market channels. Large commercial OE production outlook has improved significantly over the last three months. Airbus announced that it is increasing A320 production rate about 6% to 36 per month later this year. And Boeing has announced that it will increase 777 production from five per month to seven per month in the middle of next year and that it will accelerate its 747-8 rate increase to two per month from 2013 moving forward to 2012. 
For the commercial aftermarket, some of the macro indicators are showing improvements. Our sequential sales improvement from the fourth quarter 2009 was the first sequential improvement since the third quarter of 2008, and we continue to believe that each quarter this year will show sequential improvements over the previous quarter. We expect strong commercial aftermarket growth beyond 2010. Over the last two years, the active fleet of commercial aircraft has grown by about 6%. As the fleet continues to grow and airline maintenance practices return to more normal levels, we should see very good growth rates, driven by both catch-up demand and normal aging.
Passenger airline and freight trends continue to improve. Airline load factors remain at high levels especially in the U.S., and RPM data continues to show positive trends. Within our businesses, we're also seeing some positive developments that indicate recovery in the aftermarket is underway. During the first quarter, our Wheel and Brake business saw a pickup in activity on 747 and A330 airplanes, an indicator of good international and freight traffic trends. In our Aero Structures business, piece part sales trends continued to be favorable. Major part sales in the first quarter were consistent with our expectations for the year. 
Order intake and quote activity in most of our MRO shops is also improving. We are also seeing favorable quote aging trends indicating that airlines are making decisions to order parts repairs faster then they were last year. Market for our defense and space products remains strong. Our first quarter defense and space sales growth of 13% included 5% organic growth and was in line with our expectations.
Overall, our performance during the first quarter was in line with our expectations, and the quarter was a good step towards this being a year in which we return to growth trends in most of our markets. We've been able to maintain strong margins despite our loss of aftermarket sales through a continued focus on cost control and operational excellence. Our longer-term prospects for sustainable growth are also excellent, fueled by our significant market share gains on new commercial and military aircraft currently in development. As I noted in our investor conference last year, I believe that Goodrich can grow to a company with more than $10 billion in sales and higher segment operating income margins by 2014.
Our financial position remains excellent with almost $800 million of cash on our balance sheet and significant cash flow generation expectations for 2010. This has allowed us to continue to seek acquisition opportunities that would further enhance our growth rates and cash generation and drive shareholder value. I look forward to talking to all of you through 2010 as we continue to tell the Goodrich story. And now we'll open up for questions.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll now go to our first question from the line of Troy Lahr from Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll now go to our first question from the line of Troy Lahr from Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you guys could just talk maybe a little bit how aftermarket gets to 4% to 7% for the year, coming off of a down 10%. And it looks like there's going to be a really big pick up there. Is that -- do you think that that's aircraft coming out of t
componenttext: I wonder if you guys could just talk maybe a little bit how aftermarket gets to 4% to 7% for the year, coming off of a down 10%. And it looks like there's going to be a really big pick up there. Is that -- do you think that that's aircraft coming out of the desert? And then there's going to be spare parts? Or do you think airlines are just globally are adding that much more capacity in the back half of the year? Can you maybe just kind of walk through your assumptions there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I can give you the assumptions and between Marshall and I, we can give you a little bit more color on what's developing in the aftermarket. In terms of assumptions, we did see the 9% growth from the fourth quarter of 2009. So that sets us on a real solid
componenttext: I can give you the assumptions and between Marshall and I, we can give you a little bit more color on what's developing in the aftermarket. In terms of assumptions, we did see the 9% growth from the fourth quarter of 2009. So that sets us on a real solid growth trend sequentially. To get to the 4% to 7%, we need to average somewhere in the 4% to 5% sequential growth for each of the next three quarters to get into that range. And based on the trends that we've seen so far developing in the first quarter with respect to order backlog, the pace of orders, quote activity, things like that, as well is the breadth that we've seen across all of our commercially oriented businesses, we have pretty good confidence that, at least moving into Q2, we're on that same kind of a track. We don't have a lot of visibility going out to Q3 and four, but if you look at the kind of macro trends the recovering schedules that the airlines have posted through the middle of the year, etcetera, it seems to be shaping up very consistent with those expectations.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, with Boeing and Airbus looking to re-engine A320s and 737s possibly, what opportunities do you have out there? Do you think you can take some market share gains? And is there a possibility Boeing could add two engines as an option an
componenttext: And then just lastly, with Boeing and Airbus looking to re-engine A320s and 737s possibly, what opportunities do you have out there? Do you think you can take some market share gains? And is there a possibility Boeing could add two engines as an option and then that could really help you out a lot?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you're going to have to talk to Boeing about what options they might do, but I think that on a Boeing re-engining, we don't have the sales on that. We do supply Spirit on parts of those nacelle's. We would expect to try to maintain that kind of a
componenttext: I think you're going to have to talk to Boeing about what options they might do, but I think that on a Boeing re-engining, we don't have the sales on that. We do supply Spirit on parts of those nacelle's. We would expect to try to maintain that kind of a relationship, especially if they turn this a derivative, and it's another single-engine procurement. If it's two-engine procurement, that opens up opportunities, more opportunities. As far as Airbus goes, we would intend to bid on that. We currently have the nacelles on both the B2500 and CFM56, and we think there will be a lot of aircraft even with the old model that will overlap for a while. And we think there will be probably at least 6,000 of those aircraft eventually flying made through 2015 and aftermarket long after that. So even if we worked on a new one, we're still going to get a lot of aftermarket, but we would expect to be on a new one if they decide to re-engine. And I don't think those decisions haven't been made, so a lot of this is pure speculation at this point. So that's about all I can tell you.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from the line of Doug Harned from Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from the line of Doug Harned from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You said that three of your eight businesses were seeing better aftermarket, were up in the aftermarket sales. Could you talk about the differences between the three? What the three are? And the difference between the ones that are improving and the ones
componenttext: You said that three of your eight businesses were seeing better aftermarket, were up in the aftermarket sales. Could you talk about the differences between the three? What the three are? And the difference between the ones that are improving and the ones that have not yet seen improvement?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of the businesses that saw improvement year-over-year, wheels and brakes saw improvement our Actuation Systems business did and our Sensors and Integrated Systems business also saw improvement year-over-year. At least the first two of those -- I
componenttext: A couple of the businesses that saw improvement year-over-year, wheels and brakes saw improvement our Actuation Systems business did and our Sensors and Integrated Systems business also saw improvement year-over-year. At least the first two of those -- I think there's a good tail wind from the secular trend of just aging aircraft where we have a lot of content. We've got the flight control actuation systems on the A320 aircraft, and as they continue to age, we just see good year-over-year growth in that particular business. The Wheel and Brake business is one of the earlier businesses to turn because it's got the shortest cycle from airline activity to aftermarket sales. So we think that's being driven by the upturn in aircraft activity, and actuation actually driven more by the longer-term trend of a lot of content on high-volume production airplanes that are aging and, therefore, driving a lot of additional aftermarket.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And if you think about wheels and brakes in particular, that's a total Aftermarket business. Because as you well know, we give away the wheels and brakes to the OE, so you don't get any sales credit on that side of it. So as activity picks up in the world
componenttext: And if you think about wheels and brakes in particular, that's a total Aftermarket business. Because as you well know, we give away the wheels and brakes to the OE, so you don't get any sales credit on that side of it. So as activity picks up in the worldwide fleet, you're going to see an increase in the wheel and brake activity.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: But if you go to the five that you did not see the growth in, how would you describe those? In other words, what's different there?
componenttext: But if you go to the five that you did not see the growth in, how would you describe those? In other words, what's different there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I would say first of all, it's a very hard comp from the first quarter of '09 because remember, when we got towards the end of '08, those were peak aftermarket sales for Goodrich. So some of them had tremendous sales during that first quarter also, a
componenttext: Well I would say first of all, it's a very hard comp from the first quarter of '09 because remember, when we got towards the end of '08, those were peak aftermarket sales for Goodrich. So some of them had tremendous sales during that first quarter also, and so it's just a harder comp. It doesn't mean -- as we said, almost every business unit had sequentially greater sales from the fourth quarter. So we're on the right trend. It's just a tough comp.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: There's nothing special about those businesses? In other words, different types of trends that you're seeing there?
componenttext: There's nothing special about those businesses? In other words, different types of trends that you're seeing there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: All of them are a little bit different because they have a little bit different percentage of their business in the aftermarket, but I think that's why I went back and talked about the wheel and brake given it's 100% aftermarket. It's a very good indicato
componenttext: All of them are a little bit different because they have a little bit different percentage of their business in the aftermarket, but I think that's why I went back and talked about the wheel and brake given it's 100% aftermarket. It's a very good indicator.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from the line of Robert Stallard from Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from the line of Robert Stallard from Macquarie.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Just want to follow on this aftermarket issue. If you were to strip out your price increase that you got at the start of the year, did you still see volumes moving up nicely on the sequential front and maybe year-over-year as well in these three businesse
componenttext: Just want to follow on this aftermarket issue. If you were to strip out your price increase that you got at the start of the year, did you still see volumes moving up nicely on the sequential front and maybe year-over-year as well in these three businesses?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: Yes, there was negligible price increase.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: So you're saying it would be like an inflation price increase, or maybe slightly better than that?
componenttext: So you're saying it would be like an inflation price increase, or maybe slightly better than that?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm saying that it was negligible, nominally.
componenttext: I'm saying that it was negligible, nominally.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Is that unusual? Because normally, you get a reasonable price increase year-on-year?
componenttext: Is that unusual? Because normally, you get a reasonable price increase year-on-year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We've been trying to work with airlines and make sure that we're very competitive, and we're seeing the volume come back and we're very pleased with that.
componenttext: We've been trying to work with airlines and make sure that we're very competitive, and we're seeing the volume come back and we're very pleased with that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And just to follow up on Troy's question about the sequential trend you expect to see, this would mean that you would end this year with a pretty healthy aftermarket growth rate. Do you expect that trend to continue into 2011?
componenttext: And just to follow up on Troy's question about the sequential trend you expect to see, this would mean that you would end this year with a pretty healthy aftermarket growth rate. Do you expect that trend to continue into 2011?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I would expect the trend to be even better in 2011 from the standpoint of a further amount of economic recovery worldwide. I think we'll have a greater amount of activity, airline activity in 2011 than we have in 2010.
componenttext: I would expect the trend to be even better in 2011 from the standpoint of a further amount of economic recovery worldwide. I think we'll have a greater amount of activity, airline activity in 2011 than we have in 2010.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: So this 4% to 5% sequential improvement, for example, you see that being perhaps accelerated as you move into next year?
componenttext: So this 4% to 5% sequential improvement, for example, you see that being perhaps accelerated as you move into next year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well we're basing that 4% to 5% on 1% to 3% ASMs worldwide. We get ASMs back in that 4% of 5% normal rate, I would expect us to be able to grow at a faster rate.
componenttext: Well we're basing that 4% to 5% on 1% to 3% ASMs worldwide. We get ASMs back in that 4% of 5% normal rate, I would expect us to be able to grow at a faster rate.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned you took $3 million of step ups in the electronics, and if you add that back, you had a 14% margin, looked pretty good. Now given that's military, should we assume that, that sort of level is sustainable going forward?
componenttext: You mentioned you took $3 million of step ups in the electronics, and if you add that back, you had a 14% margin, looked pretty good. Now given that's military, should we assume that, that sort of level is sustainable going forward?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Cai, maybe even a little better than that because we also had a contract adjustment in that Electronic Systems segment that cost us about a point in margin. So if you eliminate both the inventory step up and that contract adjustment, normalized margi
componenttext: Yes. Cai, maybe even a little better than that because we also had a contract adjustment in that Electronic Systems segment that cost us about a point in margin. So if you eliminate both the inventory step up and that contract adjustment, normalized margins in electronics were actually closer to 15%, and that's kind of where we've guided for the full year 2010 and very consistent with what we would expect going forward.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: So even with the intangibles, you can do 15%?
componenttext: So even with the intangibles, you can do 15%?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. The business that we bought is a good margin business, some very high EBITDA margins. And also a lot of growth that we expect in that business, and it's through the first three months of operation. It's performed very well, very much on track with wh
componenttext: Yes. The business that we bought is a good margin business, some very high EBITDA margins. And also a lot of growth that we expect in that business, and it's through the first three months of operation. It's performed very well, very much on track with what we had anticipated. So that is not going to be a margin degradation for us for that business. It should add to the growth rates and should not affect our margins going forward.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think your guidance implied that overall operating margins would be down a little bit year-to-year, and clearly it looked like because the intangibles this area might have been. If this area is flat and aftermarket is coming back in the other areas, doe
componenttext: I think your guidance implied that overall operating margins would be down a little bit year-to-year, and clearly it looked like because the intangibles this area might have been. If this area is flat and aftermarket is coming back in the other areas, does it now look like operating margins may be flat to up for the year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We kind of said 15% to 16% margins is what we expect for the year, so that's flat. Maybe toward the end of the year, it could be a little bit better. We think we'll still be in that 15% to 16% for the full year, though. Toward the end of the year, when yo
componenttext: We kind of said 15% to 16% margins is what we expect for the year, so that's flat. Maybe toward the end of the year, it could be a little bit better. We think we'll still be in that 15% to 16% for the full year, though. Toward the end of the year, when you start to get some 787 shipments coming in, that will be a little bit of a drag on margins, but by that time, we'll start to see higher aftermarket. So I think that 15% to 16% to me looks pretty solid, and based on the good performance in the first quarter, I think there's every reason to believe that we'll be well within that range.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Last one is if you look at corporate G&A, it was high, close to $34 million in the first quarter. Why was it that high? And what are we now looking for, for the full year?
componenttext: Last one is if you look at corporate G&A, it was high, close to $34 million in the first quarter. Why was it that high? And what are we now looking for, for the full year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: There are a few unusual things in the corp G&A area in the first quarter. We fully expect that to go back to the level that we'd guided toward of $31 million to $32 million per quarter, from the second, third and fourth quarter, rest of the year. The coup
componenttext: There are a few unusual things in the corp G&A area in the first quarter. We fully expect that to go back to the level that we'd guided toward of $31 million to $32 million per quarter, from the second, third and fourth quarter, rest of the year. The couple of unusual items in the first quarter were related to foreign exchange and some compensation accruals and some timing differences, things like vacation accrual where we had higher expense in the first quarter. But that’ll actually bleed back and be favorable during the last three quarters of the year. So the message there is we were $38 million in the first quarter. We'll be back down to $31 million to $32 million, we think for the rest of the year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from the line of Peter Arment with Broadpoint Gleacher.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from the line of Peter Arment with Broadpoint Gleacher.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, regarding the aftermarket, I guess what I want to drill on I guess a little more is you said you're seeing the increase in the piece parts. Could you give us maybe just a little more color, like where you're seeing that if it's in particular reg
componenttext: Marshall, regarding the aftermarket, I guess what I want to drill on I guess a little more is you said you're seeing the increase in the piece parts. Could you give us maybe just a little more color, like where you're seeing that if it's in particular regions or that you're starting to get some strength from more than others? Or is it more broad based? And then also regarding back to Rob's question about faster growth in 2011, would that be an assumption that you'll start to see a pickup from the majors?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as piece parts, when we say piece parts, we're talking about aero structures, all right, our largest business. And that is seeing an uptick in the piece parts, and we track those daily. So we monitor it very, very closely, and so that is tracking v
componenttext: As far as piece parts, when we say piece parts, we're talking about aero structures, all right, our largest business. And that is seeing an uptick in the piece parts, and we track those daily. So we monitor it very, very closely, and so that is tracking very nicely to our forecast. The majors, which are very large pieces of the nacelle structure or the Thrust Reverser, have always been lumpy in terms of sales during the year. But what we've seen so far in the first quarter is absolutely consistent with the rate we were in the last half of 2009. And so when we get to 2011 and there's more activity, we get back to more normal ASMs, and some of these -- and we get through the kind of engine de-stocking, I think we'll see a greater amount of major sales by the time we get to 2011.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Scott, just quickly on cash conversion, how should we think about this going forward now that we're starting to see a real increase on the OE side? This is obviously different from re-engining, just in general higher OE rates going forward.
componenttext: And, Scott, just quickly on cash conversion, how should we think about this going forward now that we're starting to see a real increase on the OE side? This is obviously different from re-engining, just in general higher OE rates going forward.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll have to see how that plays out on the working capital side, but I think we'll be able to manage that and still get above our 85%.
componenttext: Yes, we'll have to see how that plays out on the working capital side, but I think we'll be able to manage that and still get above our 85%.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Joseph Nadol from JP Morgan.
componenttext: We'll now go to Joseph Nadol from JP Morgan.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: As I said, the piece parts have picked up. We see a good trend there, and that's the vast majority of the aftermarket. But kind of the icing on the cake are the majors, and as we progress in the year, we'll update our forecast. But so far, we're right on
componenttext: As I said, the piece parts have picked up. We see a good trend there, and that's the vast majority of the aftermarket. But kind of the icing on the cake are the majors, and as we progress in the year, we'll update our forecast. But so far, we're right on track to hit our forecast that we had in our EPS range. And that I think is more of a function of the number of aircraft flying and those increase than the need for majors will increase. We've seen a reasonable order rate that gives us confidence that we'll hit our forecast for the year. We’ll just have to see how quickly activity picks up on the rest of the year to determine whether or not that could go higher.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the idea was year-on-year growth rates picking up. When we're talking about 4% to 7% this year, we would expect 11% to be substantially better than that, but not at the pace that you just spoke of.
componenttext: I think the idea was year-on-year growth rates picking up. When we're talking about 4% to 7% this year, we would expect 11% to be substantially better than that, but not at the pace that you just spoke of.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to from Joseph Campbell Barclays capital.
componenttext: We'll go to from Joseph Campbell Barclays capital.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: They've given us a lot of lead time on the 777, so that's not a problem with our long lead item forgings for landing gear, and we don't have that long a lead time on the 777 gear components. So I don't think we'll have any trouble ramping up if they make
componenttext: They've given us a lot of lead time on the 777, so that's not a problem with our long lead item forgings for landing gear, and we don't have that long a lead time on the 777 gear components. So I don't think we'll have any trouble ramping up if they make the decision to raise the rate.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: It was both. We keep these statistics in our customer service organization that services almost every one of our original Equipment businesses for parts of the aftermarket. And what we were seeing during the downturn in '09 in particular was that we would
componenttext: It was both. We keep these statistics in our customer service organization that services almost every one of our original Equipment businesses for parts of the aftermarket. And what we were seeing during the downturn in '09 in particular was that we would get less quote activity, and what we did get, they would send it in and then they would not authorize the repair until the last minute when they had to have it. What we're seeing now is greater quote activity in a shorter time between the time it arrives in our MRO facility and when the airline wants it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We're still in the process of working with Boeing, and I think both sides are working very well together.
componenttext: We're still in the process of working with Boeing, and I think both sides are working very well together.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from Howard Rubel from Jefferies & Co.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from Howard Rubel from Jefferies & Co.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Two things. Marshall, first, could you talk a little bit about some productivity measures? And maybe either give it to us in terms of some of the metrics that you might consider important from an operational point of view, whether it's turned revenues per
componenttext: Two things. Marshall, first, could you talk a little bit about some productivity measures? And maybe either give it to us in terms of some of the metrics that you might consider important from an operational point of view, whether it's turned revenues per employee or some factory utilization measures that you might use?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I haven't looked at the revenue per employee lately. But I know it's gone up because we've reduced our employment base by about 1,000 people out of 25,000 and we've been able to keep flat our sales. But we look more at on-time delivery and quality m
componenttext: Well, I haven't looked at the revenue per employee lately. But I know it's gone up because we've reduced our employment base by about 1,000 people out of 25,000 and we've been able to keep flat our sales. But we look more at on-time delivery and quality measures, as well as what we're doing in terms of the Toyota production system on continuous improvement. So they're very internally driven metrics that result in better financial metrics, and a lot of the cost downturn that we have been able to achieve in the last year has been through the continuous improvement process. So I don't see all that cost coming back because we're figuring out ways to better run the business without it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on cash, two things in terms of deployment. One is you talked about the funding of the pension plan, and the second, I noticed you bought back about $42 million worth of stock in the quarter, a little bit if when did the run rate, that's probably
componenttext: And then on cash, two things in terms of deployment. One is you talked about the funding of the pension plan, and the second, I noticed you bought back about $42 million worth of stock in the quarter, a little bit if when did the run rate, that's probably a record for you. But, first, how funded is the pension plan? And what were your plans in terms of share repurchase? I know you hinted you might do some.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I would just say I'll talk about the share repurchase just for a moment and let Scott go through [audio gap] Share repurchase, basically what we're doing is just trying to combat the dilution that happens because of incentive compensation equity systems.
componenttext: I would just say I'll talk about the share repurchase just for a moment and let Scott go through [audio gap] Share repurchase, basically what we're doing is just trying to combat the dilution that happens because of incentive compensation equity systems. So it isn't been a change in our policy so far.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Howard, what we typically see is a lot of activity in the first quarter when we're issuing restricted stock units and there's conversions of options and things like that. So that activity was higher in the first quarter so we eliminated that dilution
componenttext: Yes, Howard, what we typically see is a lot of activity in the first quarter when we're issuing restricted stock units and there's conversions of options and things like that. So that activity was higher in the first quarter so we eliminated that dilution effect by being more active on the repurchase side. It doesn't signal anything more than that. On the pension side, we put our entire planned U.S. pension contribution for 2010 into the plan in the first quarter. We had cash available to do that, and we thought that given the recovery in the economy that it was timing to our advantage to put it in earlier rather than later in the year. So that's why we did that. From a pension standpoint, we've got $105 million already funded, and there's probably another $35 million or so to go during the balance of the year to hit our plans for funding in 2010. So right on track with that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: But what I meant is your percentage of funding now, where are you in...
componenttext: But what I meant is your percentage of funding now, where are you in...

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're about 83% funded on the U.S. plans on an ABO basis and that's assuming a discount rate of 5.81%, which is just a little bit lower then where we ended the year.
componenttext: Yes, we're about 83% funded on the U.S. plans on an ABO basis and that's assuming a discount rate of 5.81%, which is just a little bit lower then where we ended the year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll now go to Heidi Wood from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll now go to Heidi Wood from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, can you talk a little bit about the -- if Airbus does an A320 GTF, can you talk to us about how you're thinking about the potential for accelerated retirements? Did that impede any of the expected aftermarket volumes that you're looking for down
componenttext: Marshall, can you talk a little bit about the -- if Airbus does an A320 GTF, can you talk to us about how you're thinking about the potential for accelerated retirements? Did that impede any of the expected aftermarket volumes that you're looking for downstream?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to restate that and you tell me if I got it right. You're talking about if Airbus re-engines the A320, basically the effect on us, and I know you had a follow-on question there that we just couldn't hear.
componenttext: I'm going to restate that and you tell me if I got it right. You're talking about if Airbus re-engines the A320, basically the effect on us, and I know you had a follow-on question there that we just couldn't hear.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Would that cause an acceleration in the retirement, which would then maybe may impede the expected aftermarket volumes downstream?
componenttext: Would that cause an acceleration in the retirement, which would then maybe may impede the expected aftermarket volumes downstream?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we don't really think that it will cause an acceleration in retirements. You're going to have close to 6,000 of those A320s in the fleet by the end of 2015, and the aftermarket would continue to grow because they're still very efficient aircraft, espe
componenttext: No, we don't really think that it will cause an acceleration in retirements. You're going to have close to 6,000 of those A320s in the fleet by the end of 2015, and the aftermarket would continue to grow because they're still very efficient aircraft, especially on the short-haul side. And we think just like when the 737MG came in, they kept making the classic for several years. There will be an overlap in it. They may, I don't know if they'll have to discount, but I'm sure there'll be some differentiation there. But we see a continuation of the current aircraft for several years as they phase in the production of the new aircraft, if they make this decision. And we're prepared, if we need to and to win business on the new one and continue to be able to deliver on the old one.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And you don't have nacelles on the current 737, but many of us when we look at the options that Boeing has in addition to GTF, I think they're seriously looking at doing a clean sheet of paper 737 replacement. Can you give us a sense, Marshall, as kind of
componenttext: And you don't have nacelles on the current 737, but many of us when we look at the options that Boeing has in addition to GTF, I think they're seriously looking at doing a clean sheet of paper 737 replacement. Can you give us a sense, Marshall, as kind of how do we think about the bandwidth of potential R&D for you going forward if that were to be announced?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think if there were a brand new airplane announced instead of a re-engining for Boeing, we would be right in there bidding on all of the major systems that we have, and we certainly have the technical and the financial resources to do it.
componenttext: I think if there were a brand new airplane announced instead of a re-engining for Boeing, we would be right in there bidding on all of the major systems that we have, and we certainly have the technical and the financial resources to do it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to David Strauss from UBS.
componenttext: We'll go to David Strauss from UBS.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, can you give us some color on the contract adjustments that you took? Most of them were in the Nacelles business. Can you just give some color there? And also talk about what you're expecting in terms of the full year from positive contract adjustm
componenttext: Scott, can you give us some color on the contract adjustments that you took? Most of them were in the Nacelles business. Can you just give some color there? And also talk about what you're expecting in terms of the full year from positive contract adjustments.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The contract adjustments were pretty favorable, not only in nacelles, but they were also favorable in our Wheel and Brake business, although they were negative, as I mentioned earlier, in electronic systems. So the total for the first quarter was about $1
componenttext: The contract adjustments were pretty favorable, not only in nacelles, but they were also favorable in our Wheel and Brake business, although they were negative, as I mentioned earlier, in electronic systems. So the total for the first quarter was about $16 million positive, which compared favorably to the year-ago period, up about $12 million. We had guided -- I think last year's total was about $45 million, and our expectation is that they would be positive in 2010 but less than last year of $45 million. And we're still tracking pretty well with that. The nature of the contract adjustments is similar to what we've seen before, when contracts roll over and they're repriced, we get a benefit there. As some contracts that are shorter cycle add volume or they get extended three months at a time, et cetera, we add volume to those units. That's a help. And we continue to work the cost side very diligently within our Aero Structures business in particular. So they continue to drive overheads down, drive production cost down, continue to move products where we can to low-cost countries and low-cost suppliers. So we continue to get benefit there as well. And then the wheel and brake side, it's been a longer-term story that continues, which is the quality of the brake material and the life that we get on that material has continued to be better than expected, and we're seeing benefits there.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow up, on 787, can you tell us where you are in terms of how many shipsets you've produced at this point? When do you start to benefit from a ramp up in production there? And then also, does your 4% to 7% aftermarket growth number this year, does
componenttext: As a follow up, on 787, can you tell us where you are in terms of how many shipsets you've produced at this point? When do you start to benefit from a ramp up in production there? And then also, does your 4% to 7% aftermarket growth number this year, does that include anything for initial spares provisioning on the 787?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does include some initial provisioning related to spares for the 787 introduction. It's not a huge part of that component, but there is some that we expect toward the end of the year, as that airplane enters service. In terms of where we're at on
componenttext: Yes, it does include some initial provisioning related to spares for the 787 introduction. It's not a huge part of that component, but there is some that we expect toward the end of the year, as that airplane enters service. In terms of where we're at on the production side, I think we're producing today close to the two per month level that Boeing has talked about externally. In terms of where we're at in shipsets, I think we're in the 15 to 20 range, but I haven't heard, maybe a little higher than that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The real answer is that we're keeping up with what Boeing's asking us to do so that we're prepared to hit the manufacturing production drum beat when it really ramps up.
componenttext: The real answer is that we're keeping up with what Boeing's asking us to do so that we're prepared to hit the manufacturing production drum beat when it really ramps up.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And so you're actually delivering those today, Marshall? And the negatives margin impact of 787 is actually flowing through your numbers today?
componenttext: And so you're actually delivering those today, Marshall? And the negatives margin impact of 787 is actually flowing through your numbers today?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it flows through on the non-product inventory, but it doesn't flow through in terms of sales because the sales haven't been booked yet because they don't go to the final customer in the form of an airplane. But they're for the flight test programs.
componenttext: Well, it flows through on the non-product inventory, but it doesn't flow through in terms of sales because the sales haven't been booked yet because they don't go to the final customer in the form of an airplane. But they're for the flight test programs.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: On wheels and brakes, I mean those are going in there at the typical margin on those.
componenttext: On wheels and brakes, I mean those are going in there at the typical margin on those.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to our next question from Samuel Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll now go to our next question from Samuel Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you guys talk a little bit about as we go forward with the aftermarket going through the year, I'm trying to just think through it. I'm surprised that you would see the inventories X the preproduction, and excess over average, that that's not really g
componenttext: Can you guys talk a little bit about as we go forward with the aftermarket going through the year, I'm trying to just think through it. I'm surprised that you would see the inventories X the preproduction, and excess over average, that that's not really growing yet. Wouldn't you be building inventories in anticipation of the airline starting to take more product? And so from a cash perspective and inventories, how does that play out through the year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: That will build through the rest of the year. Some of it will be in the form of our preproduction excess over averaged or what we call our non-product inventory. That grew by about $50 million in total, not just the 787 but across all platforms in the fir
componenttext: That will build through the rest of the year. Some of it will be in the form of our preproduction excess over averaged or what we call our non-product inventory. That grew by about $50 million in total, not just the 787 but across all platforms in the first quarter., and that will grow at a faster pace as we get toward the back end of the year. We've got, I think, close to around $200 million of production inventory already on the books to support 787. So there will be some further ramp up as we go through the year, but we've got a lot of inventory already in place to support ramp up in production.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: But in terms of the aftermarket itself, though would you be booking and I guess shipping in the same quarter? Or would we see a growth on the aftermarket pieces ahead of the delivery?
componenttext: But in terms of the aftermarket itself, though would you be booking and I guess shipping in the same quarter? Or would we see a growth on the aftermarket pieces ahead of the delivery?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sam, we don't get very long visibility on orders in the aftermarket for in-production aircraft. So like on an A320 or 737MG, a lot of times we will get the order and ship it in the same month. And what we try to do is be very efficient about the inventory
componenttext: Sam, we don't get very long visibility on orders in the aftermarket for in-production aircraft. So like on an A320 or 737MG, a lot of times we will get the order and ship it in the same month. And what we try to do is be very efficient about the inventory because if it's in production, a lot of times we can pull it right off the OE line and service the airline as opposed to have already put it in inventory. I don't anticipate a big buildup in inventory for the aftermarket this year. The buildup that Paul or that Scott was talking about was on 787, and that's typical in our contract accounting.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then separately just on the taxes and the R&D tax credit, should we see still a fairly I guess high tax rate in Q2 and Q3 and then a step down in Q4 assuming the timing of when that credit gets renewed?
componenttext: And then separately just on the taxes and the R&D tax credit, should we see still a fairly I guess high tax rate in Q2 and Q3 and then a step down in Q4 assuming the timing of when that credit gets renewed?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean you hit one of the key factors, which is when does it get renewed. If it gets renewed in the second quarter retroactive to the first of the year, then we'll have a catch-up benefit in Q2 and a lower rate, normal rate going forward the next two
componenttext: Yes. I mean you hit one of the key factors, which is when does it get renewed. If it gets renewed in the second quarter retroactive to the first of the year, then we'll have a catch-up benefit in Q2 and a lower rate, normal rate going forward the next two quarters. If it doesn't get passed until the end of the year, then you're catching up for the full year. We also have some one-time adjustments that we expect as we settle various disputes in cases with the IRS here, as well as outside the U.S. As those cases settle during the year, they create some lumps in terms of the timing in the tax rate in any particular quarter. What we've guided to is a 31% rate roughly for the full year, which implies on average about 29% for each of the next three quarters, but no one of those quarters is going to be exactly as that number. It's going to be better or worse depending on the timing of those settlements and the extension of the R&D credit.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you quantify just in order of magnitude of how big those the settlements are?
componenttext: Can you quantify just in order of magnitude of how big those the settlements are?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well the R&D piece, I think it's about $0.08 a share for the full year. So it can come all at once or it can come in phases. The other settlements, I can't give you specific numbers on that, but it basically bridges the difference between your normal rate
componenttext: Well the R&D piece, I think it's about $0.08 a share for the full year. So it can come all at once or it can come in phases. The other settlements, I can't give you specific numbers on that, but it basically bridges the difference between your normal rate and the effective rate that we've published.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Herbert with Wedbush.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Herbert with Wedbush.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to see if you can provide some more detail on the Defense business. It looked like obviously another good quarter for the first quarter, specifically for the aftermarket and the OE side and anything you're seeing moving forward through the y
componenttext: I just wanted to see if you can provide some more detail on the Defense business. It looked like obviously another good quarter for the first quarter, specifically for the aftermarket and the OE side and anything you're seeing moving forward through the year that might change within the mix within that business as you look to your up 15% for the year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Remember the 15% is divided about eight points of that is the acquisition at the end of last year of Atlantic Inertial Systems. 5% is organic on the rest of our businesses, and that is right in line with the expectations of particularly in our Sensors and
componenttext: Remember the 15% is divided about eight points of that is the acquisition at the end of last year of Atlantic Inertial Systems. 5% is organic on the rest of our businesses, and that is right in line with the expectations of particularly in our Sensors and Integrated Systems business and our Intelligence Surveillance Reconnaissance businesses that are kind of playing more in the sweet spots of the defense budget. So right now we're right in line with our 5% for the first quarter organically. We expected 5% organic for the year, plus the Atlantic Inertial Systems. So right on track.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And when you look at the mix then for the organic growth, say aftermarket, there was nothing in terms of the aftermarket or the OE shift that particularly stood out into the quarter?
componenttext: And when you look at the mix then for the organic growth, say aftermarket, there was nothing in terms of the aftermarket or the OE shift that particularly stood out into the quarter?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: No, not all, just business as usual.
componenttext: No, not all, just business as usual.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: As you look to follow on to some of the previous questions, when should we start to see then working capital start to work down? Or what's your timeframe for that through the rest of the year and into 2011?
componenttext: As you look to follow on to some of the previous questions, when should we start to see then working capital start to work down? Or what's your timeframe for that through the rest of the year and into 2011?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think it's going to depend on the market here. As OE rates increase, there will be a requirement for more working capital, and as the aftermarket starts to go, we try to keep that as low as we can in service production line. But if it really does t
componenttext: Well I think it's going to depend on the market here. As OE rates increase, there will be a requirement for more working capital, and as the aftermarket starts to go, we try to keep that as low as we can in service production line. But if it really does take off, we might have to lay on a little bit more, but it will more than pay for itself.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Eric Hugel from Stevens.
componenttext: We'll go next to Eric Hugel from Stevens.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about the Actuation and Landing Systems business. The margins, if you look sequentially, have improved nicely, and I just wanted to sort of talk about the drivers. I'm assuming it's the two of those three businesses that you talked about
componenttext: I wanted to talk about the Actuation and Landing Systems business. The margins, if you look sequentially, have improved nicely, and I just wanted to sort of talk about the drivers. I'm assuming it's the two of those three businesses that you talked about seeing improvement, Actuation and the Wheels and Brakes business. Is that really the key driver here? And looking forward, should that translate into further margin expansion here? Or is there some other trends that we should take into consideration?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, if you look sequentially in Actuation and Landing Systems, we've got about 7/10 improvement in margins from the fourth quarter, and they were up a bit where we were in Q2 and Q3 of last year as well. And aftermarket is a good driver of the sequent
componenttext: I mean, if you look sequentially in Actuation and Landing Systems, we've got about 7/10 improvement in margins from the fourth quarter, and they were up a bit where we were in Q2 and Q3 of last year as well. And aftermarket is a good driver of the sequential improvement. We were up about $25 million or 13% in aftermarket sales in the quarter so that's clearly helped. That business is kind of average in terms of it's aftermarket mix to total sales. It doesn't have quite as much aftermarket exposure or content as nacelles and interiors. So some other businesses may benefit just as much or more from the aftermarket recovery, but they'll clearly be a participant. That business is -- we've kind of said 10%, 11% margins in that business is where we expected it to be short term, and as we continue to drive cost efficiency, make investments, move product into lower cost countries, we can move those margins up over type. But it's a slower process in that business because it's a little bit more capital intensive business.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Is this going to be one of the businesses that is going to be impacted by sort of more than sort of OEM production ramps up?
componenttext: Is this going to be one of the businesses that is going to be impacted by sort of more than sort of OEM production ramps up?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly as the rates ramp up, particularly with Boeing, where we get more gear sales, it helps on the overall spreading of absorption in that very capital intensive Landing Gear business. For Airbus we don't have gear except on the A380. So it's not goi
componenttext: Certainly as the rates ramp up, particularly with Boeing, where we get more gear sales, it helps on the overall spreading of absorption in that very capital intensive Landing Gear business. For Airbus we don't have gear except on the A380. So it's not going to affect it as much there but wheel and brake services both 737 and A320. So they'll get more free of charge, but they're also going to have the greater aftermarket to make up for that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Marshall, a bit of a vague question but maybe can take a swipe at it. If you look at all the costs that you've taken out in the business, let's say over the downturn, if you sort of bucket how much of that is sort of structural, I mean not coming bac
componenttext: And, Marshall, a bit of a vague question but maybe can take a swipe at it. If you look at all the costs that you've taken out in the business, let's say over the downturn, if you sort of bucket how much of that is sort of structural, I mean not coming back, versus volume related?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I got to think that a good portion of it, over half of it is structural. I mean we've done restructuring, we've taken out a plant in Arizona, moved to Mexico, we keep moving more products to low-cost country. We're really driving continuous improvem
componenttext: Well, I got to think that a good portion of it, over half of it is structural. I mean we've done restructuring, we've taken out a plant in Arizona, moved to Mexico, we keep moving more products to low-cost country. We're really driving continuous improvement in our factories worldwide. We certainly have had a fair amount of indirect costs come out, and we were, like everyone else, our travel was reduced and our travel and entertainment expenses. But some of that will have to come back because you've got to go see your customer. But a lot of that other stuff isn't coming back, and that's the idea on the continuous improvement. We want to keep getting more and more efficient. I think one of the reasons that we didn't have the same reduction in force on this recession, with only 1,000 people out of 25,000 reduced, as opposed to 5,000 after 9/11 and when SARS and the Iraqi war hit back in 2003, is because we've gotten much, much more efficient. And we just haven't hired people as rapidly as in the past because we're able to do more with less.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, I want to follow up on what you were just discussing with how different the business is today as we enter the next cycle from a  profitability perspective. I think I heard you say in your prepared remarks that you're sort of thinking the margin
componenttext: Marshall, I want to follow up on what you were just discussing with how different the business is today as we enter the next cycle from a  profitability perspective. I think I heard you say in your prepared remarks that you're sort of thinking the margin of the company is going to be higher in any given point of the next cycle versus prior cycle. I think at your investor conference when you gave us the $10 billion revenue number you were a little reluctant to talk about the longer-term margin forecast. Is something different? Or have you just kind of thought about it more? And am I hearing you correctly about the longer-term margins?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think one thing I did say, whether it was at that conference or in past calls, is that we had margins up to 17% plus in the peak of the cycle in '08. I don't see a reason why we can't it get back there. I think we may even be able to exceed it at s
componenttext: Well I think one thing I did say, whether it was at that conference or in past calls, is that we had margins up to 17% plus in the peak of the cycle in '08. I don't see a reason why we can't it get back there. I think we may even be able to exceed it at some point in time, but it's going to be a slog. We've got to keep driving costs out of the business because I mean you don't get to keep everything you gain here. We've got customers that expect certain pricing, and we have to work with them on it, but I think we can get past that peak at some point in time. I can't predict exactly when, but I think directionally that's where we're going.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe a bigger strategic question for you, Marshall. On the C919 you had what, Nextel, on the nacelles on there? Do you see that as a new competitor going forward?
componenttext: Maybe a bigger strategic question for you, Marshall. On the C919 you had what, Nextel, on the nacelles on there? Do you see that as a new competitor going forward?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: They always were a competitor because what we're really talking about Safran, which was Aircell, and we competed against them before. The difference is with a smaller aircraft like that it usually ends up with one engine. So it's more conducive to having
componenttext: They always were a competitor because what we're really talking about Safran, which was Aircell, and we competed against them before. The difference is with a smaller aircraft like that it usually ends up with one engine. So it's more conducive to having a propulsion system than a larger aircraft like an A320 or a 737MG, where you have multiple engines and a separate nacelle procurement. We don't see it as creating a new competitor. It's one that was always there.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: And then if EMBRAER were to re-engine the 190, you guys have what, the nacelle on the 190 but not on the 170? If they were to re-engine that family, does that open up opportunity for you?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: Yes, that'd be an opportunity.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: Then I guess finally, I don't think we talked too about it. On the M&A front, what are you seeing?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't see anything compelling that we have to do, but we continue to find good bolt-ons like Atlantic Inertial Systems that we review, and we reject a lot more than you ever see us come to light with. So I would see us continuing to be in that market, b
componenttext: I don't see anything compelling that we have to do, but we continue to find good bolt-ons like Atlantic Inertial Systems that we review, and we reject a lot more than you ever see us come to light with. So I would see us continuing to be in that market, but watching the multiples, see what happens. We're cautious about not getting too much in the way of the defense side. We want to make sure that anything there stays in the sweet spot of the defense budget that's going to get funded even with the downturn in Iraq and Afghanistan. So I would hope there'd be some more commercial properties, too.

componenttext: No. We had AIS baked into the original set of guidance. It's as much just looking at our first quarter results, seeing good margin performance and sales moving right along with our expectations. So I think right now we sit in a place where we're more confident about 2010 based on what we've seen in the first quarter and based on the order patterns and activity that we've seen across the company. And that gave us the confidence to absorb the tax piece and keep our guidance in the same plays.
