headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Investor Relations,
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Paul Gifford. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our second quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks followed by
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our second quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks followed by Q&A. A presentation is available on our website, www.goodrich.com, which, together with our press release, provides the basis for most of our remarks.
Before we start, let me remind you that today's remarks include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, and the actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. They are also detailed in today's earnings press release. I urge you to read them carefully. This conference call is being webcast and replays will be available at our Internet site beginning this afternoon. 
Once again, we ask that all callers limit themselves to one question so that we can have time to allow all of you to ask your questions. If you have further unanswered questions, you can get back into the queue and ask another question, time permitting.
Now I'll turn the call over to Marshall, who will provide you with an overview of our second quarter results and our updated outlook for the full year 2010.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. I assume you've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of those documents that I think you'll find helpful about Goodrich. Today I'll spend just a few m
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. I assume you've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of those documents that I think you'll find helpful about Goodrich. 
Today I'll spend just a few minutes on the second quarter results and our outlook for 2010. Then I'll focus on trends and indicators of what we are currently seeing in our markets and what we think these trends mean to Goodrich.
Overall, our second quarter earnings continued to show the sustainability of our cost-containment efforts, and our sales showed year-over-year growth for the first time in several quarters. Our earnings per share of $1.24 were excellent operationally despite a higher-than-expected tax rate. Our 17.9% operating income margin was our highest reported margin since the third quarter of 2008. Our strong operational performance allowed us to increase our full year EPS expectation to $4.30 to $4.45 from our prior outlook of $4.15 to $4.40.
Our second quarter 2010 sales rose by 1% compared to our second quarter 2009. Our large commercial airplane original equipment market channel decreased by 1%, which was simply a result of the timing of deliveries to Boeing and Airbus.
Our regional, business and general aviation original equipment sales decreased about 10% compared to the second quarter of '09. However, sales in this market channel were up 5% sequentially and are up over 15% from their bottom in the fourth quarter of 2009.
Sales in our commercial aftermarket channel decreased 3% in the second quarter 2010 compared to the second quarter of 2009. Three of our eight commercial businesses reported higher aftermarket sales in the second quarter 2010 compared to the same period a year ago. Sequentially, commercial aftermarket sales were 3% higher in the second quarter 2010 than in the first quarter 2010.
We continue to see positive aftermarket trends, which I'll discuss more about in a few minutes.
In our defense and space, sales exhibited good overall growth in the second quarter of 2010, increasing by 11% compared to the second quarter of 2009. Our acquisition of Atlantic Inertial Systems, AIS, contributed 9% of this growth.
Organic sales growth of about 2% was driven primarily by our strong sales in our Landing Gear, Sensors and Integrated Systems, Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance and Engine Controls and Power Systems businesses.
In the second quarter 2010, we achieved segment operating income margins of 17.9% compared to 16% in the second quarter 2009 and 15.3% in the first quarter of this year. The improvement was due to strong operational performance, relentless pursuit of continuous improvement and favorable revisions and estimates for certain long-term contracts.
Net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures for the second quarter 2010 was very strong at $193 million, which is approximately 121% of second quarter net income.
For our full year 2010 outlook, sales are unchanged at approximately $7.1 billion. Our current outlook represents growth of about 6% compared to 2009.
The outlook for 2010 net income per diluted share has been increased to $4.30 to $4.45 compared to our prior outlook of $4.15 to $4.40, driven primarily by better operating margin performance.
We now expect large commercial airplane original equipment sales to increase about 3%. The slight reduction compared to our prior outlook simply represents minor scheduling adjustments by Boeing and Airbus. We now expect regional, business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales to decrease by 8% to 10%, which is an improvement compared to our prior outlook. We believe that sales in this market channel bottomed in late 2009, and we should see year-over-year growth beginning next quarter. 
We have slightly lowered our expectations for the large commercial, regional, business and general aviation airplane aftermarket sales growth. We now expect this channel to grow in the low-single-digit range compared to our prior outlook of 4% to 7%. We continue to expect sequentially higher aftermarket sales each quarter as we progress through the year. 
We should start to see higher year-over-year sales beginning in the third quarter. We believe sales for this market channel bottomed in the fourth quarter 2009, and we are currently more than 10% above those levels.
Finally, our outlook for defense and space sales growth has risen. We now expect sales growth in excess of 15% including sales generated by the AIS acquisition that closed in December of last year. Organic growth in this market channel is expected to be greater than 5%.
Our 2010 outlook for earnings per diluted share includes a full year effective tax rate of about 31% for 2010, unchanged from our prior outlook. Our tax rate outlook continues to include a full year benefit of approximately 1.5% or $0.10 per diluted share related to an assumed extension of the U.S. R&D tax credit retroactive to the beginning of the year.
For 2010, we continue to expect net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures to exceed 85% of net income. We now expect capital expenditures for 2010 to be approximately $250 million and expect worldwide pension contributions to be approximately $150 million pre-tax.
Now I'll focus on current activity and trends in our primary market channels. The large commercial OE production outlook continues to look very strong for the next several years. The order flow at the Farnborough Airshow was excellent. The production rate increases announced by Boeing and Airbus over the last several months will have no significant impact in our 2010 sales, but these rates, along with increasing 787 deliveries, should provide for strong growth in this market channel for several years.
For the commercial aftermarket, some of the macro indicators are showing improvement. Passenger airline and freight trends continue to improve. Airline load factors remain at high levels, especially in the U.S., and RPM data continues to show positive trends.
Load factors are at all-time highs for some U.S. airlines. Freight traffic continues to grow faster than passenger traffic. Although freight capacity growth is still lagging traffic growth, we believe freight traffic trends are a good leading indicator of future economic trends. While these trends don't affect current period aftermarket sales, they bode well for the future.
Even though capacity growth is lagging significantly behind passenger growth this cycle, if the airlines can keep growing RPMs and profits, they will eventually add additional capacity. Such capacity increases can come in the form of new airplanes, increased utilization of existing airplanes or returning airplanes from storage. All three actions like these on the part of airlines result in increased aftermarket sales for companies like Goodrich.
Over the past two years, the active fleet of large commercial aircraft has grown about 6%. As the fleet continues to grow in age and airline maintenance practices return to more normal levels, we should see a very good and sustainable aftermarket sales growth rates driven by both catch-up demand and normal aging.
Within our businesses, we continue to see some positive trends indicating that recovery in the aftermarket is underway and is sustainable. Our Wheels and Break business experienced year-over-year sales growth for the second quarter in a row. It's a very good sign as we believe this business is one of the leading indicators of overall activity growth in the commercial aftermarket channel.
In our Aerostructures business, major sales are filling in very nicely, and we remain confident they will meet our full year expectations. Even though Aerostructures’ MRO sales have been weaker than expected so far this year, we have seen our MRO booking backlog increase during the last two months.
Our Landing Gear business is seeing significant quote activity, mostly for sales that will occur in 2011 due to long lead times for these parts. In our Interiors business, the book-to-bill ratio is now solidly over 1.0.
Overall, most of our businesses are seeing favorable quote trends and improving backlogs. We continue to see very strong demand for our defense and space products, including products supporting helicopters, ISR and wheels and brakes on fixed-wing aircraft worldwide.
Overall, our performance during the second quarter was excellent from an operational standpoint and in line with our expectations at the market-channel level. We've been able to grow our already strong margins despite slightly lower aftermarket sales through a continued focus on cost control and operational excellence. Our longer-term prospects for sustainable growth are also bright, fueled by our significant market share gains on new commercial and military aircraft currently in development.
Goodrich's financial position remains excellent with more than $850 million of cash on our balance sheet, and a significant cash flow generation expectations for 2010. This allows us to continue to seek acquisition opportunities that would further enhance our growth rates and cash generation and drive shareholder value.
I'm looking forward to talking to all of you throughout 2010, and I'm confident that the commercial aerospace is on the upswing. I look forward to your questions.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go to our first question from Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the aftermarket from the 4% to 7% growth rate down to a lower number. Is that a change in your outlook for ASM growth? Or is it the utilization and load factors? Or is there a certain bus
componenttext: Marshall, I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the aftermarket from the 4% to 7% growth rate down to a lower number. Is that a change in your outlook for ASM growth? Or is it the utilization and load factors? Or is there a certain business within Goodrich or the aircraft types that are driving it? I mean, could you just help flesh that out a little bit?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Sam, I think more than anything, it's just a quarter or a little bit more than a quarter delay in the upturn that we expected in the aftermarket. It just didn't grow as fast in the second quarter as we were originally expecting, which makes it much more d
componenttext: Sam, I think more than anything, it's just a quarter or a little bit more than a quarter delay in the upturn that we expected in the aftermarket. It just didn't grow as fast in the second quarter as we were originally expecting, which makes it much more difficult to hit those upwards of 5%, 6%, 7% total for the year because it requires the third and the fourth quarter to have tremendous growth rates. So it's more just, I think, not being able to call exactly when this upturn is starting to really take traction. We got upturn. We got the sequential growth. We just haven't seen quite as much yet as we expected. There's no one business unit or product area that's holding us back.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Ken Herbert with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: We'll go to Ken Herbert with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, you were out making some comments at Farnborough, specifically that you thought a re-engining, specifically on the 737, would be sort of an incremental negative for Goodrich in the supply channel -- the supply base. I just wondered if you could
componenttext: Marshall, you were out making some comments at Farnborough, specifically that you thought a re-engining, specifically on the 737, would be sort of an incremental negative for Goodrich in the supply channel -- the supply base. I just wondered if you could flesh those comments out a little bit and further expound upon your thinking on that and your perception of what you think is happening and what, obviously, the implications would be for a re-engining or not a re-engining for Goodrich.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you're right. I did make comments about -- I didn't think it was in the best interest of the supply chain to re-engine either on Boeing or Airbus single-aisle. And the reasoning behind that is that going to stretch our supply base even thinner. And
componenttext: Well, you're right. I did make comments about -- I didn't think it was in the best interest of the supply chain to re-engine either on Boeing or Airbus single-aisle. And the reasoning behind that is that going to stretch our supply base even thinner. And I'm not talking about the Tier 1s like Goodrich. If one of them decides to re-engine or both, we can do it. We've got the resources to do it, and our customers at Airbus and Boeing know that. It's the smaller suppliers throughout the supply chain, those that supply us and other people like other companies like Goodrich, that I worry about getting stretched too thin. So it's more on a supply base comment. And I think if you listen to the Boeing CEO the other day, they have some concerns about the same thing in addition to productivity enhancements that can be had by a re-engining and what the timing of that could be. So as you look at the backlog on A320s and 737MGs, the backlog is huge. And so there is an ability to continue to produce those aircraft with a very good sales rate. So it just takes a supply base that's already producing for those increased rates that are being announced, and then have to come in and do an additional engine or engines for both aircraft. So it's more of a supply chain issue. And for Goodrich, if Airbus decides to do it, then we'll pursue it. If Boeing decides to do it, we'll pursue it. I mean, it's something that we're capable of doing and capable of doing profitably.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Question, Marshall. You mentioned your second highest margin ever at 17.9% in your monologue, and that's a tremendous number. I'm going to refer to your Slide #8, and I want to thank both Scott and Paul for this kind of detail. You do it every quarter. You talk about the increased income from revisions of estimates. It's $15 million or $0.12 in the quarter. I don't know how backward-looking that is. But thinking about that, how sustainable is this margin? And what kind of potential do you have going from here? I think a lot of people have looked at your peak-type margins of being in the 17%, 18% level, but clearly, you don't have peak volumes here. So how should we think about that in context?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Well, let me have Scott talk to you about the cume [cumulative] catches and how that affected the quarter, and then, I'll talk about margin sustainability.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Rob, on the contract cume [cumulative] [ph] (24:09) correct, we did have a lot of favorable adjustments in the quarter, and they've been very favorable on a year-to-date basis as well -- about $33 million favorable on the quarter. The underlying strength
componenttext: Rob, on the contract cume [cumulative] [ph] (24:09) correct, we did have a lot of favorable adjustments in the quarter, and they've been very favorable on a year-to-date basis as well -- about $33 million favorable on the quarter. The underlying strength that drove those is pretty broad, and it relates to the same things we've talked about in prior quarters. We’ve got labor hour improvements, which is productivity and efficiency. We’ve got added units to the forecast. We’ve got some supply chain savings as our supply chain organization continues to renegotiate and negotiate new contracts with existing suppliers and with suppliers located in lower-cost areas of the world. We completed some contract negotiations with some customers that were also favorable in the quarter. And we continue as contracts terminate to get price increases as well, occasionally on those contracts as well. So there's a good mix of drivers that in general are sustainable, and they’ve driven favorable adjustments in the past. And with a rising volume environment as the OEs continue to increase production, that bodes well toward favorable adjustments in the future. I don't see them coming at the same rate that we got them in the second quarter. That's not a sustainable level. So if you take that out and move it to a more sustainable level, we're still producing operating income margins in the 16%-type range in the quarter. And that's kind of our expectation for the full year 2010. We got excellent growth in margins in the Electronic Systems business for reasons other than, obviously, the contract adjustments, and those are sustainable going forward -- again, not at the same level that they posted in the second quarter, but it's real good progress on the margin line this year. Marshall, you want to comment on future?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Did you talk about tax?
componenttext: Did you talk about tax?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Not on the margin side.
componenttext: Not on the margin side.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: On the net income side, it really affected us. On sustainability, Rob, if you think about when this financial recession first hit at the end of '08, September of '08, and people were taking out costs, we took out a lot of indirect cost as well as direct.
componenttext: On the net income side, it really affected us. On sustainability, Rob, if you think about when this financial recession first hit at the end of '08, September of '08, and people were taking out costs, we took out a lot of indirect cost as well as direct. And there was a combination of supply chain savings, continuous improvement in our operations and in our offices. And certainly, we pared down some of the indirect like travel and so on. Well, if you look at the 17.9% right now in the year-to-date margins, our travel this year is up between 8% and 9%. So we're coming back on that. We knew some of that would come back. Our professional services and fees are up a little bit. Our R&D spend is up. That's all hitting P&L. But we're benefiting from securing some long-term agreements with our suppliers at reasonable prices, and we're seeing the benefit of some of the restructuring we've initiated last year. And we're achieving sustained savings from continuous improvement activity by lowering the core cost of quality, scrap, rework and more efficient production flow in our factories. So there's a lot of sustainability to the continuous improvement. And that's why what Scott was saying about we can maintain a pretty good margin going forward. One small example in a plant, and I won't tell you which one at this point in time. But they have about over a 10% return on sales operating margin in the product lines in there, and we think we can take that up another eight to 10 percentage points in the next 12 months through continuous improvement by getting one-piece flow into plant and so on. So we've really made a concerted effort, and the same thing is true on the cash flow side. Every one of our businesses now has a macro plan implemented through continuous improvement to increase that cash flow. So these are things that are not going to stop.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So Marshall, and maybe this is for Scott, when we think about volumes rising both in aftermarket at some point -- not that clear -- but more visible on the lower margin OE side, do you have a sense of what your incremental should be for the overall busine
componenttext: So Marshall, and maybe this is for Scott, when we think about volumes rising both in aftermarket at some point -- not that clear -- but more visible on the lower margin OE side, do you have a sense of what your incremental should be for the overall business?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It varies so much by market channel. So the incremental margins are favorable in most of the businesses, but when you think about OE coming from 787, that's an area that's not going to be incremental margin for the company in the early stages of productio
componenttext: It varies so much by market channel. So the incremental margins are favorable in most of the businesses, but when you think about OE coming from 787, that's an area that's not going to be incremental margin for the company in the early stages of production for that aircraft. And it's going to be years, like it has been in the past when we've introduced a new aircraft, to get to a maturity level where we are producing solid margins on those programs. So we don't expect 787 volume to be helpful from a margin standpoint or an EPS standpoint near term. On the military side, some of the military growth that we're going to see moving into 2011 is related to government-contract work, which also comes in at slightly lower margins than our average. So the real trick to moving margins north is, like Marshall said, sustaining the cost-reduction initiative, productivity initiatives that we have. And then, there's a question on exactly where the aftermarket growth rate will be for 2011. We're very bullish that it will be higher than this year. But just how high is going to determine kind of where we set the margin target for 2011, and it's just a little bit too early to do that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Rob, it's my belief, if you look at where we are right now, we're pretty balanced in our revenues between OE, defense and space and aftermarket. What we haven't seen yet is that real uptick in the aftermarket, though we know it's coming. So I tend to
componenttext: And Rob, it's my belief, if you look at where we are right now, we're pretty balanced in our revenues between OE, defense and space and aftermarket. What we haven't seen yet is that real uptick in the aftermarket, though we know it's coming. So I tend to say, we haven't seen the incremental margins yet that we can get in the aftermarket, but they will come.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Peter Arment with Gleacher Investments.
componenttext: We'll now go to Peter Arment with Gleacher Investments.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, I guess on Europe and the overall exposure there, specifically in the A320 fleet. What are you seeing there just in aftermarket demand? Any color about this region? I mean, did you see a particular soft spot this quarter just given what went on
componenttext: Marshall, I guess on Europe and the overall exposure there, specifically in the A320 fleet. What are you seeing there just in aftermarket demand? Any color about this region? I mean, did you see a particular soft spot this quarter just given what went on in Europe?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it was very hard to distinguish the whole volcanic ash thing. I'm sure that took some wind out of the sails of the aftermarket. So it was very difficult to just tell what that really was, but I think we'll continue to see a steady progress though in
componenttext: Well, it was very hard to distinguish the whole volcanic ash thing. I'm sure that took some wind out of the sails of the aftermarket. So it was very difficult to just tell what that really was, but I think we'll continue to see a steady progress though in Europe. So it's not where we want to get, but I think it will, and you see the worldwide ASKs and the RPMs. The trends are favorable, particularly when you get continent to continent. We've seen large double-digit increases in the international travel. So I think one of the things that's happening with 737MGs and A320s is that they are delivering quite a few new aircraft, obviously, into the worldwide fleet. And so you're getting brand new aircraft that take a while before you get the aftermarket. Now Wheels and Brakes turns around pretty quickly, but it's still going to be probably a year before you start seeing too much MRO on the Wheel and Brake side of it. So even though the fleet’s up 6%, it’s up with new airplanes. And they haven't started bringing old airplanes back yet, really. We're starting to see the possibility with, like FedEx is going to bring some airplanes back out of storage, but we haven't seen it extensively.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: We'll now go to David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you, Marshall, talk about kind of what you're seeing on the major side in piece parts and service? Have you seen anything as far as coming back on the major side?
componenttext: Could you, Marshall, talk about kind of what you're seeing on the major side in piece parts and service? Have you seen anything as far as coming back on the major side?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, on our piece parts, on the nacelles, they are trending positive the last few months. On Nacelles, as I said in my opening, that we feel pretty good about hitting the planned levels that we had for 2010, which really are at about the same level we ha
componenttext: Well, on our piece parts, on the nacelles, they are trending positive the last few months. On Nacelles, as I said in my opening, that we feel pretty good about hitting the planned levels that we had for 2010, which really are at about the same level we had in the last three or four months of last year. We didn't predict any large jump in the majors. And so far, we're staying right on plan on that. But that will come too as a number of spare engines and reduce out in the fleets and as they start bringing on more capacity, which they really haven't done to a great extent yet.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: David, on the MRO side, we've seen improving MRO demand around the world. But on a regional basis, actually, North America and Europe are trending well. Asia is still behind where we would've expected it to be, at least within the Nacelles and the Thrust
componenttext: David, on the MRO side, we've seen improving MRO demand around the world. But on a regional basis, actually, North America and Europe are trending well. Asia is still behind where we would've expected it to be, at least within the Nacelles and the Thrust Reverser business. On a regional basis for the rest of the MRO, it's pretty even. I wouldn't highlight any major differences regionally on the other businesses. But within Nacelles, Asia seems to be, continues to be a little bit weaker. Certainly more price competition in that market as well.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: We'll now go to Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: With airlines really starting to get flushed with cash, do you think that the airlines start to restock inventory levels? Is that kind of a component on your growth that you're expecting in the back part of the year? And then, I mean, also, I mean, do you
componenttext: With airlines really starting to get flushed with cash, do you think that the airlines start to restock inventory levels? Is that kind of a component on your growth that you're expecting in the back part of the year? And then, I mean, also, I mean, do you think airlines are deciding that maybe they don't need as high of safety stock levels -- that they can’t operate efficiently without as much inventory sitting around?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think they've learned some lessons here in this downturn, and I'm sure they'll try to operate with less safety stock levels as the upturn happens. But when it starts to go beyond the capability of the current inventories, which hasn't quite happen
componenttext: Well, I think they've learned some lessons here in this downturn, and I'm sure they'll try to operate with less safety stock levels as the upturn happens. But when it starts to go beyond the capability of the current inventories, which hasn't quite happened yet, we'll start seeing a restocking. I think we'll first start seeing, particularly on the A320s and the 737MGs, an increased utilization. You'll recall that one of the things that happened to us in early '09 is that we got a lesser utilization on those A320s. And so that leverage will come back the other way as that utilization increases. That'll happen before they’ll bring on capacity.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Troy, the other thing we’ve noted at least. We don't sell a lot of our parts through distributors, but there is a view within our company that the distributors have flushed their excess inventory, and they're now sitting at normal levels, and they’re
componenttext: Troy, the other thing we’ve noted at least. We don't sell a lot of our parts through distributors, but there is a view within our company that the distributors have flushed their excess inventory, and they're now sitting at normal levels, and they’re beginning to restock at least at that level. Like I said, it's not a big component for us, but I think it's a good positive indicator that at least that distribution channel is where they should be, and they’re starting to grow again.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just so I'm clear. You think the safety stock then at airlines probably is more of a 2011 story, like building back up to safety stock?
componenttext: Okay. So just so I'm clear. You think the safety stock then at airlines probably is more of a 2011 story, like building back up to safety stock?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think that's a big driver going forward because they have found ways to operate more efficiently that continue to push more of the inventory back to the MRO shops, the OEs, the suppliers. So I don't see that as a huge catalyst going forward. I thi
componenttext: I don't think that's a big driver going forward because they have found ways to operate more efficiently that continue to push more of the inventory back to the MRO shops, the OEs, the suppliers. So I don't see that as a huge catalyst going forward. I think in 2010, the early phase of 2010 and, certainly, later stage of '09, that was a negative as they destocked, but I don't see the restocking being a big tailwind.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Now we’ll go to Joe Campbell with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Now we’ll go to Joe Campbell with Barclays Capital.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually Carter Copeland and Joe Campbell. Wondered if you could chat briefly about commentary on re-engining and integrated engine and nacelle offerings and what that means for how you’ll position yourselves competitively given the competitive pos
componenttext: It's actually Carter Copeland and Joe Campbell. Wondered if you could chat briefly about commentary on re-engining and integrated engine and nacelle offerings and what that means for how you’ll position yourselves competitively given the competitive positioning on both propulsion and nacelles by one of your competitors and what sort of value proposition you bring and what you're thinking about that and how that makes this whole process a little bit different than we originally thought.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, right now, Boeing hasn't even come out with anything in terms of the potential of re-engining. Airbus is obviously looking at it, decided not to make any decisions at the Airshow. I expect both companies will make decisions by year end. We see no ch
componenttext: Well, right now, Boeing hasn't even come out with anything in terms of the potential of re-engining. Airbus is obviously looking at it, decided not to make any decisions at the Airshow. I expect both companies will make decisions by year end. We see no change in Airbus' position of procuring nacelle separately from engines. And if you ended up having an integrated propulsion system somewhere, I'm sure that we’d work it out.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll now go to Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just want to follow up on this phenomenon of higher-than-expected original equipment rates negatively impacting the aftermarket. It sounds like you're saying this is happening now, and others are saying this as well. But as we speak today, it's really tha
componenttext: Just want to follow up on this phenomenon of higher-than-expected original equipment rates negatively impacting the aftermarket. It sounds like you're saying this is happening now, and others are saying this as well. But as we speak today, it's really that rates weren't cut when we thought they would be. We actually haven't had the narrowbody production rate increases that have been announced coming through yet. So can you just walk through the extent to which this continues to be a headwind to the aftermarket through the cycle as we actually take 73 and 8320 higher?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think it's any different than it’s been here in the last year or so because airlines continue to take new aircraft. New aircraft have a cycle to go through before they have MRO. And you have a statistic on this, Scott, that you might want
componenttext: Well, I don't think it's any different than it’s been here in the last year or so because airlines continue to take new aircraft. New aircraft have a cycle to go through before they have MRO. And you have a statistic on this, Scott, that you might want to share.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Relative to ASM versus RPM growth, if you think about it that way, year-to-date, RPMs are up 8%. ASMs are up 2%. So capacity across the world is not moving at the same rate as RPMs. So the way we interpret that is while the airlines are getting healthier,
componenttext: Relative to ASM versus RPM growth, if you think about it that way, year-to-date, RPMs are up 8%. ASMs are up 2%. So capacity across the world is not moving at the same rate as RPMs. So the way we interpret that is while the airlines are getting healthier, traffic is improving. They're getting more revenue per seat mile that they fly. Those are positive trends, but they haven't transitioned that into more rapid capacity growth. And unless capacity is growing faster than the delivery rates of new airplanes, you're going to see suppressed levels of utilization on the older aircraft, which are the ones that drive near-term aftermarket sales. So what we're seeing in May, June, ASM rates year-over-year are up more like 6%. And that's the level at which I think you start to see increased utilization. You start to see aircraft being pulled out of storage and go back into service. But we haven't seen much of that yet. It's the early stages of that, and that's what will drive faster aftermarket. So the comment is on the high level of OE deliveries suppressing utilization and, therefore, aftermarket requirements for those older aircraft.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And so doesn't that just get even tougher as airlines take even more new aircraft in the future than they are today?
componenttext: And so doesn't that just get even tougher as airlines take even more new aircraft in the future than they are today?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: If you assume that there is no increasing growth in the overall market, it would get tougher. And that's what happened in this last year because you had all these new aircraft coming in at the same time. Demand had dropped.
componenttext: If you assume that there is no increasing growth in the overall market, it would get tougher. And that's what happened in this last year because you had all these new aircraft coming in at the same time. Demand had dropped.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And a lot of the narrowbody rate increases aren't going to occur for a while. You're going back up two in Airbus by the end of this year, but Boeing isn’t projected to take their rates up until early 2012. So I don't think that puts a lot of undue press
componenttext: And a lot of the narrowbody rate increases aren't going to occur for a while. You're going back up two in Airbus by the end of this year, but Boeing isn’t projected to take their rates up until early 2012. So I don't think that puts a lot of undue pressure in 2011. But I think we're at kind of the tipping point now, and you'll start to see improvements going forward.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We now go to George Shapiro with Access 342.
componenttext: We now go to George Shapiro with Access 342.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, I want to pursue your assumptions yet of low-single digit growth now in the aftermarket because even if it's 2%, it implies the second half has got to grow around 10%. It implies that sequentially, you probably got to be up 6% or 7%, and Q3 usua
componenttext: Marshall, I want to pursue your assumptions yet of low-single digit growth now in the aftermarket because even if it's 2%, it implies the second half has got to grow around 10%. It implies that sequentially, you probably got to be up 6% or 7%, and Q3 usually is not up sequentially from Q2. You can go back to '07, '08, '09. It was not up of that magnitude. So I guess my question is what gives you the confidence that you're not going to have to reduce this aftermarket growth once again?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, if you look at Q3 and Q4, they were very low last year. So you're going to get a reasonable jump on sequentially greater sales each of those two quarters. But that was one of the reasons to bring it down because we were counting on a lot mor
componenttext: Well, I mean, if you look at Q3 and Q4, they were very low last year. So you're going to get a reasonable jump on sequentially greater sales each of those two quarters. But that was one of the reasons to bring it down because we were counting on a lot more than that before, but we just haven't seen the uptick as much. The slope hadn’t increased as much as we expected in the second quarter. But we feel reasonably confident that we can do exactly what we've predicted here.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And George, we’re already operating at a rate today that is well above where we were in the fourth quarter of last year. So if we build off of that level and continue to get some sequential growth, by the time you get to the fourth quarter, we're mid-do
componenttext: And George, we’re already operating at a rate today that is well above where we were in the fourth quarter of last year. So if we build off of that level and continue to get some sequential growth, by the time you get to the fourth quarter, we're mid-double-digit kinds of growth relative to the same period a year ago, so…

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't doubt that the fourth quarter you can get a high year-over-year comparison. My question is more the third quarter, which usually is not sequentially much better than the second quarter.
componenttext: I don't doubt that the fourth quarter you can get a high year-over-year comparison. My question is more the third quarter, which usually is not sequentially much better than the second quarter.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess we'll just wait and see.
componenttext: I guess we'll just wait and see.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We're not counting as much growth in the third quarter as we are in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: We're not counting as much growth in the third quarter as we are in the fourth quarter.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: But sequentially, you only need 3% growth kind of sequentially quarter-over-quarter. That's what we got second quarter versus first quarter. So we think that, that's a very reasonable forecast of aftermarket activity for the second half of the year. And a
componenttext: But sequentially, you only need 3% growth kind of sequentially quarter-over-quarter. That's what we got second quarter versus first quarter. So we think that, that's a very reasonable forecast of aftermarket activity for the second half of the year. And as I mentioned, when you get to the second half and you do the compares against the second half of last year, you're going to be up either high-single or low-double digits.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Joseph Nadol with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll now go to Joseph Nadol with JPMorgan.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Can we drill down into the nacelle aftermarket one more way, which is by model a little bit? I'm wondering if maybe the lack of an overhaul bounce back might be related to the older aircraft that are more parked in the desert at a higher rate and maybe A3
componenttext: Can we drill down into the nacelle aftermarket one more way, which is by model a little bit? I'm wondering if maybe the lack of an overhaul bounce back might be related to the older aircraft that are more parked in the desert at a higher rate and maybe A320s are actually doing okay. Or are you still seeing kind of a slow overhaul pace across the board? Also just any kind of color you can give on what your visibility really is in the Nacelle Overhaul business. Is this something where you get signed up a month in advance, two months in advance, three months in advance? Or do you have less visibility than that?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We're getting growth in the Aerostructures aftermarket in A320. So there’s no question about that, and broadly speaking, that's true of MRO, piece parts, et cetera. It's not as high as it could be because of the suppressed utilization on those aircraft.
componenttext: We're getting growth in the Aerostructures aftermarket in A320. So there’s no question about that, and broadly speaking, that's true of MRO, piece parts, et cetera. It's not as high as it could be because of the suppressed utilization on those aircraft. But it's still growing, and it's growing basically everywhere around the world that has a significant fleet of those aircraft. So it's more of -- we are getting growth, which is what you’d expect. It's just not as high as we think it could be and probably will be when you look out over the next few years. There's clearly a negative impact on the older aircraft that have some of our components because they're in storage, and they haven't yet been brought back out of storage. So there is a story there. Relative to your comment on visibility, major sales, they can drop in if there's damage to a nacelle, and those come in kind of ad hoc. But we get some visibility out three to six months on orders as well as quoting activity, and that's what gives us confidence, as Marshall said in his opening remarks, that we're on track to do what we said we would do for this year and with a high level of confidence, basically being six months through the year. The orders have filled in, and the quote activity is reasonable.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So isn’t it fair to say that when we look at the old out-of-production aircraft that you're on, when we really start to see those come out of the desert -- and presumably, there might be some pent-up overhaul demand there -- that's when you're really go
componenttext: So isn’t it fair to say that when we look at the old out-of-production aircraft that you're on, when we really start to see those come out of the desert -- and presumably, there might be some pent-up overhaul demand there -- that's when you're really going to get a bump here? It's not going to be just as traffic picks up on A320s.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We don't have that much on the older aircraft in the Nacelle Thrust Reverser business, so I think it's more tied, frankly, to utilization increases on A320s, which I don't think is going to be a single pop. It's just going to be a faster growth rate as th
componenttext: We don't have that much on the older aircraft in the Nacelle Thrust Reverser business, so I think it's more tied, frankly, to utilization increases on A320s, which I don't think is going to be a single pop. It's just going to be a faster growth rate as those aircraft begin to be utilized more heavily.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And we will now go to Jason D'Arcy [ph] (47:19) with Citigroup.
componenttext: And we will now go to Jason D'Arcy [ph] (47:19) with Citigroup.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, we’re about 4% got on a year-to-date basis. So some of that’s just timing of sales that we booked Q1 versus Q2. So that organic growth rate of 5%-ish, it's still pretty solid for the full year. It's typical that third and fourth quarter of the
componenttext: Jason, we’re about 4% got on a year-to-date basis. So some of that’s just timing of sales that we booked Q1 versus Q2. So that organic growth rate of 5%-ish, it's still pretty solid for the full year. It's typical that third and fourth quarter of the year is an uptick in military sales just because of the timing of military budgets and releases of orders against those budgets. And as we look at order backlog in our Wheel and Brake business and in our ISR business and in our helicopter-related products, those backlogs look very good going into the second half. And that's why we actually raised our sales guidance in military sales from around 15% to over 15% for the full year, and that's driven organically. That's not acquisition activity.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: What was the question?
componenttext: What was the question?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: How we view the business longer term from an organic growth perspective.
componenttext: How we view the business longer term from an organic growth perspective.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think if you look longer-term in those areas that Scott just outlined that those are areas of the Defense budget that will continue to be funded at a greater level than the fighter platforms, C-17s, things like that. So helicopters, even the OE producti
componenttext: I think if you look longer-term in those areas that Scott just outlined that those are areas of the Defense budget that will continue to be funded at a greater level than the fighter platforms, C-17s, things like that. So helicopters, even the OE production rate is the highest of any military platforms out there. And on ISR, there's going to be a continued need for ISR, even if we're winding down in the Middle East.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We've got a very good market share position so far. We think we've got a really excellent product there, and that's, I think, indicative of the airline activity selecting us. We typically don't end up in a -- when you're a dual-source position like that w
componenttext: We've got a very good market share position so far. We think we've got a really excellent product there, and that's, I think, indicative of the airline activity selecting us. We typically don't end up in a -- when you're a dual-source position like that with a dramatically different than 50%, 60% market share. We would hope that we're above 50%, but I don't think the higher numbers that we’re at currently are sustainable long term. But I think it's a good validation for our business of just how the airline view the robustness of the design and the value proposition that we’re offering to them.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: We'll now go to Doug Harned with Sanford Bernstein Brokerage.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually Finbar Sheehy for Doug. Taking it back to the productivity improvements and work you’ve been doing, you've been on a trajectory to increase the percent of your workforce that's in low-cost countries. I think you were on a trajectory for 11
componenttext: It's actually Finbar Sheehy for Doug. Taking it back to the productivity improvements and work you’ve been doing, you've been on a trajectory to increase the percent of your workforce that's in low-cost countries. I think you were on a trajectory for 11% in 2010. I just wanted to ask you, is that still the case? Is that a significant part of the performance improvement? And where do you see that going in '11 and '12?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's still the case. We’re still increasing our employee equivalence in low-cost countries. If you look at where we were after 9/11, we had 25,000 people, and we laid off 5,000. When we had this most recent downturn, we were back up to about 25,00
componenttext: Well, it's still the case. We’re still increasing our employee equivalence in low-cost countries. If you look at where we were after 9/11, we had 25,000 people, and we laid off 5,000. When we had this most recent downturn, we were back up to about 25,000 on probably a couple of billion dollars greater revenues. We took out about 1,000 people. And if you think about the acquisitions we've done, we've added probably 3/4 of that back, and we've also done more hiring in low-cost countries. So we're roughly at about the same level with a much higher dollar per employee. And we continue to move out of Western Europe suppliers that can't meet our demands or into Indonesia, into India, places like that, in Eastern Europe, in Mexico. And that will continue.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll now go to Eric Hugel with Stephens.
componenttext: And we'll now go to Eric Hugel with Stephens.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about the cume [cumulative] catches [ph] (54:31) in the quarter being driven by productivity improvements, pricing and other positive things. And you've said in the past that we should think about 50% to 60% incremental margins on the commercia
componenttext: You talked about the cume [cumulative] catches [ph] (54:31) in the quarter being driven by productivity improvements, pricing and other positive things. And you've said in the past that we should think about 50% to 60% incremental margins on the commercial aftermarket business. Or I think you’ve thrown out the number $0.06 for every 1% improvement in aftermarket sales. So given this increased productivity and such, should we be thinking that these incrementals could be better?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think dramatically better than the 50% to 60% that we've referenced previously just because your cost basis is as much being -- there's not as much cost when you have that kind of a margin environment. So when you're driving cost, it doesn't move
componenttext: I don't think dramatically better than the 50% to 60% that we've referenced previously just because your cost basis is as much being -- there's not as much cost when you have that kind of a margin environment. So when you're driving cost, it doesn't move those margins very much on the net side of the business. It's probably more leveraging, frankly, on the OE and to some extent on some of the military products where you’re not in a cost plus environment. So it's more leveraging for those sales, I think, than it is on the aftermarket side.  But it's important, and it also gives you the opportunity to price your product aggressively with your customers and continue to offer them value as we operate in a competitive environment, and it’s important that we push productivity so we can work on the requirements of our customers too. So not every penny falls to the bottom line.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Not all of that was factored into the guidance, and that's frankly part of the reason why we increased our outlook for the full year. We did have a higher tax rate in the second quarter than we expected and guided to. So if you're just looking at second q
componenttext: Not all of that was factored into the guidance, and that's frankly part of the reason why we increased our outlook for the full year. We did have a higher tax rate in the second quarter than we expected and guided to. So if you're just looking at second quarter EPS, while we clearly got a benefit on the contract adjustments, our tax rate was $0.06 higher than what we had guided earlier. So the net of those two, still a positive but not as much as you might expect.

componenttext: One of the things I think Boeing talked about as a barrier to pushing that narrowbody rate even higher would be the ability of suppliers to meet the requirements and CapEx needs. headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Well, if you start at the Airbus, back before the downturn, we were prepared to go to rate 40 when they were asking people to do that. They obviously never went there, but we were prepared to do it. And on the 737, we don't have any significant capital requirements to move that rate up. So we're prepared to do it for both companies.

componenttext: I think I got all those subparts to that. Just to hit the FX piece. There was about, I think, $11 million total FX benefit in the quarter. My guess is that we'll probably see some modest positives in the second half, but nowhere near the level that we’ve booked in the second quarter or in the first half.

componenttext: Okay. And then can you give us a quick comment on pension for next year given markets have not been great, discount rates are down, or just any color, how we should think about that?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our full year pension expense in 2010 is about $162 million. If we were to keep the same discount rate as '09 and achieve our long-term rate of return assumption on asset, we would expect that to be about $150 million, $152 million in 2011. Obviously, dis
componenttext: Our full year pension expense in 2010 is about $162 million. If we were to keep the same discount rate as '09 and achieve our long-term rate of return assumption on asset, we would expect that to be about $150 million, $152 million in 2011. Obviously, discount rates have come down significantly so far this year, and asset returns through the first six months of the year have been about zero. You go through July, we're probably up 4% or so for the asset-return assumption. So if you said, it doesn't get any better or change from the end of July, we would probably be around $205 million to $210 million of pension expense for next year. So that's about a $0.25 delta over where we would expect to be this year. And I just remind you that we’ve got five more months to go in 2010 for discount rates to change, assets to continue to improve, we hope. So it's obviously too early to specify a number for 2011. There's a lot that'll change between now and year end, but that's where we are right now.
