componenttext: If we look back three to six months ago, no. We were talking about just the normal change that we would expect to see year-over-year in pension related to changes in discount rates and returns as they go through the year. So it wasn't anticipated three to six months ago. But it's something that we look at every year about this time in terms of how to set the actuarial assumptions for the following year. And as we got into that process this year, we realized that we're meeting the definition of having nearly all of our pension plan participants in inactive status and that gives you -- it actually requires you to make that change in terms of your amortization period as we described in opening comments.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Scott, if we look at the swing on the headwinds that existed six months ago in '11, before you did the data and adjusted forward the prepayment, et cetera, to the headwind to the tailwind we have now, what portion of it was from the actuarial adjustmen
componenttext: So Scott, if we look at the swing on the headwinds that existed six months ago in '11, before you did the data and adjusted forward the prepayment, et cetera, to the headwind to the tailwind we have now, what portion of it was from the actuarial adjustment?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can give you a kind of general walk. 2010 pension expense will be about $162 million. And if we had, had flat discount rates, normal rate of return, we would have been at $146 million pretax for 2011. The discount rate change that we've seen in the firs
componenttext: I can give you a kind of general walk. 2010 pension expense will be about $162 million. And if we had, had flat discount rates, normal rate of return, we would have been at $146 million pretax for 2011. The discount rate change that we've seen in the first nine months of the year going from 5.9% down to 5%, that would have cost us about another $57 million in pension expense. So that would have pushed us to about $203 million. Then in addition -- then we've done two things to reduce that. One is the actuarial change. The other is we did some accelerated contributions to the plan. Between those two, we did about $100 million reduction and then we're offsetting a bit of that by becoming a little more conservative in our long-term rate of return assumptions, mortality tables, et cetera. Then again, that will reduce the volatility of those sensitivities going forward. So as discount rates change, return assumptions are either above or below what our expectation is, we'll see less volatility in expense going forward. So those are the major movers.

componenttext: We would still expect to be around $32 million a quarter on the corp line and another $6 million a quarter in the other expense line. And you're right, we were $8 million to $10 million higher in the third quarter of this year, and that relates to some unusual charges related to active medical costs that we don't expect to repeat going forward as well as higher compensation costs, both stock-based comp where we trued up to the higher stock price and higher accruals for incentive compensation as well. So again unusual items in the quarter. So quarter expenses are being well controlled and should go back to that $32 million a quarter roughly.

componenttext: The implied margin in 4Q looks to be -- if we're assuming a $7 billion top line, looks to assume just over 15% on the 15.1%, 15.2% on the segment line, I think. I'm just wondering is that mixed? What are the downside here? I know EAC is a contributor, but that's not all of it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you’re right. We're assuming around 15% margins in the fourth quarter, and there's three drivers to that. One is the lower level of contract adjustments that takes about a point off of the margin when you go from Q3 to Q4. We're also expecting some
componenttext: Yes, you’re right. We're assuming around 15% margins in the fourth quarter, and there's three drivers to that. One is the lower level of contract adjustments that takes about a point off of the margin when you go from Q3 to Q4. We're also expecting some higher low-charge shipments of wheels and brakes into the commercial and regional market in the fourth quarter, and that actually continues on into 2011. That's going to cost us maybe 3/10 of a point. And then the DeCrane acquisition adds sales in the quarter, but remember because of purchase accounting, you have to write up the inventory to full fair value so you get very little margin in the fourth quarter. So you get sales with no margin in that business until you flushed the inventory. So that's about another almost half a point to margin in the quarter. So that gaps most of the Q3 to Q4 margin.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Third Quarter 2010 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Paul G
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Third Quarter 2010 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Paul Gifford. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you Kelly, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our third quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with a few brief prepared remarks f
componenttext:
Thank you Kelly, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our third quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with a few brief prepared remarks followed by Q&A. A presentation is available at our website, www.goodrich.com, which together with our press release, provides the basis for most of our remarks.
Before we start, let me remind you that today's remarks include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. And actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. They are also detailed in today's earnings press release. I urge you to read them carefully. This conference call is being webcast, and replays will be available at our Internet site beginning this afternoon.
Once again, we ask that callers limit themselves to one question so that we can have time to allow all of you to ask your questions. If you have further unanswered questions, you can get back into the queue and ask another question, time permitting.
Now I'll turn the call over to Marshall who will provide you with an overview of our third quarter 2010 results, our updated full year 2010 outlook and our outlook for 2011.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. You've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of these documents that you'll find helpful as you think about Goodrich.Today, I'll spend a few minutes on
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. You've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and the related presentation. There's a lot of information in both of these documents that you'll find helpful as you think about Goodrich.
Today, I'll spend a few minutes on our third quarter results and our outlook for 2010, then I'll turn to our outlook for 2011 and discuss its drivers.
We continued our strong performance during the third quarter. Our sales growth of 6% was accompanied by net income growth of 10%. All of our major market channels, including the commercial aftermarket reported year-over-year sales growth. 
Our large commercial airplane original equipment market channel grew by 2%, and that growth was relatively evenly split between Boeing and Airbus. 
Our regional business and general aviation original equipment sales increased by about 21%, including sales associated with the recent acquisition of DeCrane's Cabin Management assets. Organic growth in this market channel was about 15%.
Commercial aftermarket sales were 3% higher than the third quarter last year and 2% higher than in the second quarter of 2010. Six of our eight commercial businesses reported higher aftermarket sales in the third quarter of 2010, compared to the year-ago period.
Our defense and space sales continued to exhibit growth in the third quarter of 2010, increasing by 12% compared to the third quarter of 2009. Our acquisition of Atlantic Inertial Systems contributed 8% of this growth. Organic sales growth of about 4% was driven primarily by strong sales in our Wheels and Brakes, Aerostructures and Sensors and Integrated Systems businesses.
In the third quarter of 2010, we achieved segment operating income margins of 17.3% compared to 15.8% in the third quarter of 2009. The improvement was due to strong operational performance, relentless pursuit of continuous improvement and favorable revisions and estimates for certain long-term contracts. 
Net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures for the third quarter of 2010 was very strong at $204 million, which is approximately 128% of third quarter net income.
Since last July, we've taken several additional steps to increase shareholder value. Among them, in October, our Board of Directors approved a 7% increase in our company's quarterly dividend to $0.29 per share from the previous level of $0.27 per share on its common stock. This was our fourth consecutive annual increase in our dividend.
In September, we completed the acquisition of the Cabin Management assets of DeCrane Holdings Co. The purchase price was approximately $280 million. We expect this acquisition to be neutral to earnings in 2010 and to be accretive beginning in the first quarter 2011. And in September, we issued $600 million of 10-year debt at 3.6% interest. We used the proceeds to complete the redemption of $257 million of debt due in 2012, which carried a 7.6% interest rate, and we are accelerating $300 million of pension contributions into the fourth quarter of 2010.
For our full year 2010 outlook, we have adjusted our sales outlook to approximately $7 billion, which represents growth of about 5% compared to 2009. The outlook for 2010 net income per diluted share has been adjusted to $4.30 to $4.35, compared to the prior outlook of $4.30 to $4.45. Current outlook includes debt redemption costs of approximately $0.18 per diluted share, which were not included in the prior outlook and will be recognized in the fourth quarter 2010. Excluding these costs, the current outlook would have increased above the prior outlook by $0.10 to $0.20 per diluted share, driven primarily by better operating margin performance.
We now expect large commercial airplane original equipment sales to increase by about 4%, which includes the impact of all of the recently announced production rate changes and incorporates the new delivery schedules for the Boeing 787 and 747-8. We now expect regional business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales to grow by about 4%, including sales associated with the DeCrane acquisition. Excluding sales from the DeCrane acquisition, sales in this market channel would be expected to decrease by about 6% to 7%, a slight improvement over our prior outlook.
We have slightly lowered our total 2010 expectations for large commercial, regional business and general aviation airplane aftermarket sales growth. We now expect sales in this market channel to be approximately the same as they were in 2009, compared to our prior outlook of low single-digit growth. We continue to expect year-over-year growth in the fourth quarter 2010 to exceed 10%. We believe sales for this market channel bottomed in the fourth quarter of 2009, and we are currently operating at more than 14% above those levels.
Our outlook for defense and space sales growth is largely unchanged at about 15%, including sales generated by the AIS acquisition that closed in December of last year. Organic growth in this market channel is expected to be about 5%.
Our 2010 outlook for earnings per diluted share includes a full year effective tax rate of about 30% for 2010, a slight improvement compared to our prior outlook of 31%. Our tax rate no longer includes a full year benefit of approximately 1.5% or $0.10 per diluted share related to an assumed extension of the U.S. R&D tax credit retroactive to the beginning of 2010. Our effective tax rate outlook does now include a tax benefit of approximately $23 million in the fourth quarter of 2010 related to a settlement last week with the California Franchise Tax Board concerning issues related to Goodrich and Rohr for all tax years through 2001.
For 2010, we now expect net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures to be approximately 50% of net income, including an expected incremental $300 million pension contribution in the fourth quarter. Excluding this incremental contribution, net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures would have increased to approximately 100% of net income, a significant improvement compared to our prior outlook of greater than 85% conversion. We now expect capital expenditures for 2010 to be approximately $225 million to $250 million and expect worldwide pension contributions to be approximately $450 million, pretax.
Now I'll turn to 2011. We're excited about the prospects for 2011. A large airframe manufacturers have announced production rate increases on single-isle aircraft and new programs like Boeing 787 will begin deliveries soon. We expect the commercial aftermarket to grow in 2011 as airlines and package carriers add capacity and increase utilization rates on their existing fleet. In addition, our defense and space sales should experience solid growth as demand for electro-optical reconnaissance sensors, helicopter products, inertial sensors and aftermarket parts and services for fighter and transport aircraft continue to increase. Overall, we are expecting sales growth of about 10% to 11%, including good growth in every market channel and earnings growth of between 15% to 20%.
We expect sales in 2011 to be approximately $7.7  billion to $7.8 billion, driven by growth in every market channel. Large commercial airplane original equipment sales are expected to increase by about 15% to 20% assuming all announced production rate increases are implemented and assuming Boeing 787 deliveries begin in the first quarter of 2011 and 747-8 deliveries to begin in midyear 2011.
Regional business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales are expected to grow by about 35% to 40%, including sales associated with the DeCrane acquisition. Excluding the incremental 2011 sales from DeCrane acquisition, we would expect sales growth of about 4%. 
Large commercial, regional business and general aviation airplane aftermarket sales are expected to increase by about 5% to 7%. Our outlook assumes worldwide available seat miles, ASMs, increase by 4% to 6% compared to 2010, which is roughly consistent with the latest IATA forecast. And defense and space sales are expected to increase by about 5% to 6%, organically.
Based on these sales increases, benefits from our continuous improvement in productivity initiatives and lower pension expense, we expect 2011 net income per diluted share to be in the range of $5 to $5.20, an increase of 15% to 20% compared to expectations for 2010 net income per diluted share. Our 2011 outlook includes operating margins of 16%, reflecting very rapid growth in the lower margin commercial original equipment and cost plus military contracts, offset by growth in the aftermarket and the benefit of continuous improvement and lean initiatives on costs.
Lower worldwide pretax pension expense of approximately $30 million or $0.15 per diluted share. Our estimate for 2011 pension expense assumes a 2010 actual return on U.S. plan assets of 9% and a 2011 U.S. discount rate of 5%, both of which reflect conditions as of September 30, 2010. The lower 2011 pension expense is the result of actuarial changes and the benefit of the $300 million incremental contribution I mentioned earlier, which we expect to make during the fourth quarter of 2010. Because almost all of the plan participants are now inactive, the company is changing its amortization period for gains and losses on the U.S. salary pension plan to the estimated remaining life of plan participants rather than the estimated the remaining service period of active plan participants. This change will have the added benefit of lowering pension expense sensitivity to changes in discount rates and the rate-of-return on plan assets in future years. The company also expects to reduce its expected long-term rate-of-return assumptions as of January 1, 2011. I remind you that our pension expense for 2011 will be finalized based on actual asset values and discount rates on December 31, 2010.
We are expecting a 2011 full year effective tax rate of approximately 30%, consistent with the expected tax rate for 2010. The 2011 effective tax rate does include a full year 2011 benefit of approximately 1.5% or $0.10 per diluted share related to an assumed extension of the U.S. R&D tax credit, which has not yet occurred.
We expect net cash provided from operating activities, minus capital expenditures, to exceed 85% of net income for 2011. Our outlook includes expected capital expenditures of $300 million to $350 million and a pretax worldwide pension plan contributions of $50 million to $100 million.
Overall, our performance during the third quarter was excellent from an operational standpoint. We've been able to improve our already strong margins despite slow aftermarket sales growth through a continued focus on cost control and operational excellence. We continue to expect long-term sustainable growth in sales and earnings fueled by our significant market share gains on new commercial and military aircraft, currently in development, and steadily increasing commercial aftermarket sales.
Our financial position remains excellent with more than $1.3 billion of cash on our balance sheet as of September 30 and significant cash flow expectations for 2011. We've used about $300 million of cash to redeem the debt due 2011, and we'll use another $300 million in the fourth quarter to fund our pension plan. At year-end 2010, we expect to have about $800 million of cash on hand with no significant debt maturities until 2016. This will allow us the flexibility to continue to seek acquisition opportunities that further enhance our sales and earnings growth, contribute to cash generation and drive shareholder value.
I'm looking forward to talking to all of you throughout the rest of this year and through 2011, and I'm confident that the commercial aerospace is back on a solid growth track.
Let's open up the call for questions.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go to our first question from David Strauss of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go to our first question from David Strauss of UBS.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marshall, on your 2011 aftermarket forecast, can you give us some of the moving pieces there? You're assuming 4% to 6% of ASM growth, but only 5% to 7% aftermarket growth. Can you talk to us about what you're assuming in terms of pricing, specifically. An
componenttext: Marshall, on your 2011 aftermarket forecast, can you give us some of the moving pieces there? You're assuming 4% to 6% of ASM growth, but only 5% to 7% aftermarket growth. Can you talk to us about what you're assuming in terms of pricing, specifically. And then on the major side, what you're assuming that you're going to get on the major side in terms of any recovery there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the major side, we're looking at about the same level in our forecast for 2011 as what we've experienced in 2010. Of course, there's always a possibility that, that can be more, but we don't know yet on that. On pricing, we're able to get price increas
componenttext: On the major side, we're looking at about the same level in our forecast for 2011 as what we've experienced in 2010. Of course, there's always a possibility that, that can be more, but we don't know yet on that. On pricing, we're able to get price increases on parts, but on labor and some of our MRO areas, it's very difficult to get that in order to get contracts from the airlines. So pricing in our outlook for 2011 isn't as robust maybe as we put in some of the boom years that we've had in the past. However, we still have ability to gain pricing in various parts of our aftermarket.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the ASM forecast of 4% to 6%, how does that kind of split up between new aircraft versus old aircraft? Do you think next year we're going to continue to see much more in the way of new aircraft growth versus old aircraft growth and that ki
componenttext: And in terms of the ASM forecast of 4% to 6%, how does that kind of split up between new aircraft versus old aircraft? Do you think next year we're going to continue to see much more in the way of new aircraft growth versus old aircraft growth and that kind of dampens what we've done in terms of the aftermarket again next year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we'll continue to see more on the new aircraft side next year with the amount of deliveries that are taking place. Although we're starting to see signs that some airlines are bringing back old aircraft out of the desert. We've gotten some aftermar
componenttext: I think we'll continue to see more on the new aircraft side next year with the amount of deliveries that are taking place. Although we're starting to see signs that some airlines are bringing back old aircraft out of the desert. We've gotten some aftermarket sales from 747-400s and some of the Fedex planes that are coming out. So I think we'll get a better mix of aftermarket next year than we've seen in 2010. And of course, if we get even 1% more in aftermarket sales, that's $0.06 a share.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Douglas Harned with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Douglas Harned with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd like to continue on the aftermarket. Are you seeing -- to what extent are you seeing an impact of cannibalization of parts at this point or consolidation of airlines, say impacting inventory levels, optimization of inventory levels on spares. Are are
componenttext: I'd like to continue on the aftermarket. Are you seeing -- to what extent are you seeing an impact of cannibalization of parts at this point or consolidation of airlines, say impacting inventory levels, optimization of inventory levels on spares. Are are you seeing any material effects from either of those right now?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're seeing nothing on the consolidation side. And I don't think the cannibalization side has gotten worse, it's probably getting better.
componenttext: We're seeing nothing on the consolidation side. And I don't think the cannibalization side has gotten worse, it's probably getting better.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So when you look forward to next year and you think about deferred maintenance levels, and I saw in one of your charts, you said that's essentially flat going into next year, no up or down impact. How do you arrive at that look where you aren't expecting
componenttext: So when you look forward to next year and you think about deferred maintenance levels, and I saw in one of your charts, you said that's essentially flat going into next year, no up or down impact. How do you arrive at that look where you aren't expecting deferred maintenance to be a significant driver?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's difficult to sort out between deferred maintenance and what is actually needed just because of operations out there. And so they tend to get lumped into the same bucket. So where we see deferrals more than anything is when there's some kind of
componenttext: Well, it's difficult to sort out between deferred maintenance and what is actually needed just because of operations out there. And so they tend to get lumped into the same bucket. So where we see deferrals more than anything is when there's some kind of upgrade like in our Interiors business in that area. But when you see it in Wheels and Brakes, those are just ongoing operational maintenance needs that the airline has to do because they're required to fly the aircraft. Where I think we'll see the deferred maintenance is we watch what airplanes are coming out of the desert, out of storage. That's where we will see deferred maintenance start piling up.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus on the cash side of the house for a second, pre-production excess over average inventory a source of cash for the first time in a long time. Nice swing factor in the quarter in terms of cash performance. Can you, Scott, maybe talk a litt
componenttext: I wanted to focus on the cash side of the house for a second, pre-production excess over average inventory a source of cash for the first time in a long time. Nice swing factor in the quarter in terms of cash performance. Can you, Scott, maybe talk a little bit about that? And also how that folds into the remainder of the this year and into next?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll just kind of talk generally in terms of what we expect, what we call non-product inventory, which includes both R&D as well excess over average in those calculations. Historically, We've talked about that from a growth standpoint. So looking at
componenttext: Yes. I'll just kind of talk generally in terms of what we expect, what we call non-product inventory, which includes both R&D as well excess over average in those calculations. Historically, We've talked about that from a growth standpoint. So looking at our growth spend, excluding any kind of customer participation payments, we've now kind of turned our discussion around to net of those kinds of receipts from customers. So that's why you're seeing an improvement relative to what we talked about before fo 2010. So we're looking at $75 million to $100 million net build in non-product inventory, which is both capitalized R&D and excess over average for 2010. So a use of cash, full year, in the $75 million to $100 million range. And then when we look at 2011, that will go back to more normal levels of $200 million to $250 million of growth in the area. So use of cash in 2011, and a lot of that is just related to timing of participation payments from customers.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of 2001 assumptions on cash, is the new engine option included in that, and is it a swing in either direction?
componenttext: And in terms of 2001 assumptions on cash, is the new engine option included in that, and is it a swing in either direction?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've assumed that in our 2011 forecast, but it's not a big mover in 2011. If they were to go forward, there is some cash flow that we would expend on that program, but it's not a huge mover for 2011.
componenttext: We've assumed that in our 2011 forecast, but it's not a big mover in 2011. If they were to go forward, there is some cash flow that we would expend on that program, but it's not a huge mover for 2011.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: And we'll go to our next question from Rama Bondada with Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to the aftermarket side for 2011, can you give us some more detail of the timing here? Are you assuming this to be more second half 2011 weighted, or is it more steady over the four quarters?
componenttext: Going back to the aftermarket side for 2011, can you give us some more detail of the timing here? Are you assuming this to be more second half 2011 weighted, or is it more steady over the four quarters?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're predicting for us it's fairly steady. I think we'll see sequential growth as we go through the year.
componenttext: We're predicting for us it's fairly steady. I think we'll see sequential growth as we go through the year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then looking at the $0.25 headwind you're expecting for 2011 long-term contracts, I know this is lumpy year-to-year. But can you give us some color on your assumptions here?
componenttext: And then looking at the $0.25 headwind you're expecting for 2011 long-term contracts, I know this is lumpy year-to-year. But can you give us some color on your assumptions here?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Again it's -- headwinds means it's lower, but still favorable adjustments. We're going to get about $75 million roughly of favorable adjustments in 2010. And we're thinking that, that will be more like $25 million pretax in 2011. So $50 million less
componenttext: Sure. Again it's -- headwinds means it's lower, but still favorable adjustments. We're going to get about $75 million roughly of favorable adjustments in 2010. And we're thinking that, that will be more like $25 million pretax in 2011. So $50 million less or about $0.25 a share, but again still positive in both years. The drivers that continue in 2011 continue to be our continuous improvement, lean manufacturing efforts that drive costs down. We still continue to benefit from rising production rates, rising aftermarket, which helps us spread our overall rates, continue to drive cost reductions with our supply chain as well. And then as we add units to certain contracts, that's also a benefit. And those will continue into 2011. Some of the unusual things we got in 2010 that don't repeat are the significant changes in volumes on some of the -- in production aircraft that were announced in 2010, those drive immediate changes to some of those contracts, which we got the benefit of in 2010. And we also had price negotiations that concluded with both customers and suppliers that drove some changes in 2010, and those are lumpy by definition. They depend on when contracts expire.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't mean to harp too much on the spares in the aftermarket, but just your comment about the 10% year-over-year growth in the fourth quarter, and I guess if I look at the falloff you had last year, it seems to imply a sequential falloff from Q3 to Q4 o
componenttext: I don't mean to harp too much on the spares in the aftermarket, but just your comment about the 10% year-over-year growth in the fourth quarter, and I guess if I look at the falloff you had last year, it seems to imply a sequential falloff from Q3 to Q4 of this year in the aftermarket. Am I reading through that right?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We would expect it to be flat. It could be slightly down, it could be slightly up. But the guidance is very close to flat.
componenttext: We would expect it to be flat. It could be slightly down, it could be slightly up. But the guidance is very close to flat.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is there any reason why we're not seeing a continued pickup? Is that a seasonal issue?
componenttext: And is there any reason why we're not seeing a continued pickup? Is that a seasonal issue?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's a little bit of seasonality in there. It's not a huge driver. We just saw some good timing of some orders that we got in the third quarter. It's possible we're being a little bit conservative, but I think, it's just based on what we're seeing in t
componenttext: There's a little bit of seasonality in there. It's not a huge driver. We just saw some good timing of some orders that we got in the third quarter. It's possible we're being a little bit conservative, but I think, it's just based on what we're seeing in terms of order backlog across all of our businesses, the flow of majors that we have in the fourth quarter booked-to-date. All those lead us to guide toward about flat.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sam, if you look at '07 and '08 -- I used those two rather than '09 because '09 everything was going down throughout the year, we saw a third to fourth quarter decline in our aftermarket. So there is a little bit of seasonality because the package carrier
componenttext: Sam, if you look at '07 and '08 -- I used those two rather than '09 because '09 everything was going down throughout the year, we saw a third to fourth quarter decline in our aftermarket. So there is a little bit of seasonality because the package carriers are not going to -- they're flying heck out of their airplanes in the fourth quarter, and you see the same thing around the holidays with the airlines. So there's less opportunity for MRO during the fourth quarter than there is in the third quarter. So we've kind of factored that in, in our forecast, but I think what Scott said is correct. Given the market's been kind of building, we could get surprised with little better quarter that we expect.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In your 5% to 7% assumption for next year, how much is provisional spares? Is that material part of that at all?
componenttext: In your 5% to 7% assumption for next year, how much is provisional spares? Is that material part of that at all?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's not. It's not. Particularly, when we think of the A320 fleet, a fleet like that -- adding aircraft to the fleet doesn't require additional provisional spares.
componenttext: It's not. It's not. Particularly, when we think of the A320 fleet, a fleet like that -- adding aircraft to the fleet doesn't require additional provisional spares.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was thinking more for the initial 787.
componenttext: I was thinking more for the initial 787.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That remains to be seen. I think it'll be small early on, but it'll build over time.
componenttext: That remains to be seen. I think it'll be small early on, but it'll build over time.

componenttext: Marshall, in nacelles, what was the aftermarket on a sequential basis? Because you obviously performed very well with the margin up year-over-year, I was just wondering how it looks sequentially.

componenttext: No, the Boeing is not the only customer where we've received some benefits from participation in programs. So no, it would not be appropriate to assume that, that was all Boeing.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I recently spoke to a peer of yours and they were telling me that they're now beginning to see a recovery in to a higher-value spare parts. I guess you sort of mentioned that when you talked about the majors, but are you seeing any change in as airlines b
componenttext: I recently spoke to a peer of yours and they were telling me that they're now beginning to see a recovery in to a higher-value spare parts. I guess you sort of mentioned that when you talked about the majors, but are you seeing any change in as airlines become more profitable in not only their spend, it's the volume of spend, but what they're spending on?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the closest that I can come to that is to say that we've seen very good backlog on our Interiors business and on our Actuation business, which indicates that we're starting to move up that value a little bit. But I think it's a little early to say t
componenttext: Well, the closest that I can come to that is to say that we've seen very good backlog on our Interiors business and on our Actuation business, which indicates that we're starting to move up that value a little bit. But I think it's a little early to say that. Wheel and Break businesses has been pretty strong in terms of the third quarter versus the previous quarters. So those are reasonably high value for us. So it depends on what you see mean by high value.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to 787 and 747, given sort of the delivery date changes, I know you factored them into your guidance, but were there any sort of changes in schedules as a result of these slips? I know PCB mentioned that there were some changes in their sched
componenttext: With regards to 787 and 747, given sort of the delivery date changes, I know you factored them into your guidance, but were there any sort of changes in schedules as a result of these slips? I know PCB mentioned that there were some changes in their schedules. Are you guys seeing anything as a result of that?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we've been pretty well on track with our shipments to Boeing on 787. So we're tracking exactly as they're expecting the delivery.
componenttext: No, we've been pretty well on track with our shipments to Boeing on 787. So we're tracking exactly as they're expecting the delivery.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from Joe Nadol with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from Joe Nadol with JPMorgan.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, it's Seth Seifman on for Joe this morning. About defense, you guys are looking for a fairly nice 5% to 6% pickup next year. I'm wondering as you look out over the next year to two to three years, are you at all concerned about a significant decl
componenttext: Actually, it's Seth Seifman on for Joe this morning. About defense, you guys are looking for a fairly nice 5% to 6% pickup next year. I'm wondering as you look out over the next year to two to three years, are you at all concerned about a significant decline in defense aftermarket sales as operating tempo comes down. You've already had troops come out of Iraq and probably peaking in Afghanistan. Can you give us some thoughts on defense aftermarket?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there still going to be flying helicopters and there's still going be flying transport aircraft. They're already at a much lower tempo on a fire-type aircraft. We're going to have very limited new platforms like the F-35, so they've got to contain w
componenttext: Well, there still going to be flying helicopters and there's still going be flying transport aircraft. They're already at a much lower tempo on a fire-type aircraft. We're going to have very limited new platforms like the F-35, so they've got to contain what they have. And generally when they end up doing is upgrading also. And we're seeing that particularly on helicopters, but same thing on Joint-STARS and C5s and so on. So we don't see a problem in the next several years. In fact, we think most our defense outlook is in kind of a sweet spot of their budget.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's both. We do a very good detailed bottom-up forecast by value streams and businesses, all of our major businesses and then we corroborate it by looking at industry outlooks like IATA and European Airline Association and ATA and the airlines schedules,
componenttext: It's both. We do a very good detailed bottom-up forecast by value streams and businesses, all of our major businesses and then we corroborate it by looking at industry outlooks like IATA and European Airline Association and ATA and the airlines schedules, OAG. So we really look at it from a number of different directions to hone in on what we think is kind of a reasonable outlook for the year. I was heartened by how the U.S. airlines did in the third quarter and the comments by Doug Parker of U.S. Airways about how they've maintained a pretty good discipline and how Richard Anderson from Delta has said that the structure of the industry right now has certainly promoted a higher profitability. So I think that bodes well for the future here for these airlines.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: and we'll go to our next question from Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: and we'll go to our next question from Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question for you on the DeCrane acquisition and your strategy with regard to the business jet market, generally speaking. Can you give us a sense of what you want to do longer term with business jets? How the DeCrane acquisition fits into tha
componenttext: Just a quick question for you on the DeCrane acquisition and your strategy with regard to the business jet market, generally speaking. Can you give us a sense of what you want to do longer term with business jets? How the DeCrane acquisition fits into that? And specifically with DeCrane, the margin improvement opportunities that you see in that acquisition that you might be able to realize over the next 18 months or so?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, let me tell you that we bottomed at the right time, I think. And secondly, I think we're going to get a fair amount of growth as we've already seen the aftermarket picking up, but we're going to start to see OE growth. It's not hugely
componenttext: Well, first of all, let me tell you that we bottomed at the right time, I think. And secondly, I think we're going to get a fair amount of growth as we've already seen the aftermarket picking up, but we're going to start to see OE growth. It's not hugely robust in 2011 for the entire industry, but it is that the midsize jets and up where a lot of the specialized interior products that DeCrane makes goes into, I think, has a little bit better outlook than the average for the total of the industry. So we're very bullish on where we're going there. But even with the DeCrane acquisition, we're still talking only four to five percentage points of total revenue. And we won't get too far out of line on that. We like specialty areas in the business jet area, but you won't see us ending up with 15% or 20%.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then opportunities for margin expansion in that business that you just...
componenttext: And then opportunities for margin expansion in that business that you just...

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we think that we can take continuous improvement system -- Goodrich operating system and assist those businesses in squeezing even a better margin out. And they're already very good margin businesses. They're well-run businesses.
componenttext: Well, we think that we can take continuous improvement system -- Goodrich operating system and assist those businesses in squeezing even a better margin out. And they're already very good margin businesses. They're well-run businesses.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our next question from Carter Leake with Davenport & Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our next question from Carter Leake with Davenport & Company.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm looking at Paul's famous bubble chart on military sales and in it ISR starts to show good growth opportunities. Could you just give some color on ISR, what you see in that area for growth?
componenttext: I'm looking at Paul's famous bubble chart on military sales and in it ISR starts to show good growth opportunities. Could you just give some color on ISR, what you see in that area for growth?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we have a great opportunity on the ISR side. We'd participate in almost every level of ISR in the optical side, whether it's shortwave, infrared, medium or long, from the very small UAV, all the way up to satellites, YouTube being one of our best
componenttext: I think we have a great opportunity on the ISR side. We'd participate in almost every level of ISR in the optical side, whether it's shortwave, infrared, medium or long, from the very small UAV, all the way up to satellites, YouTube being one of our best platforms out there. So we see the need for intelligence surveillance and reconnaissance as not stopping even when things start winding down whenever in Iraq or Afghanistan because we're still going to have places around this world we want to understand better what's going on. So we see that as a robust opportunity for us going forward.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from George Shapiro with Access 342.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from George Shapiro with Access 342.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: Marshall or Scott, I just needed some clarification. In your walk through from '10 to '11, you've got aftermarket contributing $0.25 a share in earnings, but based on the fact the 5% to 7% growth in each 1% being $0.06, why wouldn't that be $0.30 to $0.42 a share?

componenttext: It could be higher, George. We're just doing round numbers.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: And then just another one, Scott. You had a big increase in CapEx in '11, I mean what's that for relative to the '10 number?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's a number of things. There were a couple of items that were deferred out of 2010 into 2011, as you've probably noticed, we've taken our CapEx guidance for 2010 down a couple times during the year. And that's just the timing of when we're going to n
componenttext: There's a number of things. There were a couple of items that were deferred out of 2010 into 2011, as you've probably noticed, we've taken our CapEx guidance for 2010 down a couple times during the year. And that's just the timing of when we're going to need additional production rate capital for some of the narrowbody activity as well as getting some clarification on where Airbus is going to go with their A320, whether they'll re-engine or not. So that drives some of the timing out into 2011 instead of 2010. And we also have some incremental capital in the next year or two relative to trying to drive more and more production into some lower-cost countries around the world. So we're getting 10% organic topline growth across the company, and we want to make sure we're producing that growth in the lowest areas in the world. So we've got significant capital associated with continuing to drive that. And that would be margin enhancing in the out years.

componenttext: Well, I think there's always a need to make sure we're delivering value to our defense customer. That hasn't changed. That's been there. In terms of the outlook, as I mentioned earlier, I think between helicopters, our HUMS business, our ISR business and some of our aftermarket maintenance businesses that we are positioned very well to take advantage of whatever defense spending there is. So I think that in our case, we are positioned to be in the sweet spot of that defense spending as we go forward.

componenttext: I think near term we're not too concerned about that. Longer term, we continue to get on other kinds of systems within helicopters and within ISR that will help us in that growth rate.

componenttext: And Kenneth, it's not all downside, either. That's a decent model going forward and it benefits both the customer and ourselves. So it's not all downside.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: Just Marshall, I wanted to just check something I thought you said regarding the 2011 estimate. Did you describe the segment margin being around 16% in 2011? And then just thinking over the sort of longer term margin cycle, fantastic Q3, 17.2%. I think that's only been beaten in Q3 of '08 when you did over 18% margin. Where do you think where we are in that margin cycle? I mean how far that the top line growth and maybe less margin? Can you just describe the matrix please.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're very proud of the fact that during 2010, we've advanced the margins without the benefit of our higher-margin aftermarket sales being robust. We've had, in the industry, a pretty tepid growth in the commercial airline aftermarket. So ordinarily
componenttext: Well, we're very proud of the fact that during 2010, we've advanced the margins without the benefit of our higher-margin aftermarket sales being robust. We've had, in the industry, a pretty tepid growth in the commercial airline aftermarket. So ordinarily, you would expect the company like ours with much exposure that we have to the airline aftermarket to have margins affected, but we went the other way. We were able to -- through continuous improvement and enhancing particularly at our Landing Systems business and Electronic Systems business we're able to move the overall total margins up to 17%-plus. As we go move forward, we don't expect to lose that momentum on continuous improvement, and we do expect to see a more robust aftermarket in 2011 and 2012. So I think we can both move top line and bottom line.

componenttext: With the engine guys reporting such robust double-digit growth in the quarter, you had a low single-digit sales comp, both sequentially and year-over-year. componenttext: Also remember that they were the orders, I think on the engine side, were off a very low third quarter of last year, too. So I think as we see more airline activity going forward and we will see nacelle piece part and major activities, so it's a question of how good are we forecasting as an industry, that 4% to 6% ASM growth. Because I think that has the potential if the worldwide economy continues to improve of going higher. And our piece parts are not as discretionary as maybe majors. And majors will come as those engine orders, those big engine orders come also. So I saw it as a good sign that they were getting those kinds of orders, but I'm not going to count my chickens before they hatch.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: If we look back three to six months ago, no. We were talking about just the normal change that we would expect to see year-over-year in pension related to changes in discount rates and returns as they go through the year. So it wasn't anticipated three to
componenttext: If we look back three to six months ago, no. We were talking about just the normal change that we would expect to see year-over-year in pension related to changes in discount rates and returns as they go through the year. So it wasn't anticipated three to six months ago. But it's something that we look at every year about this time in terms of how to set the actuarial assumptions for the following year. And as we got into that process this year, we realized that we're meeting the definition of having nearly all of our pension plan participants in inactive status and that gives you -- it actually requires you to make that change in terms of your amortization period as we described in opening comments.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Scott, if we look at the swing on the headwinds that existed six months ago in '11, before you did the data and adjusted forward the prepayment, et cetera to the headwind to the tailwind we have now, what portion of it was from the actuarial adjustment
componenttext: So Scott, if we look at the swing on the headwinds that existed six months ago in '11, before you did the data and adjusted forward the prepayment, et cetera to the headwind to the tailwind we have now, what portion of it was from the actuarial adjustment?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can give you a kind of general walk. 2010 pension expense it will be about $162 million. And if we had, had flat discount rates, normal rate of return, we would have been at $146 million pretax for 2011. The discount rate change that we've seen in the f
componenttext: I can give you a kind of general walk. 2010 pension expense it will be about $162 million. And if we had, had flat discount rates, normal rate of return, we would have been at $146 million pretax for 2011. The discount rate change that we've seen in the first nine months of the year going from 5.9% down to 5%, that would have cost us about another $57 million in pension expense. So that would have pushed us to about $203 million. Then in addition -- then we've done two things to reduce that. One is the actuarial change. The other is we did some accelerated contributions to the plan. Between those two, we did about $100 million reduction and then we're offsetting a bit of that by becoming a little more conservative in our long-term rate of return assumptions, mortality tables, et cetera. Then again, that will reduce the volatility of those sensitivities going forward. So as discount rates change, return assumptions are either above or below what our expectation is, we'll see less volatility in expense going forward. So those are the major movers.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: We would still expect to be around $32 million a quarter on the corp line and another $6 million a quarter in the other expense line. So again unusual items in the quarter. So quarter expenses are being well controlled and should go back to that $32 million a quarter roughly.

componenttext: The implied margin in 4Q looks to be -- if we're assuming a $7 billion top line, looks to assume just over 15% on the 15.1%, 15.2% on the segment line, I think. I'm just wondering is that mixed? What are the downside here? I know EAC is a contributor, but that's not all of it.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you re right. We're assuming around 15% margins in the fourth quarter, and there's three drivers to that. One is the lower level of contract adjustments that takes about a point off of the margin when you go from Q3 to Q4. We're also expecting some h
componenttext: Yes, you re right. We're assuming around 15% margins in the fourth quarter, and there's three drivers to that. One is the lower level of contract adjustments that takes about a point off of the margin when you go from Q3 to Q4. We're also expecting some higher low-charge shipments of wheels and brakes into the commercial and regional market in the fourth quarter, and that actually continues on into 2011. That's going to cost us maybe 3/10 of a point. And then the DeCrane acquisition adds sales in the quarter, but remember because of purchase accounting, you have to write up the inventory to full fair value so you get very little margin in the fourth quarter. So you get sales with no margin in that business until you flushed the inventory. So that's about another almost half a point to margin in the quarter. So that gaps most of the Q3 to Q4 margin.
